title: Williams v. State
description: In this appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the post-conviction relief (PCR) judge's finding that registration on the sexual offender registry is a collateral consequence of sentencing.  The petitioner pled guilty to kidnapping and other charges.  The petitioner's trial counsel did not ask the trial judge to make a finding on the record that the kidnapping did not include a criminal sexual offense.  Consequently, the petitioner was classified as a sexual offender, which will require him to register on the sexual offender registry upon his release from prison.  The petitioner filed a PCR application, claiming his trial counsel was ineffective for failing to ask the trial judge to make a finding on the record as to the nature of the kidnapping.  Finding registration is a collateral consequence of sentencing, the PCR judge dismissed the application.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Dexter Antonio
      Williams, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge
Â Alison Renee Lee, Post-Conviction Relief
  Judge
Opinion No. 4398
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Assistant Appellate Defender M. Celia Robinson, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Brian T. Petrano, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Dexter Antonio Williams (Williams) appeals the Post-Conviction
  Relief (PCR) judgeâ€™s finding that Williamsâ€™ trial counsel was not ineffective
  for failing to move to exempt Williams from sexual offender status and for not
  advising Williams he would be required to register as a sexual offender unless
  the trial court ordered otherwise.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Williams pled guilty to kidnapping, two counts of armed robbery,
  possession of a stolen motor vehicle, failure to stop for a blue light, and
  possession of a gun by a person under the age of twenty-one.Â  Pursuant to section 23-3-430(C)(15) of the South
  Carolina Code (2007), a defendant over the age of eighteen who pleads guilty to
  kidnapping will be classified as a sexual offender unless the trial court makes
  a finding on the record that the kidnapping did not include a criminal sexual
  offense.Â  Williamsâ€™ trial counsel did not ask the trial court to make a
  determination as to the nature of the kidnapping.Â Â Â  
Subsequent to Williamsâ€™ guilty plea, Williams filed a PCR
  application claiming ineffective assistance of counsel. Â A PCR hearing was held,
  and Williams argued his trial counsel was ineffective for failing to ask the
  trial court to make a finding of fact on the record that Williamsâ€™
  participation in the kidnapping was not sexual in nature, which would relieve
  Williams of having to register as a sexual offender upon his release from
  prison.Â  The PCR judge held registration on the sexual offender registry
  was a collateral consequence of Williamsâ€™ sentence, and Williamsâ€™ application
  was dismissed.Â  Williams then filed a petition for writ of certiorari, which this
  Court granted.[1] Â This appeal follows.Â Â  Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThis Court will sustain the PCR judgeâ€™s factual
  findings and conclusions regarding ineffective assistance of counsel if there
  is any probative evidence to support those findings.â€Â  Hutto v. State,
  376 S.C. 77, 80, 654 S.E.2d 846, 847 (Ct. App. 2007).
LAW/ANALYSIS

Williams argues his
  trial counsel was ineffective: (1) for failing to move to exempt Williams from
  sexual offender status because the kidnapping charge against him was not sexual
  in nature; and (2) for failing to advise Williams he would be required to
  register as a sexual offender unless the trial court ordered otherwise.Â  We
  disagree.Â  
To establish a
  claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, a PCR applicant must prove trial
  counselâ€™s performance was deficient, and due to this deficient representation,
  the applicant was prejudiced.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984).Â  This same standard applies to a guilty plea.Â  Alexander v. State,
  303 S.C. 539, 542, 402 S.E.2d 484, 485 (1991).Â  
â€œThe
  imposition of a sentence may have a number of collateral consequences, however,
  and a plea of guilty is not rendered involuntary in a constitutional sense if
  the defendant is not informed of the collateral consequences.â€Â  Brown
    v. State, 306 S.C. 381, 382-83, 412 S.E.2d 399, 400 (1991) (emphasis in
  original).Â  Thus, a defendant need not be advised of all collateral
  consequences of his or her plea in order for the plea to withstand
  constitutional scrutiny.Â  Id.; see also Cuthrell v. Dir.,
    Patuxent Inst., 475 F.2d 1364, 1365-66 (4th Cir. 1973) (â€œ[B]efore pleading,
  the defendant need not be advised of all collateral consequences of his plea .
  . . .â€).Â  â€œ[A]side from two non-collateral matters specifically listed in the
  PCR Act, PCR is a proper avenue of relief only when the applicant mounts a
    collateral attack challenging the validity of his conviction or sentence .
  . . .â€Â  Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 367, 527 S.E.2d 742, 749
  (2000) (emphasis in original).Â Â Â  
The pivotal
  question of whether Williamsâ€™ counsel was ineffective for failing to ask the
  trial court to make a finding on the record that Williamsâ€™ kidnapping charge
  was not sexual in nature, therefore, depends on whether registration on the
  sexual offender registry is a collateral consequence of sentencing.Â  If
  registration is a collateral consequence of sentencing, Williamsâ€™ trial counsel
  cannot be viewed as ineffective for failing to advise Williams of the registration
  requirement, and by implication, trial counsel cannot be deemed ineffective for
  failing to move to exempt Williams from sexual offender status.Â Â  Â Â 
â€œThe
  distinction between â€˜directâ€™ and â€˜collateralâ€™ consequences of a plea, while
  sometimes shaded in the relevant decisions, turns on whether the result
  represents a definite, immediate and largely automatic effect on the range of
  the defendantâ€™s punishment.â€Â  Cuthrell, 475 F.2d at 1366.Â  Therefore, a
  consequence that the defendant must be informed of is one which impacts the
  sentence imposed on the defendant, and as such, is a direct consequence.Â  See State v. Armstrong, 263 S.C. 594, 598, 211 S.E.2d 889, 891 (1975)
  (stating the defendant must be apprised of the direct consequences, which are
  the direct and immediate results, of his guilty plea).Â  Â Â Â 
Registration
  on the sexual offender registry has no effect on the range of Williamsâ€™
  punishment.Â  Registration is not intended to punish sex offenders, but rather
  the purpose of requiring registration is â€œto protect the public from those sex
  offenders who may re-offend and to aid law enforcement in solving sex crimes.â€Â  State v. Walls, 348 S.C. 26, 31, 558 S.E.2d 524, 526 (2002).Â  The South
  Carolina Sex Offender Registry Act (the Act) was created to be a non-punitive
  act, and our Supreme Court has found that â€œthe Act is not so punitive in
  purpose or effect as to constitute a criminal penalty.â€Â  Id.Â  Thus, the
  consequence of registering as a sexual offender pursuant to the Act is
  regulatory in nature and is imposed to promote public safety.Â  Accordingly, we agree
  with the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that registration on the sexual offender registry
  is a collateral consequence of Williamsâ€™ sentencing.Â  Consequently, Williamsâ€™
  trial counsel was not ineffective for failing to request the trial court to
  make a determination as to whether the kidnapping was sexual in nature.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the decision of the PCR judge is
AFFIRMED.[2]
SHORT,
  J., and CURETON, AJ., concur.Â  


[1] In granting Williamsâ€™ petition, we requested the
  parties to brief whether the
  PCR court was correct for finding Williamsâ€™ counsel was not ineffective for
  failing to move to exempt Williams from sexual offender status and whether the
  PCR court was correct for finding Williamsâ€™ counsel was not ineffective for
  failing to advise Williams that he would be required to register as a sexual
  offender unless the trial court ordered otherwise.Â  These issues are our sole
  appellate considerations.Â Â Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â

title: Pelzer v. State
description: In this PCR case, appellant requests the case be remanded to the circuit court for a full hearing arguing the statute of limitations should be tolled because his application was filed in the wrong venue.
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of
  Appeals

	
		
			
				Nathaniel K. Pelzer, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF
  CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
Thomas W.
  Cooper, Circuit Court Judge
Alison Renee
  Lee, Post-Conviction Relief Judge
Opinion No. 4399
Submitted June
  1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M.
  Pachak, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry D.
  McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy
  Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Brian T.
  Petrano, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.:Â 
  Nathaniel K. Pelzer (â€œPelzerâ€) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s summary dismissal of
  his application for post-conviction relief (PCR) for failure to file within the
  applicable statute of limitations. Â We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL
  / PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On
  June 4, 2001, Pelzer pled guilty to first degree criminal sexual conduct and
  kidnapping in Richland County.Â  Two twenty year, concurrent sentences were
  imposed.Â  Pelzerâ€™s direct appeal was withdrawn on August 31, 2001.Â  
Pelzer
  filed an application for post-conviction relief on September 16, 2002. Â Included
  in his application were arguments based on (1) ineffective assistance of
  counsel, (2) lack of subject matter jurisdiction, (3) involuntary plea, and (4)
  violation of due process. Â The State filed a return and motion to dismiss dated
  July 25, 2003, and a hearing was held July 27, 2004.Â  The State asserted Pelzer
  failed to comply with the one-year statute of limitations for filing post
  conviction relief applications.Â  Additionally, the State moved for summary
  judgment on Pelzerâ€™s claim that the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction
  over his preliminary hearing.Â  
The
  record indicates Pelzerâ€™s application was notarized August 30, 2002, and Pelzer
  asserts it was mailed the same day.Â  However, he admits it was incorrectly sent
  to the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense who then forwarded the
  application on September 5th to the proper recipient, the Richland
  County Clerk of Court.Â  
The
  circuit judge issued an order denying and dismissing Pelzerâ€™s application for
  failing to comply with the one-year statute of limitations.Â  His claim of lack
  of subject matter jurisdiction was likewise dismissed.Â  A petition for writ of
  certiorari dated April 11, 2005, was filed.Â  Pursuant to Rule 227(1), SCACR,
  the South Carolina Supreme Court transferred the case to this court.Â  
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
Summary
  dismissal of a PCR application without a hearing is appropriate only when (1)
  it is apparent on the face of the application that there is no need for a
  hearing to develop any facts and (2) the applicant is not entitled to relief.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-70(b)-(c) (2003); State v. Leamon, 363 S.C. 432,
  611 S.E.2d 494 (2005). Â â€œWhen considering the Stateâ€™s
  motion for summary dismissal of an application for PCR, a judge must assume
  facts presented by an applicant are true and view those facts in the light most
  favorable to the applicant.â€Â  Wilson v. State, 348 S.C. 215, 217, 559
  S.E.2d 581, 582 (2002) (citing Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 363,
  527 S.E.2d 742, 747 (2000)).Â  Likewise, this court must view the facts in the
  same fashion when reviewing the appropriateness of a dismissal.Â  Leamon,
  363 S.C. at 434, 611 S.E.2d at 494.Â  
LAW
  / ANALYSIS
Pelzer
  requests his case be remanded for a full hearing arguing the statute of
  limitations should be equitably tolled because he filed his application in the
  wrong venue.Â  
The
  statute of limitations for filing an application for PCR is one year.Â  Section
  17-27-45(A) of the South Carolina Code provides:

	An application for relief filed
  pursuant to this chapter must be filed within one year after the entry of
  judgment of conviction or within one year after the sending of the remittitur
  to the lower court from an appeal or the filing of the final decision upon an
  appeal, whichever is later.Â  

Mailing
  does not constitute filing.Â  State v. Gary, 347 S.C.627, 629, 557 S.E.2d
  662, 663 (2001).Â  â€œWhen a statute requires the filing of a paper or document,
  it is filed when delivered to and received by the proper officer.â€Â  Gary, 347 S.C. at 629, 557 S.E.2d at 663 (citing Fox v. Union-Buffalo Mills,
  226 S.C. 561, 86 S.E.2d 253 (1955)).Â  â€œUnder S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-40 (1985),
  the application must be filed with clerk of the court in which the conviction
  took place.â€Â  Id.Â  
Pelzerâ€™s remittitur is dated August 31, 2001.Â  One year after was August 31, 2002, and
  adding one day pursuant to Rule 6(a), SCRCP, Pelzerâ€™s last day to file his
  application was September 1, 2002.Â  Because September 1st was a
  Sunday and Monday, September 2nd, was Labor Day, the period runs
  until the end of the next day that is neither a Saturday, Sunday, nor a
  holiday.Â  Rule 6(a), SCRCP.Â  Thus, the period expired Tuesday, September 3,
  2002.Â  
Pelzer
  admits the application was not â€œtechnicallyâ€ filed within one year.Â  However,
  statutes of limitations are not simply technicalities, but are fundamental to a
  well-ordered judicial system.Â  Moates v. Bobb, 322 S.C. 172, 176, 470
  S.E.2d 402, 404 (Ct. App. 1996) (citing C.S.J. Limitations of Actions Â§
  2 (1989)).Â  

	Statutes of limitations embody important
  public policy considerations in that they stimulate activity, punish
  negligence, and promote repose by giving security and stability to human
  affairs.Â  One purpose of a statute of limitations is to relieve the courts of
  the burden of trying stale claims when a plaintiff has slept on his rights.Â 
  Another purpose of a statute of limitations is to protect potential defendants
  from protracted fear of litigation.

Id.
Equitable
  tolling is a doctrine rarely applied in South Carolina to stop the running of
  statutes of limitations.Â  Hooper v. Ebenezer Senior Svcs. and Rehabilitation
    Ctr., 377 S.C. 217, 230, 659 S.E.2d 213, 219 (Ct. App. 2008).Â  â€œEquitable
  tolling is reserved for extraordinary circumstances.â€Â  Id.; see, e.g., Irwin v. Depâ€™t of Veterans Affairs, 498 U.S. 89, 96 (1990) (stating that
  while equitable tolling was allowed where claimant actively pursued remedies
  but filed defective pleading, or was induced by adversary into allowing
  deadline to pass, â€œ[w]e have generally been much less forgiving in receiving
  late filings where the claimant failed to exercise due diligence in preserving
  his legal rights.â€); Hopkins v. Floydâ€™s Wholesale, 299 S.C. 127, 382
  S.E.2d 907 (1989) (holding statute of limitations equitably tolled for workersâ€™
  compensation claim during reliance period in which employer represented to
  employee that claim compensable and would be taken care of without employee
  filing claim). Â The doctrine of equitable tolling can be summarized:

	The time requirements in lawsuits
  between private litigants are customarily subject to equitable tolling if such
  tolling is necessary to prevent unfairness to a diligent plaintiff.Â  However,
  equitable tolling, which allows a plaintiff to initiate an action beyond the
  statute of limitations deadline, is typically available only if the claimant
  was prevented in some extraordinary way from exercising his or her rights, or,
  in other words, if the relevant facts present sufficiently rare and exceptional
  circumstances that would warrant application of the doctrine.
	
		
			
				Equitable tolling has been deemed 
				available whereâ€” 
 
			
			
				â€”
				extraordinary circumstances prevented the 
				plaintiff from filing despite his or her diligence.
 
			
			
				â€”
				the plaintiff actively pursued his or her 
				judicial remedies by filing a defective pleading during the 
				statutory period or the claimant has been induced or tricked by 
				the defendant's misconduct into allowing the filing deadline to 
				pass.
 
			
			
				â€”
				the plaintiff, despite all due diligence, is 
				unable to obtain vital information bearing on the existence of 
				his or her claim. 
			
		
	
	It has been held that equitable tolling
  applies principally if the plaintiff is actively misled by the defendant about
  the cause of action or is prevented in some extraordinary way from asserting
  his or her rights.Â  However, it has also been held that the equitable tolling
  doctrine does not require wrongful conduct on the part of the defendant, such
  as fraud or misrepresentation.

51
  Am. Jur. 2d Limitation of Actions Â§ 174 (2007); see also Hooper,
  377 S.C. at 232, 659 S.E.2d at 221.Â  
Here,
  Pelzer has not alleged any wrongdoing by the State. Â Rather, Pelzer relies on
  our Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Gary v. State, 347 S.C. 627, 557 S.E.2d
  662 (2001), to demand equitable tolling. Â We find this reliance misplaced.Â 
  Pelzer states Gary held â€œthat the statute of limitations should be
  equitably tolled when an application is simply filed in the wrong venue.â€Â Â  In Gary, the applicant claimed he had mailed his PCR application within the one-year
  limitation period but to the wrong place.Â  The period had run when the
  application came back.Â  Our Supreme Court did not address his equitable tolling
  argument finding it was not preserved.Â  A footnote specifically clarified,
  â€œ[w]e express no opinion on the validity of this defense to the statute of
  limitations.â€Â  Id. at 629, 557 S.E.2d at 663, n. 2.
At the dismissal hearing, Pelzerâ€™s counsel contended
  Pelzerâ€™s misunderstanding of where to file was â€œunderstandable given his status
  as a layman and his lack of knowledge of the law.â€Â  We disagree that his error
  resulted from any lack of legal skill rather than simple neglect.Â  Pelzerâ€™s PCR
  application, which was filled out by hand and signed, clearly instructs:Â  â€œWhen
  the application is completed, the original shall be mailed to the Clerk of
  Court for the County in which applicant was convicted.â€Â  Three lines below this
  directive, the applicant is asked to name the location of the court which
  imposed his sentence.Â  Pelzer answered â€œRichland County.â€Â  Under these facts,
  the narrow window by which Pelzerâ€™s application missed the statute of limitations
  cannot be construed as so exceptional a circumstance as to warrant equitable
  tolling.Â  The reasoning of the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in
  denying equitable tolling to a party is particularly illuminating:

	[A]ny invocation of equity
  to relieve the strict application of a statute of limitations must be guarded and infrequent, lest
  circumstances of individualized hardship supplant the rules of clearly drafted
  statutes. To apply equity generously would loose the rule of law to whims about
  the adequacy of excuses, divergent responses to claims of hardship, and
  subjective notions of fair accommodation. We believe, therefore, that any
  resort to equity must be reserved for those rare instances where--due to
  circumstances external to the party's own conduct--it would be unconscionable
  to enforce the limitation period against the party and gross injustice would
  result.

Harris v. Hutchinson, 209 F.3d 325, 330 (4th Cir. 2000) (holding habeas petitionerâ€™s missing filing deadline due to
  erroneous advice from counsel not extraordinary circumstance requiring equitable
  tolling).
For
  the foregoing reasons, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary dismissal
  of Pelzerâ€™s PCR application.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1]Â  We decide
  this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Bryson v. Bryson
description: In this appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the special referee's exclusion of one of the appellant's witnesses and denial of the appellant's motion for a nonsuit.  The Court of Appeals also declined to address the appellant's argument concerning the order for repayment of monies from a sale of property due to the lack of authority cited in the appellant's brief.  The personal representative of the decedent's estate brought an action against the appellant, who held the deceden's power of attorney, alleging breach of fiduciary duty, conversion, and fraud.  At trial, the special referee excluded one of the appellant's witnesses and also denied the appellant's motion for a nonsuit.  The special referee subsequently found the appellant breached his fiduciary duty and ordered monetary damages to be paid to the estate.  The special referee also set aside a deed of real property between the decedent and the appellant.

<!--

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Carl N. Bryson,
      as Personal Representative of the Estate of Conrad Ardell Bryson and its
      heirs, Respondent,
				v.
				Herman Billy
      Bryson, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Referee
Opinion No.Â  4400
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5, 2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David R. Harrison, of Pickens, for Appellant.
				William Douglas Richardson, of Easley, for Respondent.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Carl N. Bryson (Carl), as personal representative (PR) of Conrad
  Ardell Brysonâ€™s (Ardell) estate, sued Herman Billy Bryson (Billy) for breach of
  fiduciary duty.Â  The special referee awarded the estate $306,786.49 in damages
  and set aside a deed that Ardell transferred to Billy.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On December 8, 1997, Ardell appointed
  Billy, his half-brother, as his power of attorney.Â  From 2001 until Ardellâ€™s
  death, Billy spent time with Ardell and took him to the doctor.Â  In 1997, Dr.
  Thomas E. Parrish (Dr. Parrish) diagnosed Ardell with severe dementia, and
  later in 1998, Dr. Parrish diagnosed Ardell with Alzheimerâ€™s disease.Â  Billy
  testified he was unaware of the diagnoses.Â  However, several witnesses
  testified Ardellâ€™s symptoms and behavior stemming from Alzheimerâ€™s disease were
  apparent.Â  Â Â 
At
  trial, Dr. Parrish opined to a reasonable degree of medical certainty, Ardell
  was not capable of caring for himself.Â  Furthermore, Dr. Parrish testified
  Ardell did not have the mental competency to make everyday decisions, transfer
  personal or real property, or handle his finances.Â  Glenda Bryson Smith
  (Glenda) and Laura Jane Smith (Laura), Ardellâ€™s caretakers, testified Ardell displayed
  signs of his illness and acted in a childlike manner.Â  Further, Glenda
  testified Billy hired her to care for Ardell and he knew about Ardellâ€™s
  condition.Â  
After Billyâ€™s
  power of attorney appointment, he and Ardell opened a joint bank account, and
  several checks were written from that account.Â  One check for $50,000 was
  written as a loan to an insurance company, which Billy testified was an
  investment in Hal Blackwell Insurance Company.Â  Billy paid off his sonâ€™s
  mortgage with another check from the joint account in the amount of $25,877.Â  Billy
  also purchased a car, paid for home improvements, took out cash, and made
  several other purchases for his personal benefit with Ardellâ€™s funds while
  acting as Ardellâ€™s power of attorney.Â  Additionally, Ardell deeded property to
  Billy without consideration on August 8, 2002.Â Â Â  
Carl, as PR of Ardellâ€™s estate, filed a
  summons and complaint against Billy in Pickens County on August 18, 2004,
  alleging Billy breached his fiduciary duty as Ardellâ€™s power of attorney and
  committed fraud and conversion.Â  Billyâ€™s answer sought dismissal of the action,
  but the case proceeded to trial in front of a special referee.[1]Â  
At trial, Billy sought to have Ardellâ€™s neighbor, Brian Lloyd
  Smith (Smith), a witness whom Billy did not name in his answers to the
  interrogatories and whom Carl was not informed of until the morning of the
  trial, testify as to his observations of Ardell.Â  The special referee allowed
  Billy to proffer Smithâ€™s testimony but ultimately excluded the evidence.Â  Additionally,
  at the close of trial, Billy moved for an involuntary nonsuit, claiming Carl
  was not the real party in interest.Â  The special referee denied this motion.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The special referee found Billy breached his fiduciary duty to
  Ardell and awarded the estate $306,786.49.Â  Additionally, the special referee ordered
  the deed of real property, which Ardell transferred to Billy and executed on
  August 8, 2002, be set aside in its entirety except for the portion of the
  parcel Ardell transferred to Providence Christian Academy.Â  The special referee
  ordered the property be included in Ardellâ€™s estate.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œ[A] claim of
  breach of fiduciary duty is an action at law[,] and the trial [courtâ€™s]
  findings will be upheld unless without evidentiary support.â€Â  Jordan v. Holt, 362 S.C. 201, 205, 608 S.E.2d 129, 131 (2005).Â  Accordingly, our
  standard of review extends only to the correction of errors of law, and â€œwe
  will not disturb the refereeâ€™s factual findings that have some evidentiary
  support.â€Â  Jones v. Daley, 363 S.C. 310, 314, 609 S.E.2d 597, 599 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Exclusion of a Witness
Billy contends the special referee erred in excluding
  Smithâ€™s testimony.Â  We disagree.Â  Â Â 
â€œThe
  decision of whether or not to allow a witness to testify who was not previously
  listed on answers to interrogatories rests within the sound discretion of the
  trial [court].â€ Â Jumper v. Hawkins, 348 S.C. 142, 150, 558 S.E.2d 911,
  915 (Ct. App. 2001) (citation omitted). Â â€œExclusion of a witness is a sanction
  which should never be lightly invoked.â€Â  Id. at 149, 558 S.E.2d at 915
  (citation omitted).Â  Before imposing the sanction of excluding a witness, a
  trial court is required to consider and evaluate several factors:Â  

	(1) the
  type of witness involved; (2) the content of the evidence emanating from the
  proffered witness; (3) the nature of the failure or neglect or refusal to
  furnish the witnessâ€™ name; (4) the degree of surprise to the other party,
  including the prior knowledge of the name of the witness; and (5) the prejudice
  to the opposing party.

Id. at 152, 558 S.E.2d at 916.Â  
In Barnette
  v. Adams Bros. Logging, Inc., the South Carolina Supreme Court found the
  trial court abused its discretion in excluding an expert witness when there was
  no disobedience of any court order and no prejudice to the opposing party other
  than necessity of further discovery.Â  355 S.C. 588, 593, 586 S.E.2d 572, 575
  (2003).Â  Additionally, our Supreme Court stated the exclusion rule is designed
  to promote decisions on the merits after a full and fair hearing, and the trial
  courtâ€™s sanction should serve to protect the rights of discovery provided by
  the rules of civil procedure.Â  Id. at 592, 586 S.E.2d at 574. Â In
  recognizing the potentially harsh sanctions a trial court may invoke in
  addition to the sanction of exclusion of a witness, our Supreme Court noted, â€œA
  sanction of dismissal is too severe if there is no evidence of any intentional
  misconduct.â€Â  Id. (internal citations omitted). 
Similarly,
  in Orlando v. Boyd, the South Carolina Supreme Court reversed the trial
  courtâ€™s sanction when no evidence of intentional misconduct existed in the
  record to â€œwarrant the exclusion of a crucial witness.â€Â  320 S.C. 509, 512, 466
  S.E.2d 353, 355 (1996).Â  Our Supreme Court held, â€œ[When] the effect will be the
  same as granting judgment by default or dismissal, a preclusion order may be
  made only if there is some showing of willful disobedience or gross
  indifference to the rights of the adverse party.â€Â  Id. at 511, 466
  S.E.2d at 355.
Previously, this Court found it is within the trial
  courtâ€™s discretion to allow an appropriate sanction when a party fails to
  strictly comply with a scheduling order.Â  Arthur v. Sexton Dental Clinic,
  368 S.C. 326, 338, 628 S.E.2d 894, 900 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Therefore, when
  noncompliance is undisputed, the question becomes whether the trial court
  abused its discretion in imposing exclusion of a witness as a sanction.Â  Id.Â  Though the trial court did not specifically enunciate the Jumper factors, this Court found the trial court â€œconsidered the requisite factors and
  made the appropriate inquiry before ultimately excluding the challenged
  witnesses.â€Â  Id. at 339, 628 S.E.2d at 901.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In
  the present case, Billy attempted to call Smith as a witness, and Carl objected
  because Smithâ€™s name was not provided in the answers to interrogatories.Â 
  Additionally, Carl was not informed Billy was calling Smith as a witness until
  the morning of the trial.Â  The special referee allowed Billy to proffer Smithâ€™s
  testimony, and based on the content of Smithâ€™s proffer, the special referee
  excluded Smith as a witness.Â  By virtue of the proffer, we find the special
  referee properly considered the Jumper factors.Â  Cf. Jumper,
  348 S.C. at 150-51, 558 S.E.2d at 916 (â€œ[T]he court never made an inquiry into
  the content of the evidence [the expert witness] would offer. By not getting any information about the proposed witnessâ€™ testimony, the court did not meet its
  duty of discovering and evaluating the content of the potential evidence.â€)
  (emphasis in original).
Billy
  wished to call Smith as a fact witness,[2] and through his proffer, Smith explained he had known Ardell his whole life and
  was his neighbor for several years.Â  Smith also stated Ardellâ€™s will named the
  chairman of the board of deacons of their church as administrator of his
  estate.Â  Further, Smith stated Ardell appeared lucid, competent, and able to
  understand conversations.Â  Therefore, the special referee properly considered
  the type of witness Smith would be and the content of his proposed testimony as
  required by the first and second factors of Jumper.Â  
Additionally,
  the special referee satisfied the third Jumper factor by considering the
  nature of Billyâ€™s failure to furnish Smithâ€™s name as a witness, stating, â€œIt is
  clear from his testimony he is here as a result of a conversation with your
  client prior to ever receiving a letter from [Carlâ€™s attorney].Â  And the
  motivating factor was a personal contact with your client as opposed to
  notification that there was a trial.â€Â  
As
  to the fourth and fifth Jumper factors, this late notification
  inevitably created significant surprise and prejudice to Ardellâ€™s estate and
  its representatives.Â  The failure to inform the estate until the morning of the
  trial that Smith would be a witness left the estate with an insufficient amount
  of time to adequately prepare for an examination of Smith and eliminated the
  estateâ€™s opportunity to depose Smith.Â  See Arthur, 368 S.C. at
  341, 628 S.E.2d at 902 (finding the respondent was significantly surprised and
  prejudiced when the appellant failed to give notice of two witnesses until the
  Friday before trial because the respondent was not able to depose the witnesses
  before trial). Â 
Based
  on the foregoing, we find the special referee properly considered all factors
  set forth in Jumper when deciding to exclude Smith as a witness, and
  therefore, the exclusion was not an abuse of discretion.Â  Â Â 

II.Â  Involuntary Nonsuit
Billy also contends
  the special referee erred in failing to grant his motion for an involuntary nonsuit.Â 
  Specifically, Billy argues Carl, as PR of Ardellâ€™s estate, is not the real
  party in interest.Â  We disagree.Â  Â 

	Rule
  17(a), SCRCP, provides in part: 
	
		Every
  action shall be prosecuted in the name of the real party in interest.Â  An
  executor, administrator, guardian, bailee, trustee of an express trust, a party
  with whom or in whose name a contract has been made for the benefit of another,
  or a party authorized by statute may sue in his own name without joining with
  him the party for whose benefit the action is brought; and when a statute so
  provides, an action for the use or benefit of another shall be brought in the
  name of the State.
	

Unless
  a party promptly challenges the opposing partyâ€™s status as a real party in
  interest, such a challenge is waived.Â  Bardoon Props., NV v. Eidolon Corp.,
  326 S.C. 166, 169, 485 S.E.2d 371, 373 (1997) (â€œA challenge to a partyâ€™s status
  as real party in interest must be made promptly or the court may conclude the
  point has been waived.â€).
We
  find Billy waived his right to challenge Carlâ€™s status as the real party in
  interest.Â  Billy first raised this argument at the close of trial.[3]Â 
  Although Billy asserts he raised such a motion at the beginning of trial as
  well, the record is devoid of such evidence.Â  As the appellant, Billy bears the
  burden of presenting a sufficient record for review. Â See Helms
    Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 339-40, 611 S.E.2d 485, 487-88
  (2005) (stating the appellant has the burden of providing a sufficient record
  on appeal).Â  
Because
  Billy has failed to provide a sufficient record for our review in this matter,
  we affirm the special refereeâ€™s denial of Billyâ€™s motion for an involuntary
  nonsuit.Â  See Goode v. St. Stephens United Methodist Church, 329
  S.C. 433, 447, 494 S.E.2d 827, 834 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding the appellate court
  must affirm the trial court on an issue when the appellant fails to provide
  adequate materials for this Court to consider the argument).Â  Â Â Â 
III.Â  Repayment from
  Property Sale
Finally,
  Billy argues the special referee erred in ordering him to repay monies from a
  sale of property when the special referee did not set aside the sale of
  property.Â  We find this issue abandoned on appeal.Â  
An
  issue is deemed abandoned and will not be considered on appeal if the argument
  is raised in a brief but not supported by authority. Historic Charleston
    Holdings, L.L.C. v. Mallon, 365 S.C. 524, 533 n.7, 617 S.E.2d 388, 393 n.7
  (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Billy failed to cite any authority in support of his
  assertion the special referee erred in ordering him to repay proceeds from the
  sale of property.Â  Therefore, Billy abandoned this issue on appeal, and we
  decline to consider the argument.Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the special refereeâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[4]
THOMAS
  and PIEPER, JJ., concur.Â  


[1] Both parties consented to have this matter referred
  to a special referee.
[2] We note Barnette and Orlando involved
  the exclusion of expert witnesses rather than the exclusion of a lay witness as
  in the present case.Â  After excluding the expert witnesses, the trial courts
  dismissed the cases.Â Â Â  Barnette, 355 S.C. at 591, 586 S.E.2d at 574; Orlando, 320 S.C. at 511, 466 S.E.2d at 355.Â  The exclusion of Smithâ€™s testimony,
  however, did not lead to such a dramatic result.Â  Further, Smithâ€™s testimony,
  while favorable to Billy, was not as crucial to the case as were the witnessesâ€™
  testimonies in Barnette and Orlando.Â  These distinctions support
  the conclusion the special refereeâ€™s exclusion was not an abuse of discretion.Â  
[3] Billy argues Ardell appointed members of the Six Mile Baptist Church as executors of his estate through his will and made no provisions
  for a PR.
[4] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Doe v. Roe
description: John Doe (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s order terminating his parental rights to his biological child (Child) and ordering payment of his attorney's fees and $1,635.50 in guardian ad litem fees.  We reverse and remand.
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John Doe, Appellant,
				v.
				Jane Roe, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Anne GuÃ© Jones, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 4401
Heard May 7, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5, 2008
REVERSED AND REMANDED 


	
		
			
				Holly Huggins
  Wall, of Johnsonville, for Appellant.
				Emma I. Bryson, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PIEPER, J.:  John Doe (Father) appeals the family
  courtâ€™s order terminating his parental rights to his biological child (Child)
  and ordering payment of his attorney's fees and $1,635.50 in guardian ad litem
  fees.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
In July 2004, Jane Roe (Mother) learned she
  was pregnant and informed two men that one of them is Childâ€™s father.Â  Eight
  months later, on March 6, 2005, Child was born.Â  Both potential fathers were at
  the hospital for Childâ€™s birth.Â  The man excluded from being Childâ€™s biological
  father assisted Mother in the delivery room and served as Motherâ€™s birth coach.[1]Â  Father was not permitted in the
  delivery room during Childâ€™s birth.Â  While at the hospital the day after Childâ€™s
  birth, Mother indicated she was uncomfortable and wanted Father to leave.Â  As a
  result, she requested that her father (Grandfather) ask Father to leave. 
Less
  than a week after Childâ€™s birth and prior to any determination as to paternity,
  Grandfather called Father to meet with him to discuss the rights and
  responsibilities of parenthood should the paternity test reveal Father to be Childâ€™s
  biological father. Â During this conversation, Grandfather indicated that
  child support and visitation are inextricably linked. Â Grandfather further
  suggested the possibility of termination of parental rights should Father decide
  he did not want to assume parental responsibilities.[2]Â  Additionally, Grandfather directed
  Father to the DSS website and indicated that the site includes a child support
  calculator. 
On March 15, 2005, nine days after Childâ€™s birth, Grandfather
  informed Father a paternity test had excluded the other man as Childâ€™s father.Â 
  The same day, Mother e-mailed photos of Child to Father.Â  The next day, Father
  told his mother about the paternity test results, and the following day she visited
  Child with a gift.Â  
On December 15, 2005, Father filed a complaint
  asking the court to establish his paternity and to award attorney's fees and costs.Â 
  Father additionally sought an award of custody or liberal visitation and to
  issue a restraining order against Mother should his paternity be established.Â  In Motherâ€™s
  answer, she agreed to Fatherâ€™s request for a paternity determination; she also
  counterclaimed, asking the court to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights (TPR)
  and to award attorney's fees and costs.Â  Mother further requested: (1) that the
  court hold in abeyance the issues of child support and visitation, pending the
  courtâ€™s TPR decision; (2) that the court issue a restraining order against
  Father; and (3) that the court award attorney's fees and costs.Â  In a temporary
  order, the court ordered paternity testing and appointed Patricia Forbis as
  Childâ€™s guardian ad litem (GAL).Â  On June
  8, 2006, Mother and Father agreed to bifurcate the issues in order to expedite a
  decision regarding TPR. Â Additionally, they agreed the court would thereafter determine
  GAL and attorney's fees only if Fatherâ€™s parental rights were terminated. Â 
The
  hearing on the TPR issue was held on October 9 and 10, 2006.Â  Child was then
  nineteen months old.Â  At the call of the hearing, the court was advised a
  paternity test had determined Father was Childâ€™s father; neither party
  contested this finding.[3]Â 
  In its written order of December 19, 2006, the court terminated Fatherâ€™s
  parental rights based upon its finding that clear and convincing evidence
  supported TPR on the statutory grounds of failure to visit and failure to support
  Child for six months and finding TPR was in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  The court further
  ordered Mother and Father to pay their own attorney's fees, ordered Mother to
  pay GAL fees of $845.50, and ordered Father to pay GAL fees of $1,635.50.Â 
  Fatherâ€™s petition for supersedeas was denied on June 6, 2007.Â  This appeal
  followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In TPR proceedings,
  the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby
    Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â Â  Before
  parental rights can be permanently terminated, the alleged grounds for
  termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richberg v.
    Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 357, 296 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1982).Â  On appeal, this
  court may review the record and make its own determination whether grounds for
  termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence. S.C. Depâ€™t of
    Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 609, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003).Â Â 
  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we are not required to disregard
  the findings of the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, and was in a
  better position to assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Id.Â  In reviewing TPR cases, we note â€œ[t]he termination of the legal relationship
  between natural parents and a child presents one [of] the most difficult issues
  this [c]ourt is called upon to decide.â€ Charleston County Depâ€™t. of Soc. Serv. v. King, 369 S.C. 96, 105, 631 S.E.2d 239, 244 (2006)
  (alteration in original) (citations omitted).Â Â  As a result, â€œ[w]e exercise great
  caution in reviewing termination proceedings and will conclude termination is
  proper only when the evidence clearly and convincingly mandates such a result.â€Â  Id.Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
In South Carolina, procedures for TPR are governed by statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  20-7-1560 to 1582 (Supp. 2007).Â  The purpose of the TPR statute is:

	to
  establish procedures for the reasonable and compassionate termination of
  parental rights where children are abused, neglected, or abandoned in order to
  protect the health and welfare of these children and make them eligible for
  adoption by persons who will provide a suitable home environment and the love
  and care necessary for a happy, healthful, and productive life.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1560
  (Supp. 2007).Â  
The
  family court may order TPR upon a finding of one or more of the eleven
  statutory grounds and a finding that TPR is in the best interest of the
  child.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2007).Â  The TPR statute
  â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for
  freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by
  terminating the parent-child relationship.Â  The interests of the child shall
  prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2007).Â  
Father first alleges it was improper for the family court to
  determine his paternity and terminate his parental rights in the same order.Â  This
  issue is not preserved for our review.
This
  argument was not raised to the family court and is, therefore, not preserved
  for our review.Â  â€œIt is an axiomatic rule of law that issues may not be raised for the first
  time on appeal.â€Â  Talley v. S.C. Higher Educ. Tuition Grants Comm., 289
  S.C. 483, 487, 347 S.E.2d 99, 101 (1986).Â  Additionally, we note Father and
  Mother signed an order bifurcating the issues to expedite the TPR
  determination.Â  See Harrison v. Bevilacqua, 354 S.C. 129, 139-40,
  580 S.E.2d 109, 114-15 (2003) (stating â€œpetitioner cannot now complain the trial court erred when it took [his] own
  suggestionâ€).
Next, Father asserts the family court erred in finding clear and
  convincing evidence exists to establish the statutory grounds of willful
  failure to visit and willful failure to support.Â  Although we disagree that the
  family court erred with regard to these statutory grounds, we need not address this
  argument in light of our ruling on whether termination is in the best interest of
  the child.Â  
Father argues the family court erred in determining TPR was in
  Childâ€™s best interest.Â  We agree.Â  â€œIf
  the family court finds that a statutory ground for [TPR] has been proven, it
  must then find that the best interests of the child would be served by [TPR].â€Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 580, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App.
  2003).Â  In a TPR case, the best interest of the child is the paramount
  consideration.Â  Id. at 579, 578 S.E.2d at 735.Â  â€œThe interests of the child shall prevail if the
  childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578
  (Supp. 2007).Â  However, â€œ[t]he public policy of this state in child custody
  matters is to reunite parents and children.â€ Â Hooper v. Rockwell, 334
  S.C. 281, 296, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 (1999); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-20.Â  The
  supreme court has recognized a child's shared interest in preventing an
  erroneous termination of the familial bond with a child's natural parent.Â  Greenville County Dep't Soc. Servs. v. Bowes, 313 S.C. 188, 196, 437
  S.E.2d 107, 111 (1993).Â  Furthermore, there is a presumption that it is in the
  best interest of a child to be in the custody of its biological parent.Â  Shake
    v. Darlington County Dep't of Soc. Servs., 306 S.C. 216, 222, 410 S.E.2d
  923, 926 (Ct. App. 1991) (citing Moore v. Moore, 300 S.C. 75, 79, 386
  S.E.2d 456, 458 (1989)). Â 
Terminating
  parental rights can forever sever the relationship between parent and child.Â  As
  a result of the gravity of the effect of termination on a parent-child
  relationship, our courts have routinely held that a decision to terminate
  parental rights should be reached only when the evidence supports a finding that
  termination is in the best interest of the child.Â  In an effort to protect an
  individualâ€™s parental rights to children born out of wedlock, this court, in Charleston County Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, reversed the family courtâ€™s
  order terminating fatherâ€™s parental rights where father was incarcerated
  and unable to connect with child.Â  368 S.C. 87, 103, 627 S.E.2d 765, 774 (Ct.
  App. 2006).Â  In reasoning that TPR was not in childâ€™s best interest, the court
  stated:

	terminating
  Father's parental rights will not ensure future stability for Child.
  Moreover, keeping Father's parental rights intact will not disrupt Child's current living situation. Father does not gain custody of Child simply
  because the Department failed to terminate his parental rights at this time.
  Rather, by not terminating Father's parental rights, Father merely maintains
  his right to connect with Child as well as his obligation to
  support Child, emotionally, financially, or otherwise. The Department should,
  in the best interest of Child, facilitate this connection and
  accompanying obligation.

Id. (emphasis added).Â  Â The Jackson court ruled in
  favor of father despite the inevitable lack of conventional support the
  incarcerated father could provide child while in prison.Â  Id.Â  In
  finding that termination was not in child's best interest, the court noted that
  the child resided in a therapeutic foster home and child's foster parents had
  not expressed an interest in adopting him.Â  Id.Â  Because there was no
  evidence that the foster parents had plans to adopt child, the court found
  terminating father's parental rights would not ensure future stability for
  child and keeping father's rights intact would not disrupt child's current
  living situation. Â Id. 
Here,
  as in Jackson, there is no indication that terminating Father's rights
  will ensure future stability for Child or that keeping Father's parental rights
  intact will disrupt Child's current living situation. Â Instead, keeping
  Fatherâ€™s parental rights intact simply allows Father to establish a
  relationship with Child and to provide emotional and financial support for
  Child. Â While we acknowledge that there is some evidence to suggest that Mother
  had plans to marry and that fiancÃ© may adopt Child, these plans have not been
  finalized.Â  Further, at oral argument, nearly three years after Mother's
  engagement, counsel was unable to confirm such plans.[4] Â Thus, while we recognize that a stable family relationship may be in a child's
  best interest, we find the request herein to be premature based on the record
  presented. If anything, given Mother's situation and Father's demonstrated
  desire to establish a relationship with Child, we find that keeping Father's
  rights intact under these circumstances will only serve to benefit Child by
  allowing the familial bond between Father and Child to be furthered.Â  
Moreover,
  Father is both capable and willing to provide the necessary emotional, financial,
  and other obligations embodied in a parentâ€™s right to care for a biological
  child.Â  Since Father demonstrates his desire to establish a relationship with
  Child and because keeping Fatherâ€™s rights intact need not disrupt the quality
  of Childâ€™s life, the record fails to demonstrate that it would be in Childâ€™s
  best interest to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights at this time.Â  Instead,
  based on the record, we find Father should have the opportunity to connect with
  Child in such manner deemed appropriate under the reasoned view of the family
  court.Â  
Next, Father
  contends the family courtâ€™s decision to terminate his parental rights violates
  his constitutional right to have a relationship with his biological child.Â 
  Because this issue was not raised to the family court, it is not preserved for
  our review.Â  Further, due to our disposition herein, we need not address this
  issue.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311
  S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (finding the court need not address remaining
  issue when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
Father also argues the family court erred
  by ordering him to pay GAL fees of $1,635.50
  and his own attorney's fees.Â 
  We disagree.Â  
Father fails to support his argument with
  authority; therefore, the argument is conclusory and is abandoned on appeal.Â  See Rule 208(b)(1)(D), SCACR.
  Â Notwithstanding, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion and
  affirm the family courtâ€™s order regarding GAL and attorney's fees. 
CONCLUSION
We find that termination of
  Fatherâ€™s parental rights is premature at this juncture and is, therefore, not
  in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  Accordingly, we remand this case to the family court
  to issue an order of visitation and to establish Fatherâ€™s duty of support. Â Additionally,
  we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in ordering Father to pay
  his own attorney's and GAL fees.Â Â  For the foregoing reasons, the order of the
  family court is
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] The man excluded from being Childâ€™s biological father
  is now Motherâ€™s fiancÃ©. Â Mother testified they began an exclusive relationship
  in December 2004 and became engaged in May 2005.Â  Â 
[2] This conversation took place before the paternity
  test revealed Child's biological father.
[3] A
  paternity test conducted in March 2006 confirmed Father was Childâ€™s biological
  father; however, the family court was not notified of this prior to the October
  2006 TPR hearing.Â  
[4] Additionally, we note that one of the primary
  purposes of TPR is to immediately free the child for adoption.Â  S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 20-7-1560 (Supp. 2007).Â  This is especially true in cases where a child is
  faced with abuse and neglect.Â  Following their engagement in May 2005, Mother
  and fiancÃ© planned to be married in October of 2006.Â  This date was cancelled.Â 
  At oral argument, there was no evidence of record that the couple had
  subsequently married or set a new date.Â  Again, we consider this only for
  purposes of whether there exists some beneficial interest to Child to be part
  of some other stable family relationship.

title: State v. Tindall
description: In this criminal appeal arising from a traffic stop, the court addresses the admissibility of drugs and a statement, and whether the trial court erred in failing to give a jury charge on third-party guilt.
text:
<!--

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Terry T.
      Tindall, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Oconee County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4402
Heard March 4, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney
  General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Christina T.
  Adams, of Anderson, for Respondent.
			
		
	

SHORT, J.:  In this criminal action, Terry T. Tindall appeals the trial
  courtâ€™s ruling that a search and seizure did not violate the Fourth Amendment.Â 
  Tindall also appeals the trial courtâ€™s failure to charge the jury on the issue
  of third-party guilt.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On the morning of April 15, 2004, Oconee
  County Sheriffâ€™s Deputy Sergeant Dale Colegrove was patrolling part of Interstate
  85 in Oconee County.Â  Colegrove stopped Tindall about 7 a.m. for speeding and
  following another vehicle too closely.Â  Colegrove wrote Tindall a warning
  ticket but continued to talk to him.Â  Approximately fifteen to twenty minutes
  into the stop, Tindall allegedly consented to a search of the vehicle.Â  Sergeant
  Colegrove and other officers discovered three packages of cocaine under the
  rear bumper of the vehicle, weighing a total of 2,380 grams.
A grand jury indicted Tindall for
  trafficking in cocaine in excess of four hundred grams.Â  At trial,
  Tindall moved to suppress the evidence discovered during the search.Â  Colegrove
  and Tindall testified in camera during the suppression hearing.Â  
Tindall testified that the morning of his arrest, he was traveling
  from his home in Hampton, Georgia to visit his brother in Durham, North Carolina. He testified he and his brother were going to Wilmington, North Carolina â€œto take care of some businessâ€ for their mother.Â  The vehicle Tindall was
  driving at the time of his stop was rented to Lee Braggs.Â  Tindall was named an
  authorized driver, as was another individual, Lewis Wilkerson.Â  Tindall
  testified his car was not reliable enough to make the trip and because he did
  not have a credit card, Braggs had rented the vehicle for him.
After Colegrove pulled Tindall over, he
  informed Tindall he had been speeding, swerving, and following too closely.Â  Tindall
  denied speeding or following too closely.Â  Colegrove requested Tindall
  exit the vehicle and sit in the front seat of his patrol car.Â  As Colegrove
  questioned Tindall, two other police cars arrived.
Colegrove asked Tindall how long he would
  be in North Carolina, and he replied he would only be there for the day.[1]Â  Tindall testified he informed Colegrove
  he intended to leave the rental car in Durham and his brother was going to drive
  him back to Hampton.Â  Tindall explained that once the car was in Durham, Braggs, a restaurateur, needed the car to pick up seafood in North Carolina or Florida.Â  Tindall testified Braggs knew Tindall did not have the means to get to Durham, so Braggs rented the car and let Tindall drive it to Durham. Â Tindall also said
  Braggs â€œneeded to get to Durham quicker than driving there.Â  He needed to get
  to Durham to take care of some business, and he needed the car once he got to Durham.â€
Colegrove returned Tindallâ€™s license and other
  documents, along with a warning ticket. Â Tindall testified he did not
  feel as though he could leave because Colegrove was still talking to him and
  the other officers were standing beside the door of the police car.Â  He further
  testified Colegrove never informed him he could leave.Â  Colegrove then asked
  Tindall if he could search the car and Tindall replied: â€œI donâ€™t care or . . .
  I donâ€™t mind.â€ Â Tindall testified he believed the stop lasted twenty
  minutes but was not surprised to learn the videotape from Colegroveâ€™s car
  revealed it was only twelve minutes. 
Colegrove testified he observed Tindall
  traveling seventy-three miles per hour in a sixty-five-mile-per-hour zone.Â  He
  also observed him following another car too closely and crossing the white
  line.Â  Colegrove decided to stop Tindall and started the videotape equipment in
  Â his vehicle.Â  Colegrove testified when Tindall exited the vehicle he did a
  â€œfelony stretch,â€ raising his hands as â€œkind of a stress relief action,â€ which
  police officers are taught to look for in criminal patrol classes.Â  He further
  testified Tindall continued to act very nervous even after learning he would
  only receive a warning ticket. Â He also testified normally once people
  learn they will not receive a ticket their nervousness subsides, but Tindall
  continued to have a rapid heartbeat.Â  On cross-examination, Colegrove admitted
  he did not document Tindallâ€™s physical manifestations of nervousness in his
  report. 
Additionally, Colegrove testified he found
  the circumstances of Tindallâ€™s trip suspicious because the car had to be
  returned to Atlanta that same day and Tindall was not the renter of record.Â  Also,
  Colegrove testified the cities traveled to and from were considered â€œdrug
  hubs.â€Â  Based on his observations, Colegrove concluded Tindall was concealing
  something illegal inside the car.
Following the suppression hearing, the trial court denied
  Tindallâ€™s motion to suppress finding Colegrove had a reasonable suspicion that
  something illegal was occurring.Â  Tindall also moved to suppress a statement he
  gave to officers at the scene of the arrest.Â  The trial court denied the motion
  to suppress the statement. 
The jury convicted Tindall of trafficking in cocaine.Â  The trial
  court sentenced Tindall to twenty-five years imprisonment and assessed a
  $250,000 fine.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  South Carolina Supreme Court has articulated the standard of review to apply to
  Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases. Â State v. Brockman, 339 S.C.
  57, 528 S.E.2d 661 (2000). Â A trial courtâ€™s factual rulings are reviewed under
  the â€œclear errorâ€ standard, like any other factual finding.Â  Id. at 66,
  528 S.E.2d at 666.Â  The appellate court will affirm if any evidence supports
  the ruling and reverse only if there is clear error.Â  Id. Â Under the â€œclear errorâ€ standard, an
  appellate court will not reverse a trial courtâ€™s finding of fact simply because
  it would have decided the case differently. Â State v. Pichardo, 367
  S.C. 84, 95-96, 623 S.E.2d 840, 846 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Fourth Amendment
  Violation
Tindall contends the trial court erred in denying his
  motion to suppress the cocaine because the traffic stop and subsequent encounter
  violated his Fourth Amendment rights.Â  We disagree. 
The
  Fourth Amendment guarantees a person the right to be secure from unreasonable
  searches and seizures. Â U.S. Const. amend. IV; State v. Butler, 343 S.C. 198, 201, 539 S.E.2d 414, 416 (Ct. App. 2000). Â â€œ[T]he Fourth
  Amendment protects against unreasonable searches and seizures, including
  seizures that involve only a brief detention.â€ Â State v. Pichardo 
  367 S.C. 84, 97, 623 S.E.2d 840, 847 (Ct. App. 2005). Â A temporary
  detention during an automobile stop, even if only for a brief
  period and for a limited purpose, constitutes a seizure within the meaning of
  the Fourth Amendment. Â State v. Maybank, 352 S.C. 310, 315, 573 S.E.2d
  851, 854 (Ct. App. 2002). Thus, an automobile stop is â€œsubject to the constitutional
  imperative that it not be â€˜unreasonableâ€™ under the circumstances.â€ Â Whren v.
    United States, 517 U.S. 806, 810 (1996). Â When probable cause exists to
  believe a traffic violation has occurred, the decision to stop the automobile
  is reasonable per se.Â  State v. Williams, 351 S.C. 591, 598, 571 S.E.2d
  703, 707 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
When
  police lawfully detain a motor vehicle for a traffic violation, they may order
  the driver to exit the vehicle without violating Fourth Amendment proscriptions
  on unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  Id. Â In carrying out the stop, the
  police â€œmay request a driverâ€™s license and vehicle registration, run a computer
  check, and issue a citation.â€ Â United States v. Sullivan, 138 F.3d 126,
  131 (4th Cir. 1998) (quoting Florida v. Royer, 460 U.S. 491 (1983)). Â Once the
  underlying basis for the initial traffic stop has concluded, any further
  detention for questioning is not automatically unconstitutional. Â Pichardo,
  367 S.C. at 98-99, 623 S.E.2d at 847-48.Â  An investigative detention must be
  temporary and last no longer than is necessary to effectuate the purpose of the
  stop and the scope of the detention must be carefully tailored to its
  underlying justification. Â Florida v. Royer, 460 U.S. 491, 500 (1983). Â Once the purpose of that stop has been fulfilled, the continued
  detention of the car and the occupants amounts to a second detention. Â Williams,
  351 at 598-99, 571 S.E.2d at 707-08. Â 
Lengthening
  a detention once an initial stop is completed is permissible in two situations:
  (1) the officer has an objectively reasonable and articulable suspicion illegal
  activity has occurred or is occurring; or (2) the initial detention has become
  a consensual encounter.Â  Â Â Pichardo,
  367 S.C. at 99, 623 S.E.2d at 847-48 (quoting United States v. Hunnicutt,
  135 F.3d 1345, 1349 (10th Cir. 1998)). Â Thus, anÂ  â€œofficerâ€™s continued
  questioning of a vehicleâ€™s driver and passenger outside the scope of a valid
  traffic stop passes muster under the Fourth Amendment either when the officer
  has a reasonable articulable suspicion of other illegal activity or when the
  valid traffic stop has become a consensual encounter.â€Â  Id. Â 
The
  term â€œreasonable suspicionâ€ requires a particularized and objective basis that
  would lead one to suspect another of criminal activity. Â State v. Woodruff,
  344 S.C. 537, 546, 544 S.E.2d 290, 295 (Ct. App. 2001). Â In determining whether
  reasonable suspicion exists, the whole picture must be considered. Â United States v. Sokolow, 490 U.S. 1, 8 (1989). Â The burden is on the State to articulate
  facts sufficient to support reasonable suspicion. Â State v. Butler, 343 S.C. at 202, 539 S.E.2d at 416.
We
  find the traffic stop ended when Colegrove issued the warning and returned
  Tindallâ€™s license. Â Therefore, Tindall was detained after the conclusion of the
  traffic stop.Â  The State argues the detention was consensual.Â  We need not
  determine if the detention was consensual because we find Colegrove had an objectively
  reasonable articulable suspicion illegal activity had occurred or was occurring.Â  
Colegrove
  testified he further detained Tindall because he believed something illegal was
  occurring based on Tindallâ€™s actions after the stop.Â  Colegrove observed
  numerous things after the stop including:Â  1) Tindall was nervous even after
  receiving the warning; 2) Tindall was driving a rental car that he had not
  rented; 3) Tindall was driving only one way and then dropping the car off; 4)
  Tindall planned on driving approximately eighteen hours in one day; and, 5) the
  cities involved were both â€œdrug hubs.â€Â  We find evidence in the record to
  support a determination that Colegrove had a reasonable suspicion something
  illegal was occurring.Â  Therefore, the search and seizure did not violate
  Tindallâ€™s Fourth Amendment rights and the trial court did not err in admitting
  the cocaine.Â  
II.Â  Suppression of Statement 
Tindall argues the
  trial court erred in admitting his statement because it was obtained as a
  result of the alleged violation of the Fourth Amendment.Â  We disagree.Â  Although Tindallâ€™s Brief references Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966), the
  argument solely concerns the legality of the search.Â  Because we find the
  search legal, as previously discussed, the trial court did not err in admitting
  the statement.Â  
III.Â  Third-Party Guilt
Tindall
  maintains the trial court erred in failing to instruct the jury on the issue of
  third-party guilt.Â  We disagree.
The
  trial court is required to charge the law as determined from the evidence
  presented at trial.Â  State v. Gates, 269 S.C. 557, 561, 238 S.E.2d 680, 681 (1977).Â  If any evidence supports a charge, it should be given.Â  State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 262, 513 S.E.2d 104, 108 (1999).Â  A trial courtâ€™s refusal to
  give a requested charge must be both erroneous and prejudicial to warrant
  reversal.Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 261,
  565 S.E.2d 298, 303 (2002).Â  â€œFailure to give requested jury instructions is not prejudicial error where the instructions given afford the
  proper test for determining the issues.â€Â  Id. at 263, 565 S.E.2d at
  304.Â  
In
  the recent decisions of State v. Rice[2] and State v. Swafford[3],
  this Court reiterated that the rule for admitting third-party guilt in South
  Carolina is found in State v. Gregory, 198 S.C. 98, 16 S.E.2d 532
  (1941).Â  The rule states:Â  

	[E]vidence
  offered by [an] accused as to the commission of the crime by another person
  must be limited to such facts as are inconsistent with his own guilt, and to
  such facts as raise a reasonable inference or presumption as to his own
  innocence; evidence which can have (no) other effect than to cast a bare
  suspicion upon another, or to raise a conjectural inference as to the
  commission of the crime by another, is not admissible . . . . [B]efore such
  testimony can be received, there must be such proof of connection with it, such
  a train of facts or circumstances, as tends clearly to point out such other
  person as the guilty party.

Gregory, 198 S.C. at 104-05, 16 S.E.2d at 534-35 (internal
  citations omitted).Â  The Gregory rule â€œand its analogues in other
  jurisdictionsâ€ require the trial court to â€œfocus the trial on the central
  issues by excluding evidence that has only a very weak logical connection to
  the central issues.â€Â  Rice, 375 S.C. at 320, 652 S.E.2d at 418.Â  â€œ[T]he Gregory rule [also] requires the trial judge to consider the probative value or the
  potential adverse effects of admitting proffered third-party guilt evidence.â€Â  Swafford,
  375 S.C. at 641, 654 S.E.2d at 299.Â  
While
  these third-party guilt cases revolve around the admission of evidence of third-party guilt, Tindall appeals the trial
  courtâ€™s failure to charge the jury on third-party guilt.Â  The evidence
  at trial indirectly implicating a third party included Tindallâ€™s testimony that
  he took possession of the rental vehicle when â€œ[i]t was left in the driveway of
  [his] homeâ€ the day before his trip and the fact that he did not rent the
  vehicle.Â  The trial court found it had not â€œheard any testimony in particular
  blaming a third party.â€Â  The evidence that someone other than Tindall placed
  the drugs in the car raised merely a conjectural inference at best and we find
  no error by trial court based on State v. Gregory.Â  

	Furthermore, the trial court charged the jury on mere
  presence, stating:
	
		Now, to prove possession in
  this case, the State must prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant
  had both the power and the intent to control the disposition or use of the
  cocaine.Â  Possession may be either actual or constructive.Â  Actual possession
  means that the cocaine was in the actual physical custody of the defendant.Â  Constructive
  possession means that the defendant had dominion and control or the right to
  exercise dominion or control over any of the cocaine itself or the property in
  which the cocaine was found.
		Mere presence at the scene
  where the drugs were found is not enough to prove possession.Â  Actual knowledge
  of the presence of the cocaine is strong evidence of the defendantâ€™s intent to
  control its disposition or use.Â  The defendantâ€™s knowledge and possession may
  be inferred when a substance is found on the property under the defendantâ€™s
  control.Â  However, the inference is simply an evidentiary fact to be taken into
  consideration by you along with other evidence in the case and to be given the
  weight you decide it should have.
	

We
  find this charge adequately charged
  the law as determined from the evidence presented at trial. See Gates, 269 S.C. at 561, 238 S.E.2d at 681 (finding trial court required to charge the law as determined from the
  evidence presented at trial).Â  Accordingly, because the
  charge given provided the proper law for the jury to consider given the
  evidence presented, the trial court did not err in failing to give the
  requested charge.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons,
  the trial courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON
  and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1]  Tindall testified it took seven hours to get from Hampton to Durham and then over two hours to get from Durham to Wilmington. 
[2]  375 S.C. 302, 652 S.E.2d 409 (Ct. App.
  2007).
[3]  375 S.C. 637, 654 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App.
  2007).

description: Wiesart appeals the trial courtâ€™s ruling that S.C. Code Ann. Â§23-3-430(14) (Supp. 2007) is not retroactive.  We reverse.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Dean Edgar
      Wiesart, Appellant,
				v.
				Robert M.
      Stewart, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4403 
Heard May 8, 2008 â€“ Filed June 5, 2008Â Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Timothy Kirk Truslow, of North Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General David E. Spencer, all of
  Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

GOOLSBY, A.J.:Â  Wiesart appeals the trial courtâ€™s ruling that S.C. Code Ann. Â§23-3-430(14) (Supp. 2007) is not retroactive.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In 1979, a Maryland court convicted Wiesart
  of indecent exposure after he was caught skinny-dipping with his girlfriend in
  a hotel pool.Â  Fifteen years later, Wiesart pled guilty in Horry County to a controlled substance offense.Â  He received probation.Â  Wiesartâ€™s probation
  agent informed him that he was required to register under the sex offender registry
  pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-430 (Supp. 1995) because of the
  prior indecent exposure conviction.
Prior
  to 1996, S.C. Code Â§Â§ 23-3-430 and 23-3-460 required any person
  convicted of indecent exposure to register annually[1] as a sex offender.Â  In 1996, the
  statute was amended to include a person convicted of indecent exposure only â€œif
  the court makes a specific finding on the record based on the circumstances of
  the case the convicted person should register as a sex offender.â€[2]Â  
On January
  9, 2006, upon learning of the amendment, Wiesart brought a declaratory judgment
  action in the trial court.Â  He argued he was entitled to a hearing on the issue
  of whether he was required to register as a sex offender pursuant to Â§ 23-3-430, as amended.Â  The trial court ruled against Wiesart,
  finding the statute was not retroactive.Â  Wiesart appeals. 
LAW / ANALYSIS
Wiesart
  argues the amendment to Â§ 23-3-430 is retroactive because it is
  procedural or remedial in nature.Â  We agree.[3]
Generally, â€œstatutory enactments are to be considered prospective
  rather than retroactive in their operation unless there is a specific provision
  in the enactment or clear legislative intent to the contrary.â€[4]Â  Statutes that are remedial or procedural in nature, however, operate retroactively.[5]Â  A statute is remedial and applies retroactively when it creates new
  remedies for existing rights or enlarges rights of persons under disability.[6] Â 
Here,
  the 1996 amendment to Â§ 23-3-430 is procedural in nature.Â  As set forth above,
  the amendment creates a requirement that the trial court make a specific
  finding on the record regarding whether a person convicted of indecent exposure
  should register as a sex offender.Â  The amendment does not create a new right.Â 
  Instead, it sets forth a procedure for determining whether a person convicted
  of indecent exposure is required to register on the sex offender registry.  [7]Â  
Moreover,
  the registration requirement renews itself on a recurring basis.Â  We take note
  of the fact that the Legislature was aware of this recurring obligation when it
  passed the amendment to the statute regarding the necessary findings for
  registration. 
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  PIEPER, J., concur.


[1]Â  In 2006, S.C. Code Â§23-3-460 (Supp. 2006) was
  amended to require bi-annual registration. 
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-430(14) (Supp. 2006).
[3] We are aware of Hazel v. State, Op. No. 26448
  (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 10, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 9 at 52).Â  Hazel,
  however, does not apply to this case because retrospective application of the
  registration statute was not an issue in Hazel.Â  
[4] South Carolina Dept. of Revenue v. Rosemary
  Coin Machines, Inc., 339 S.C. 25, 28, 528 S.E.2d 416, 418 (2000).
[5] Id.
[6] 4 S.C. Jurisprudence Action Â§ 15 (2007); see Hercules, Inc. v. South Carolina Tax
  Commâ€™n, 274 S.C. 137, 143, 262 S.E.2d
  45, 48 (1980) (statutes affecting the remedy, not the right, are generally
  retrospective). 
[7] Â This court does not pass judgment on the issue of
  whether the circumstances of this case warrant Wiesartâ€™s registration as a sex
  offender.

description: Father argues the family court erred by: (1) finding an enforceable agreement requiring Father to pay Kyleâ€™s college expenses including transportation; (2) denying Father a credit towards the $36,000; (3) finding Kyle had characteristics qualifying him to receive college funds; and (4) awarding attorney fees to Mother and Kyle.

<!--
