THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Patsy Gail
      Nicholson and Kyle Allen Nicholson,  Respondents,
				v.
				F. Allan
      Nicholson, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Rochelle Y. Williamson, Family Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4404
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 6,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Margaret A. Chamberlain, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Brian K. James, of Easley, for the Respondents.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.: Â Patsy
  Gail Nicholson (Mother) and her adult son Kyle Allan Nicholson (Kyle) initiated
  this action against F. Allan Nicholson (Father) seeking Fatherâ€™s payment of
  Kyleâ€™s college expenses pursuant to a separation agreement.Â  Father appeals the
  family courtâ€™s order in favor of Mother and Kyle.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Mother and Father married in March 1978, separated
  in October 1992, and later divorced.Â  They had two children, Kyle being the
  youngest.Â  A separation agreement entitled â€œComplete Property, Support,
  Custody, and Separation Agreementâ€ (the Agreement) was approved by the family
  court and made part of the Order Approving Separation.Â  The Agreement provided:

	3-OTHER
  BENEFITS FOR CHILDREN
	The Husband presently owns ____ shares of stock in Duke Power
  Company, as a result of his employment.Â  The Husband agrees to use the proceeds
  from the sale of the stocks for the minor childrenâ€™s educational needs, first
  and foremost, or to other necessities for the children as a need may arise.Â 
  Notwithstanding his continued employment at Duke Power Company or his
  termination from employment, the Husband agrees to provide for the minor
  children in an amount equivalent to the value of 1,200 shares of the Duke Power
  Stock at its present value of 36,000.

Kyle graduated
  from high school in May 2006 with a grade point average of 3.4 and ranked
  thirty-eighth in a class of one hundred fifteen.Â  He received awards in art
  during his junior and senior years.Â  His career ambitions focused on the design
  field with special interests in automotive design or architecture.Â  In
  September 2006, he enrolled at Tri-County Technical College majoring in
  University Transfer hoping to later attend Clemson University or another school
  offering design programs.Â  
While
  still in high school, Kyle was diagnosed with depression and placed on
  medication.Â  During his first semester at the technical college, he explained
  to the court his depression was worsened by the stress of not knowing where he
  would live or if he would have the money to continue his education.Â  His anxiety
  grew to the point where â€œeveryday was kind of a struggleâ€ and, following a
  suicide attempt and hospitalization, he withdrew from school.Â  Kyle did not
  take his prescribed medication properly, used marijuana prior to his
  hospitalization, and tried cocaine one time.Â  At the time of the hearing, Kyle
  remained in counseling and found it beneficial.Â  He no longer uses illegal
  drugs and his prescribed medicine has been adjusted with positive results.Â 
  Kyle returned to Tri-County Technical College the spring semester following his
  withdrawal.
In his
  financial declaration, Kyle indicated he intended to participate in a
  work-study program expecting to earn $309 per month.Â  His tuition was covered
  by financial aid, federal Pell grants, and a Life Scholarship requiring he
  maintain a 3.0 grade point average and complete a certain number of credits.Â  
Kyle used a car, but it was not in his name. Â Because Mother had
  totaled her vehicle and was moving from the area, she would take the car Kyle
  had been driving.Â  Among the expenses Kyle submitted were auto related costs of
  $250 per month and automobile payments of $300 per month.Â  On a monthly basis,
  Kyle estimated he needed $200 for food and household supplies, $200 for
  utilities, $30 for his medical co-payment, and $100 for computer and internet supplies.Â 
  Overall, his monthly expenses were $1620.Â  Additionally, he listed a $4000 debt
  owed to a family friend for money borrowed by Mother on Kyleâ€™s behalf to pay
  the actionâ€™s attorney fees. 
The
  family court judge found the â€œOther Benefits for Childrenâ€ clause ambiguous. Â The
  testimony of Mother and Father was received on the issue of intent.Â  Father
  testified he earns $72,000 per year as an employee of Duke Energy, where he has
  worked for twenty five years.Â  The Duke Energy stock referenced in the Agreement
  began as a stock benefit account but later changed to a 401(k).Â  At the time of
  the hearing, the stock had split and was worth approximately $60,000.Â  He
  explained the disposition of the stock at the time Mother and Father entered
  the Agreement:

	
		
			Q: 
			[W]as that part of the equitable
  division of marital property with [Mother], your ex-wife?
 
		
		
			A:
			Yeah, that was set aside yes, to help pay for 
			things, educational things, or things that they needed, as they grew 
			up from the time we separated.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Okay.  So in lieu of her taking a percentage 
			of stock, yâ€™all were essentially holding it in trust for your kids; 
			is that right?
 
		
		
			A:
			We set aside that amount to help with the kids.
		
	

Father stated he did not understand â€œeducational needsâ€ as used in
  the Agreement to be college.Â  His understanding of â€œother necessities for
  childrenâ€ included â€œ[c]lothes, things they need in school, food when they donâ€™t
  have money for food, powerâ€¦.â€ Â 
Father presented
  the family court with a list of miscellaneous expenditures made on behalf of
  the children in years past.Â  The list, admittedly prepared for the purpose of
  the hearing, included such items as trips to the beach and amusement parks,
  musical instruments, a Play Station, and a go-cart.Â  Father argued these were
  â€œother necessitiesâ€ and asserted his $36,000 obligation should be set off
  accordingly.Â  He admitted he never communicated to Mother or Kyle that the
  expenses were to be counted towards the shares of stock he owned.Â  
Mother
  was currently seeking disability due to temporal arthritis and collagen
  vascular disease. Â She had been residing with her aging parents in North Carolina, returned to South Carolina to help Kyle after his emotional problems intensified,
  and planned to return to her parentsâ€™ home.Â  She testified the Agreement provided
  for the childrenâ€™s college education.
The family court judge ruled: the Agreement was ambiguous but (1)
  the intent was to include college expenses as indicated by the testimony of
  Mother and Father; (2) â€œother necessitiesâ€ was intended to include living
  expenses incident to college; (3) Father agreed to pay up to $36,000, the
  stockâ€™s value at the time of the Agreement; (4) the older child did not seek
  benefits under the Agreement; and (5) the Agreement contained no requirement
  the children mitigate expenses or work. Â 

	The order mandated:
	Defendant/father shall pay directly to Kyle Nicholson the sum of
  $800.00 per month for the months of January through May 2007 and for the months
  of September through December 2007, yet equating to nine (9) months a year.Â 
  The Defendant/father shall do the same for next year.Â  Kyle Nicholson shall
  provide proof to his father that he is continuously enrolled full time to
  obtain the money.
	[A]fter Kyle Nicholsonâ€™s two (2) years at Tri-County Technical College, there shall be a balance left from the agreement in the amount of $21,600.00
  for his last two (2) years of college, or eighteen (18) months for a sum of
  $1,200 per month.
	Kyle Nicholson shall be required to exhaust all grants and
  scholarships, but shall not be required to incur loans or minimize expenses.
	Kyle Nicholson shall provide a print-out to his father of his
  tuition, room and board, books, and his grants and scholarships.
	$400.00 transportation expenses shall be included in the tuition,
  room and board, and books.Â  The room and board expenses shall not exceed the
  cost to live on campus with room and board and full meal plan.
	[T]he Defendant/fatherâ€™s obligation shall forever end if Kyle
  Nicholson is not continuously enrolled full time, except if he has a medical
  withdrawal unrelated to substance abuse.Â  Kyle Nicholson shall not use illegal
  drugs and the Defendant/father shall have full discovery on that issue.
	[T]he Defendant/father shall pay attorneyâ€™s fees directly to
  Plaintiffâ€™s attorney in the amount of $2000â€¦.
	Kyle Nicholson is not entitled to assistance under Risinger v.
  Risinger, 273 S.C. 36, 253 S.E.2d 652 (1979).

STANDARD OF REVIEW
On
  appeal from the family court, this court has jurisdiction to find facts in
  accordance with its own view of the evidence. Â Ray v. Ray, 374 S.C. 79,
  83, 647 S.E.2d 237, 239 (2007); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Srvcs., County

Griffith at 646-47, 506 S.E.2d at 534-35 (emphasis

  (Ct. App. 2006); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 203, 522 S.E.2d 835,
  839 (Ct. App. 1999).
Through
  this courtâ€™s plenary powers of review, we find the decision to award attorneyâ€™s
  fees is supported by the record.Â  Neither Mother nor Kyle had the ability to
  pay the fee to bring this action without borrowing money from a friend.Â  Their
  counsel obtained beneficial results.Â  Whereas Father has been with his employer
  for many years and was currently earning $72,000 per year, Mother and Kyle were
  unemployed.Â  Mother was seeking disability and Father admitted Kyleâ€™s school attendance
  would inhibit his ability to work.Â  Â Â Given Motherâ€™s and Kyleâ€™s strained
  financial circumstances, the effect of owing the full attorney fees would more
  adversely affect their standard of living than it would Fatherâ€™s as a result of
  his required $2000 contribution.Â  
The attorneyâ€™s
  fee affidavit specifically called the family courtâ€™s attention to the Glasscock factors:

	4.  [Counsel] incorporates herein
  Rule 407 of the South Carolina Appellate Court Rules which contains the Rules
  of Professional Conduct and further calls the attention of the Court to the
  holding of Glasscock v. Glasscock, 403 S.E.2d 313 (S.C. 1991),
  concerning the factors and criteria which should be considered in the setting
  of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  He relies upon the discretion of the Court in the
  determination of the amount of fees, based, among other things, upon the
  Courtâ€™s file, the Courtâ€™s knowledge of the litigation between the parties,
  which reflects the difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily
  expended, the result accomplished, the fact that there is no contingency of
  compensation in a domestic relations case, the professional standing of
  counsel, and fees customarily charged in this area for similar legal services.Â  
	

In the
  case at bar, where the controversy was based on an alleged ambiguity in the Agreement,
  the partiesâ€™ testimony regarding intent was the centerpiece of its resolution.Â 
  The affidavit stated counsel for Mother and Kyle spent 21.10 hours preparing
  the pleadings and affidavits and readying for the hearing.Â  Counsel provided he
  was admitted to the South Carolina Bar ten years earlier and had since been in
  private practice.Â  Concerning his professional standing, he was an active
  member of the state bar and other professional legal associations.Â  Contingency
  of compensation was not applicable in this domestic action.Â  Mother and Kyleâ€™s
  counsel secured beneficial results for his clients.Â  Although no indication of
  customary legal fees for similar services appears, the record sufficiently
  supports the Glasscock factors.Â  Accordingly, $2000 is a reasonable
  award, and we find no abuse of discretion.
CONCLUSION
The Agreement is enforceable and was intended to provide for the
  childrenâ€™s educational needs and other necessities.Â  Under the circumstances of
  this case, transportation is a necessity enabling Kyle to attend classes.Â  We rule
  Father must pay Kyle the sum of $800 per month, including transportation
  expenses of $400, for the months of January through May 2007 and September
  through December 2007, equating to nine months per year.Â  Father shall do the
  same for 2008.Â  After Kyleâ€™s first two years of college, Father shall apply the
  $21,600 balance towards Kyleâ€™s last two years, or eighteen months at a sum of
  $1200 per month. Â Father is not entitled to a credit towards the $36,000 he
  owes.Â  The record provides ample evidence to support the award of attorney fees.Â 
  Accordingly, the order of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Swicegood v. Lott
description: Sheriff Leon Lott, in his official capacity as Sheriff of Richland County, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s failure to grant his motions for directed verdict and judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV), as well as his post-trial motions for a new trial absolute and new trial nisi.  We affirm.
text:
<!--

-->


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Shawn M.
      Swicegood, Respondent,
				v.
				Leon Lott, in
      his official capacity as Sheriff of Richland County, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge 
Opinion No. 4405
Heard April 9, 2008 â€“ Filed June 6, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Andrew F. Lindemann, Robert D. Garfield, William H. Davidson, II,
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
				S. Jahue Moore, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.: Â Sheriff
  Leon Lott, in his official capacity as Sheriff of Richland County, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s failure to grant
  his motions for directed verdict and judgment
  notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV), as well as his post-trial motions for a new
  trial absolute and new trial nisi.  We affirm.
FACTS
The Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department (Department) was conducting an
  investigation on a former deputy, Brian Gailey, based on allegations of
  criminal activity.Â  The Department became convinced then-current deputy Shawn Swicegood
  had information on Gailey because the two were friends and former co-workers.Â  Upon
  arriving at work on February 28, 2003, Swicegood was taken into the office of
  Chief Investigator David Wilson for questioning.Â  Swicegood repeatedly denied having
  any knowledge of Gaileyâ€™s alleged illegal activity. Â 
Wilson did not
  believe Swicegood, asking him if he would submit to a polygraph examination. Â Swicegood
  agreed, and ultimately was administered three polygraph exams, which the
  Sheriffâ€™s Department believed indicated Swicegood had not told the truth.Â  In
  preparation for the polygraph, Swicegood told the examiner he was in possession
  of an unauthorized assault rifle which he had built from scrap metal pieces.Â 
  The Department contacted the Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms, and
  federal weapons charges were initiated against Swicegood, to which he
  ultimately pled guilty and served eighteen months in federal prison.Â  
On the same day,
  and after Swicegoodâ€™s interrogation had begun, Department Captain James Stewart,
  at Wilsonâ€™s direction, began looking into the hours Swicegood had reported on
  his Department timesheet.Â  Specifically, Stewart was directed to compare
  Swicegoodâ€™s reported hours as a deputy, against the hours Swicegood had
  reported participating in the Departmentâ€™s Special Duty Program.Â  The program,
  also known as moonlighting, was encouraged by the Department as an opportunity
  for deputies to find extra work to supplement their incomes. Â Swicegood
  participated in the moonlighting program, including providing security at a
  Cash-O-Matic location.Â  Stewartâ€™s investigation ultimately yielded three
  instances where Swicegoodâ€™s security moonlighting overlapped with hours he had
  submitted to the Department for his deputy duties.[1]Â 
  These instances were for fifteen minutes each, and because Stewart believed
  this represented a pattern, he did not approach Swicegood in order to allow him
  a chance to explain the discrepancies.Â  Instead, Stewart went to a magistrate
  and swore out three warrants for Swicegoodâ€™s arrest for obtaining signature or
  property by false pretenses.Â  
The three warrants were
  then given to Wilson to serve on Swicegood during the still ongoing interrogation.Â 
  Throughout the interrogation, Wilson stated he would make both the state and
  federal charges â€œgo awayâ€ if Swicegood would give the information that the
  Department wanted on Gailey.Â  When Swicegood refused to perjure himself, he was
  arrested, and spent approximately the next eighteen hours in jail.Â  By the time
  Swicegood posted bail, reports of his arrest and charges had been given by the
  Department to The State newspaper, other news agencies, and were posted on the
  internet.Â  
Swicegood brought an action for false arrest,
  malicious prosecution, abuse of process, and negligence against Lott in his
  official capacity. Â On summary judgment motion, the circuit court dismissed
  Stewart as a defendant, and dismissed all causes of action against Lott except
  for the abuse of process claim.Â  A jury trial was held only on the abuse of
  process action which resulted in a $150,000 jury verdict in favor of
  Swicegood.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn ruling on motions for directed verdict and JNOV,
  the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that
  reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party
  opposing the motions and to deny the motions where either the evidence yields
  more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.â€ Â Law v. S.C. Dept. of
    Corrections, 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006). Â An appellate
  court will only Â reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling on a JNOV motion when there
  is no evidence to support the ruling or where
  it is controlled by an error of law.Â  Id. at 434-35, 629 S.E.2d at 648 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Sovereign Immunity
  Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60(17)
Lott contends the
  circuit court erred in denying his motions for a directed verdict and judgment
  notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV) on the grounds that he is entitled to sovereign
  immunity pursuant to an exception of the general waiver of immunity under the
  South Carolina Tort Claims Act.[2]Â 
  Specifically, Lott maintains an action for abuse of process necessarily
  involves alleging elements of actual malice and intent to harm, for which he
  would be entitled to immunity as a matter of law under Section 15-78-60(17) of
  the South Carolina Code (2005).Â  We disagree.
The tort of abuse
  of process consists of two elements:Â  an ulterior purpose, and a willful act in
  the use of the process that is not proper in the regular conduct of the
  proceeding.Â  Hainer v. Am. Med. Int'l, Inc., 328 S.C. 128, 136, 492
  S.E.2d 103, 107 (1997).Â  In explaining the elements of abuse of process, the
  circuit court charged the jury that Swicegood must prove by a greater weight or
  preponderance of the evidence that Lott â€œhad some ulterior purpose or bad
  intent.â€Â  Additionally, in explaining the second element of the tort, the
  circuit court explained â€œit is the malicious misuse or perversion of the
  process for a result thatâ€™s not legitimate for its purpose that constitutes an
  abuse of process.â€ 
Section 15-78-60(17)
  provides:Â  â€œThe governmental entity is not liable for a loss resulting from . .
  . (17) employee conduct outside the scope of his official duties or which constitutes actual fraud, actual malice, intent to
    harm, or a crime involving moral turpitude.â€ (emphasis added).Â  Thus, Lott
  contends, the preceding jury charge necessarily involves a finding of both
  malicious conduct sufficient to rise to the level of actual malice, and intent
  to harm.Â  As stated above, the tort of abuse of process contains neither an
  element of intent to harm, nor actual malice.Â  Although harm may result from
  the â€œbad intentâ€ used by the circuit court to describe an ulterior purpose,
  proving an abuse of process claim does not require a party to intend such
  harm.Â  See Eldeco, Inc. v. Charleston County Sch. Dist., 372 S.C.
  470, 481, 642 S.E.2d 726, 732 (2007) (finding the comparable torts of tortious
  interference with contractual relations, and intentional interference with
  prospective contractual relations do not contain an intent to harm element
  providing immunity under Â§ 15-78-60(17)).Â  
Similarly, there is
  no required element of actual malice.Â  Actual malice in this situation refers
  to common law actual malice, and has been defined by situations where â€œdefendant
  was actuated by ill will in what he did, with the design to causelessly and
  wantonly injure the plaintiff.â€Â  Jones v. Garner, 250 S.C. 479, 488, 158
  S.E.2d 909, 914 (1968); see also Hubbard and Felix, The South
  Carolina Law of Torts, p. 398.Â  The improper purpose element of an abuse of
  process claim usually takes the form of coercion to obtain a collateral
  advantage, not properly involved in the proceeding itself.Â  Therefore, it is
  the use of the process to coerce or extort that is the abuse, and need not be
  accompanied by any ill will.Â  As the tort of abuse of process does not require
  a finding of actual malice or intent to harm, the circuit court did not err in
  denying Lottâ€™s motions for directed verdict and JNOV as to his immunity under Â§
  15-78-60(17).
II. Arrest Warrants
  Carried To Their Authorized Conclusion
Lott
  next contends the circuit court erred in failing to grant his motions for
  directed verdict and JNOV because the process had been carried to its
  authorized conclusion.  We disagree.  
Lott
  maintains that because the arrest warrants obtained by Stewart for the alleged
  double-dipping were carried to their authorized conclusion, i.e., Swicegood was
  taken to trial and the charges were ultimately dismissed, then there should be
  no liability for the tort of abuse of process.  This logic is
  misplaced.  Lott relies upon the isolated statement in Guider v.
    Churpeyes, Inc. that â€œ[r]egardless, there is no liability
  when the process has been carried out to its authorized conclusion, even though
  with bad intentions.â€  370 S.C. 424, 432, 635 S.E.2d 562, 566 (Ct. App.
  2006) (emphasis added).  However, this statement should not be interpreted
  to mean that no liability may ever arise where the process is carried to its
  authorized conclusion.Â    Indeed, the essence of the tort of abuse of
  process centers on events occurring outside of the process, namely:Â  

	The
  improper purpose usually takes the form of coercion to obtain a collateral
  advantage, not properly involved in the proceeding itself, such as the
  surrender of property or the payment of money, by the use of the process as a
  threat or club. There is, in other words, a form of extortion, and it is what
  is done in the course of negotiation, rather than the issuance or any formal
  use of the process itself, which constitutes the tort.

Huggins v. Winn-Dixie
  Greenville, Inc., 249 S.C. 206, 209,
  153 S.E.2d 693, 694 (1967) (citation omitted).  The existence of probable
  cause for the double-dipping arrest warrants is not in dispute. 
  Nonetheless, there is clearly evidence in the record the Department initiated
  the investigation into Swicegoodâ€™s moonlighting with the intent of coercing him
  into implicating Gailey. Â The â€œwillful actâ€ element of the abuse of process
  tort has been interpreted by this court to consist of three different
  components:Â  1) an act that is either willful or overt; 2) in the use of the
  process; 3) that is ultimately reprehensible because it is either (a) unauthorized
  or (b) aimed at an illegitimate collateral objective.Â  Food Lion, Inc. v.
    United Food & Commercial Workers Intern. Union, 351 S.C.65, 71, 567
  S.E.2d 251, 254 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The evidence before us is sufficient to
  create a jury question as to both the ulterior purpose element and all three
  aspects comprising the willful act element.  
Our decision that a jury issue was created on the peculiar facts of this case
  should not be interpreted to chill law enforcement activity in its legitimate
  procurement of cooperation to further investigations.  The eliciting of
  cooperation from an accused in one case in exchange for leniency with existing
  charges, where the accused genuinely has information that would benefit law
  enforcement, does not, and never has fallen within the tort of abuse of
  process.  Here, however, taking the facts in the light most favorable to Swicegood, as we must for the purposes of evaluating this issue at the directed
  verdict and JNOV stage, the evidence is susceptible to the inference that the
  primary purpose of the investigation and issuance of warrants was to coerce or
  extort Swicegoodâ€™s testimony against Gailey, even though he had previously
  indicated he had no knowledge that would further the Departmentâ€™s
  investigation.Â  Thus the facts of this case are distinguished from normal
  police investigative procedure.Â  As a result, the circuit court did not err in
  denying Lottâ€™s motions on this issue.
III. Causal Connection
  Between the Abuse of Process and Damages 
Lott
  next contends the circuit court erred in denying his motions for directed
  verdict and JNOV because Swicegood failed to prove the causal connection
  between the alleged misuse of the process and his claimed damages.Â  He
  maintains that under abuse of process, recoverable damages are only those
  resulting from the misuse of the process, but not those losses resulting from
  the proper use of the process.Â  
The
  South Carolina Supreme Court has addressed the issue of damages in an abuse of
  process action in the second Huggins case to come before the court after
  remand and appeal.Â  It provides an appropriate explanation of the damages
  recoverable from an abuse of process claim.Â  Huggins v. Winn-Dixie
    Greenville, Inc., 252 S.C. 353, 166 S.E.2d 297 (1969).Â  The court concluded
  â€œ[d]amages recoverable for abuse of process are compensatory for the natural
  results of the wrong, and may include recompense for physical or mental injury;
  expenses; loss of time; and injury to business, property or financial standing.â€Â  Id. at 362, 166 S.E.2d at 301 (citation omitted).Â  In finding that
  once abuse of process is proven, damages are recoverable, the court went on to explain
  that â€œthere may be recovery without proof for harm to the plaintiffâ€™s
  reputation, standing and credit,â€ as well â€œas to humiliation and other mental
  suffering or injury to [a personâ€™s] feelings.â€Â  Id. at 363, 166 S.E.2d
  at 301 (citation omitted). Moreover, if some damage to the reputation could be
  considered a natural and probable consequence of the abuse of process, then
  submission to the jury is proper, even if there was no proof as to the damage.Â  Id.Â  Swicegood testified as to the frustration, embarrassment, and
  humiliation he experienced having to face his family, friends and members of
  his church, after his arrest had been leaked to the press.Â  We find this to be
  sufficient evidence to support the submission of damages to the jury. 
IV. New Trial; New Trial Nisi Remittitur
Lott next contends
  the circuit court erred in failing to grant his post-trial motion for a new trial
  absolute.Â  We disagree.
A circuit court may
  grant a new trial absolute on the ground that the verdict is excessive or
  inadequate.Â  Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 379, 426 S.E.2d 802, 805
  (1993).Â  The circuit court should grant a new trial absolute on the
  excessiveness of the verdict only if the amount is so grossly inadequate or
  excessive as to shock the conscience of the court and clearly indicates the
  figure reached was the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, partiality,
  corruption or some other improper motives.Â  Id. at 379-80, 426 S.E.2d at
  805.Â  
The grant or denial
  of new trial motions rests within the discretion of the circuit court, and its
  decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless its findings are wholly
  unsupported by the evidence, or the conclusions reached are controlled by error
  of law.Â  Umhoefer v. Bollinger, 298 S.C. 221, 224, 379 S.E.2d 296, 297
  (Ct. App. 1989).Â  â€œIn deciding whether to assess error to a courtâ€™s denial of a
  motion for a new trial, we must consider the testimony and reasonable
  inferences to be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving
  party.â€Â  Id.
Lott first
  maintains the circuit court erred in denying his motion for a new trial
  absolute because the juryâ€™s charge, which defined ulterior purpose as â€œbad
  intent,â€ was incorrect and confusing to the jury.Â  Lott failed to lodge an
  objection at the close of the jury charge.Â  Only after the jury requested to be
  re-charged on the law of abuse of process and ulterior motive did counsel take
  exception to the charge.Â  See Lundy v. Lititz Mut. Ins. Co., 232
  S.C. 1, 10, 100 S.E.2d 544, 548 (1957) (finding an objection was waived as
  untimely, where counsel did not object at the conclusion of the main charge,
  but later objected to additional instructions that were substantially the same
  as the main charge).Â  
Lott next contends
  the circuit court erred because of the excessiveness of the verdict.Â  We
  disagree.Â  Swicegood lost his job, and testified as to the humiliation he felt
  amongst his family, friends and church members as a result of this process,
  and, as noted above, this is evidence of compensable damages for an abuse of
  process claim.Â  The circuit court did not abuse its discretion in finding the
  award of $150,000 was neither so excessive as to shock the conscience, nor the
  result of passion, caprice, prejudice, partiality, corruption or some other
  improper motives.Â  
Finally, Lott
  contends the circuit court erred in failing to grant his motion for a new trial nisi remittitur.Â  Although Lott claims to have made a nisi motion, and that it was denied by the circuit court, a review of the record
  before us finds no motion for a new trial nisi.Â  As a result, this issue
  is unpreserved for our review.Â  See Peterson v. Richland County,
  335 S.C. 135, 515 S.E.2d 553 (Ct. App. 1999) (although brief indicated that a
  motion to reconsider was filed and denied, neither the motion nor the order
  were in the record on appeal).

  We hold the circuit court did not err in failing to grant Lottâ€™s motions for
  directed verdict and JNOV, or his
  post-trial motions for a new trial absolute and new trial nisi.Â  Accordingly,
  the decision of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED
PIEPER, J., and GOOLSBY,
  A.J., concur.



[1] Based on Swicegoodâ€™s annual wage at the time, each
  alleged instance amounted to $3.75 of â€œdouble-dipping.â€Â  Additionally,
  testimony indicates it was common practice to fill out timesheets with expected
  hours at the beginning of each month, before actually working the hours.Â  
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-10 (2005).

title: State v. Lyles
description: In this murder case, the Appellant avers the exclusion of proffered testimony constituted an abuse of discretion that deprived Appellant of his due process right to present witnesses in his own defense. The State replies: When the defendants testified that they went to the apartment to â€œget some weedâ€ on December 8, 2004 when the admitted shooting occurred, there was no abuse of discretion in excluding proposed defense evidence unknown to each defendant at the time of the shooting: (1) that a person attempted to solicit selling drugs to a neighbor of the apartment in October 2004 as unduly prejudicial under Rule 403; and (2) evidence that the victim, Tavaris Howze, who was seated on the couch watching a movie and shot in the left side of his head, had a single partially smoked hand rolled cigarette which was reported to contain marijuana, was not relevant.  Alternately, any error in the admission of this evidence with de minimis probative value was harmless error in light of their testimony and the evidence of guilt where the exclusion did not require a new trial under Rule 103.

<!--

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of
  Appeals

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina, Respondent,
				v.
				Lance Lyles, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Spartanburg   County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit
  Court Judge
Opinion No. 4406
Heard June 3,
  2008 â€“ Filed June 6, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Tara Dawn
  Shurling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia; and
  Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for
    Respondent.
			
		
	


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Â Â Lance Lyles (Lyles)
  appeals his convictions for murder, attempted first degree burglary, attempted
  armed robbery, and possession of a pistol by a person under the age of
  twenty-one.Â  Lyles contends that the circuit court erred by excluding the
  proffered testimony of two defense witnesses because the exclusion constituted
  an abuse of discretion by denying Lyles his due process right to present witnesses
  in his own defense.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
On
  December 8, 2004, two men approached the apartment of Clarence Spicer (Spicer)
  in Spartanburg, South Carolina.Â  At the time, Spicer, known as â€œSeeâ€ or â€œC.â€,
  and the victim, Tavaris Howze (Howze), were the only people inside the
  apartment.Â  Spicer recounted the events:Â  

	[T]wo guys came up to my door, one of
  them with a mask and a gun and the other with a hood covering his face.
	I opened the door and saw that.Â  One of
  the guys tried to step in.Â  I stopped him on his way in.Â  The other guy came
  from the side with a gun and a mask on, and I started trying to close the
  door.Â  And while I was closing the door one of them shot inside of my house,
  and thatâ€™s when [Howze] was shot.

Spicer
  called 911 and waited for the authorities.Â  Upon their arrival, police officers
  discovered Howzeâ€™s body in the apartment with a gunshot wound to the head.Â  Howze
  died from his injuries.Â  
At the time of the shooting, Spicer did
  not recognize either of the men.Â  However, he later recalled the identity of
  the individual in the hood as Lance Lyles because Lyles had visited Spicerâ€™s
  apartment several weeks beforehand.Â  Spicer relayed Lylesâ€™ identity to the
  police and an arrest warrant was issued.Â  Police officers then approached Lyles
  and a chase ensued.Â  He was subsequently apprehended and arrested.Â  Spicer was
  able to identify Lyles as one of the assailants from a photographic lineup and
  again at trial.Â  Following the arrest, police searched Lylesâ€™ residence and discovered
  multiple rounds of ammunition in various sizes, several shell casings, and a
  jacket containing a ski mask.Â  
Several
  days after Lylesâ€™ arrest, Joshua Jeter (Jeter) was arrested as Lylesâ€™
  accomplice to the crimes.Â  Jeter indicated he and Lyles had been outside of
  Spicerâ€™s apartment on the night of the incident and Jeter was wearing a ski
  mask.Â  However, Jeter did not admit he was carrying a firearm at the scene
  until making another statement almost a year after his arrest.Â  In the latter
  statement, Jeter conceded he carried a pistol to the apartment but claimed it
  was a different caliber than the weapon that killed Howze.
Both
  Lyles and Jeter were indicted for several offenses including murder, burglary
  in the first degree, armed robbery, and unlawful possession of a pistol by a
  person under the age of twenty-one.Â  At trial, both individuals testified in
  their own defense.Â  Lyles and Jeter gave conflicting accounts of the incident
  with each inculpating the other as the shooter.Â  However, each corroborated
  they had originally gone to the apartment to purchase drugs from Spicer and had
  no intention of robbing him.
Both
  men were convicted of murder, attempted burglary in the first degree, attempted
  armed robbery, and unlawful possession of a pistol by a person under the age of
  twenty-one.Â  Lyles was sentenced to life for murder and other consecutive
  sentences for the lesser offenses.Â Â Â  
ISSUE
Did trial judge
  err in excluding testimony as unfairly prejudicial and irrelevant when the
  proffered statements went to establishing (1) drugs were previously sold from
  the apartment where the incident occurred and (2) drugs were present in the
  apartment at the time of the incident?
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State
    v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 472, 613 S.E.2d 381, 384 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State
      v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State v. Wood,
  362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004)); State v. Landis,
  362 S.C. 97, 101, 606 S.E.2d 503, 505 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Abdullah,
  357 S.C. 344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œThis court is bound
  by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.â€Â  Preslar,
  364 S.C. at 472, 613 S.E.2d at 384; accord State v. Bacchus, 367
  S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2005) (citing State v. Quattlebaum,
  338 S.C. 441, 442, 527 S.E.2d 105, 111 (2000)).Â  The appellate court does not
  re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the evidence but simply
  determines whether the trial judge's ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  State

The
  question of â€œ[w]hether an error is harmless depends on the circumstances of the
  particular case.â€Â  Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151; accord State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 193, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990); Douglas, 367 S.C. at 519-520, 626 S.E.2d at 70; State v. Thompson, 352 S.C.
  552, 562, 575 S.E.2d 77, 83 (Ct. App. 2003).Â Â  â€œ â€˜No definite rule of law
  governs this finding; rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the
  error must be determined from it relationship to the entire case.â€™ â€Â  Thompson,
  352 S.C. at 562, 575 S.E.2d at 83 (quoting Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573,
  336 S.E.2d at 151).Â  â€œError is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt where it did
  not contribute to the verdict obtained.â€Â  Pagan, 369 S.C. at 212, 631
  S.E.2d at 267 (citing Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 172, 420 S.E.2d
  834, 842 (1992)).Â  â€œWhere a review of the entire record establishes the error
  is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, the conviction should not be reversed.â€Â  Thompson, 352 S.C. at 562, 575 S.E.2d at 83 (citing State v. Pickens,
  320 S.C. 528, 530-531, 466 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1996); State v. King, 349
  S.C. 142, 161, 561 S.E.2d 640, 650 (Ct. App. 2002)); see Mizzel, 349
  S.C. at 334, 563 S.E.2d at 319 (â€œIn determining whether an error is harmless,
  â€˜the reviewing court must review the entire record to determine what effect the
  error had on the verdict.â€™ â€) (quoting State v. Clark, 315 S.C.
  478, 484, 445 S.E.2d 633, 636 (1994) (Toal, J. dissenting)).Â  
â€œ â€˜Harmless beyond a reasonable doubtâ€™
  means the reviewing court can conclude the error did not contribute to the verdict
  beyond a reasonable doubt.â€Â  Mizzel, 349 S.C. at 334, 563 S.E.2d at 319
  (quoting Arnold, 309 S.C. at 172, 420 S.E.2d at 842).Â  â€œ[I]n
  order to conclude that the error did not contribute to the verdict, the Court
  must â€˜find that error unimportant in relation to everything else the jury
  considered on the issue in question, as revealed in the record.â€™ â€Â  Lowry v.
    State, 376 S.C. 499, 508, 657 S.E.2d 760, 765 (2008) (quoting Yates v.
      Evatt, 500 U.S. 391, 403 (1991)). Â â€œWhen guilt is conclusively proven by
  competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached, [the
  appellate court] will not set aside a conviction because of insubstantial
  errors not affecting the result.â€ Â State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 179,
  460 S.E.2d 368, 371 (1995); accord; State v. Bryant, 369 S.C.
  511, 518, 633 S.E.2d 152, 156 (2006); State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5,
  377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) (citing State v. Livingston, 282 S.C.
  1, 6, 317 S.E.2d 129, 132 (1984)).
After
  reviewing the record, we conclude any error in the exclusion of the proffered
  testimony would have no impact on the outcome of the case.Â  All the elements of
  the crimes charged were proven beyond a reasonable doubt and no other rational
  conclusion could be reached.Â  The excluded evidence, if admitted, would have
  had no impact on the verdict reached by the jury.Â  Therefore, any error
  committed was harmless.Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold the testimony proffered by the
  defense regarding potential drugs sales at the apartment and the presence of
  drugs at the crime scene was irrelevant.Â  Additionally, even if the testimony were
  relevant, it should be excluded under Rule 403, SCRE, as unfairly prejudicial
  because of its tendency to confuse the issues and mislead the jury.Â  Because
  this testimony is inadmissible under the rules of evidence, Lyles was not
  denied an opportunity to present a complete defense by its exclusion.Â  Furthermore,
  any error regarding the exclusion of the testimony was harmless. Accordingly, Lylesâ€™ convictions are 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and KITTREDGE,
  JJ., concur.

title: Quail Hill v. County of Richland
description: Quail Hill, LLC (Buyer) brought this action against Richland County as the result of its purchase of a 72.5 acre tract in reliance upon representations by County officers and staff regarding its zoning.  The circuit court granted summary judgment to County on Buyerâ€™s claims for equitable estoppel, negligence, negligent misrepresentation, and inverse condemnation.  We believe genuine issues of material fact exist as to some of Buyerâ€™s claims and therefore affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Quail Hill,
      LLC, Appellant,
				v.
				County of Richland,
				South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4407
Heard April 9, 2008 â€“ Filed June 6, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED
  IN PART, and REMANDED


	
		
			
				Clifford O. Koon, Jr., and Paul D. de Holczer, 
				of Columbia, for Appellant.
				William H. Davidson, II, and Michael Wren, 
				of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

Hearn, C.J.:Â 
  Quail Hill, LLC (Buyer) brought this action against Richland County as the
  result of its purchase of a 72.5 acre tract in reliance upon representations by
  County officers and staff regarding its zoning.Â  The circuit court granted
  summary judgment to County on Buyerâ€™s claims for equitable estoppel,
  negligence, negligent misrepresentation, and inverse condemnation.Â  We believe
  genuine issues of material fact exist as to some of Buyerâ€™s claims and
  therefore affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTS
In 2002,
  Buyer contacted a licensed real estate broker and authorized him to act as its
  agent in locating and purchasing a parcel suitable for development of a
  manufactured-home subdivision.Â  Broker identified a 72.5-acre parcel as a
  potential site for Buyerâ€™s development. 
At this
  time, the Richland County Planning Department, Development Servicesâ€™ website
  advised the public:Â  â€œSince 1997 the department has performed the planning,
  zoning and land use management staff functions of county government. . . . The
  Development Services Counter is the key point of public contact for the
  planning and zoning functions of the County.Â  It is the primary information
    resource of property owners and land use professionals who often need to know
    â€˜What can and can not be done with a piece of property.â€™â€ (emphasis
  supplied).Â  
Accordingly, in January 2003, Broker met with the Richland County
  Planning Department staff (Staff) to obtain the zoning classification and
  permitted uses for the parcel. Â Countyâ€™s subdivision coordinator, Carl Gosline,
  told Broker the parcel was zoned RU (rural), a classification that permits a
  manufactured-home subdivision. Â Additionally, County tax records listed the
  parcelâ€™s zoning as RU. 
On
  March 13, 2003, Buyer purchased the parcel and then surveyed, platted, and
  prepared it for development.Â  In September, Buyer filed an application with the
  County Planning Commission for site plan approval for his proposed subdivision.
  Â Buyerâ€™s site plan requested subdividing the parcel into twenty lots for
  manufactured homes.Â  The Staff Report to the Planning Commission recommended
  approval of Buyerâ€™s subdivision plan and included the following findings: (1) the
  parcel was zoned RU, (2) the proposed projectâ€™s impact on traffic was well within
  design capacity for the access road, (3) the proposed project was compatible
  with adjacent development, and (4) the project implemented objectives of the
  North Central Subarea Plan, including varied and low-density development
  initiatives.Â  On October 6, 2003, the Planning Commission voted unanimously to
  approve Buyerâ€™s subdivision application and site plan. Â Thereafter, Buyer began
  marketing and selling lots for Brockington Acres.Â  
Over a year later, after the first manufactured homes were already
  installed, community members contacted their county council representative and
  asked him to attend a neighborhood meeting at a church adjoining Brockington
  Acres.Â  Countyâ€™s current zoning
  administrator, Geonard Price, accompanied
  the council member to the meeting, where neighbors inquired about zoning
  restrictions and expressed opposition to the development of Brockington Acres.Â 
  Shortly thereafter, on November 14, 2004, Staff notified Buyer that Price had interpreted the official
  zoning map and found the parcel was zoned RS-1, a classification that prohibits
  manufactured homes.[1]Â 
  Three days later, Price issued an order requiring Buyer to cease development of
  the subdivision.Â  
On November 17, 2004, County issued its
  order stopping further development; however, since receiving final site plan
  approval from the Planning Commission in October 2003, Buyer had already sold
  five of the subdivisionâ€™s twenty lots.Â  Two purchasers had obtained County permits
  authorizing them to install manufactured homes and, in fact, two homes were already
  installed on the lots. Â Another purchaser had permits to install manufactured homes
  on three lots, but had not yet installed them when the County issued its order
  to cease development. Â 
When Buyer contacted Staff about Countyâ€™s order to cease
  development at Brockington Acres,Â  Staff told him to apply to county council
  for a zoning map amendment and assured him it would recommend approval of his
  request.Â  However, just two weeks later, the Staff Report recommended the
  Planning Commission deny Buyerâ€™s application for a zoning map amendment.
  Â At a meeting on December 2, 2004, the Planning Commission accepted the Staff
  Report and recommended county council deny Buyerâ€™s request for a zoning map amendment.
  Â Thereafter, county council voted unanimously to deny Buyerâ€™s application to
  amend the zoning map. 
Buyer filed a complaint in circuit court requesting
  an injunction and alleging causes of action against County for equitable
  estoppel, negligence, negligent misrepresentation, and inverse condemnation.Â  Buyer
  sought an order requiring County to change zoning of his parcel from
  RS-1 to RU. Â Alternatively, Buyer sought damages and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  County
  moved for summary judgment, which the circuit court granted.Â  This appeal
  followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing
  the grant of a summary judgment, this court applies the same standard that
  governed the trial court; summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine
  issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a
  matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860
  (2002); see also Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  â€œOn appeal from an order
  granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities,
  conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most
  favorable to the appellant, the non-moving party below.â€Â  Willis v. Wu,
  362 S.C. 146, 151, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS

I. Validity of Zoning
  Ordinances
Initially Buyer
  contends there is a material issue of fact as to whether County validly enacted
  its 1978 zoning ordinances.Â  We agree with the circuit court that Buyer is
  statutorily barred from challenging the validity of the zoning ordinance at
  this juncture.Â  
It
  took County thirteen months to provide the minutes from the county council
  meetings in 1978 wherein the zoning on the subject property was purportedly
  granted.Â  While Buyer asserts certain irregularities in connection with the
  approval of the zoning ordinances, the circuit court correctly held that Buyer
  may not now be heard to challenge the validity of the enactment of the
  ordinances.Â  Section 6-29-760(D) of the South Carolina Code (2004) provides: 

	No challenge to the adequacy of notice or challenge to the
  validity of a regulation or map, or amendment to it, whether enacted before or
  after the effective date of this section, may be made sixty days after the
  decision of the governing body if there has been substantial compliance with
  the notice requirement of this section or with established procedures of the
  governing authority or the planning commission. 

Accordingly,
  we find Buyerâ€™s argument is without merit.
II. Inverse Condemnation
Buyer next alleges
  the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of County on his
  claim for inverse condemnation.Â  We disagree. Â 
An inverse condemnation may result from the
  governmentâ€™s physical appropriation of private property, or it may result from
  government-imposed limitations on the use of private property.Â  Byrd v. City
    of Hartsville, 365 S.C. 650, 656, 620 S.E.2d 76, 79 (2005).Â  To prevail in
  an action for inverse condemnation, â€œa plaintiff must prove an affirmative,
  aggressive, and positive act by the government entity that caused the alleged
  damage to the plaintiff's property.â€ Â WRB Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. County of Lexington, 369 S.C. 30, 32, 630 S.E.2d 479, 481 (2006).
The circuit court
  found there was â€œno evidence that the zoning designation [of Buyerâ€™s parcel]
  was changed, and at most, any representation of the zoning designation of the
  property by Mr. Gosline or contained in the Tax Assessorâ€™s records was a
  mistake.â€Â  This finding is in line with Buyerâ€™s own complaint, which stated
  â€œthe staff represented to [Buyer] that it had erroneously advised [Buyer] that
  the subject property was zoned â€œRUâ€ and that records in the development staff
  offices and Tax Assessorâ€™s office differed from the official zoning map.â€Â  
On
  appeal, Buyer puts forth two alternative arguments in support of its assertion
  that the circuit court erred in granting Countyâ€™s motion for summary judgment
  on the inverse condemnation claim.Â  First, Buyer contends there has never been
  a valid, enforceable zoning map and that therefore, it was denied the ability
  to develop the property as it desired without being subject to zoning
  restrictions.Â  As discussed above, because Section 6-29-760(D) bars Buyerâ€™s
  challenge, this contention is without merit. Next, Buyer contends
  that Countyâ€™s action in informing it the zoning of the property was RU
  constituted a sufficient showing of an affirmative, aggressive, and positive
  act to establish inverse condemnation.Â  
However, the only
  evidence in the record indicates that Countyâ€™s informing Buyer of the zoning
  designation for the property was merely a mistake, caused primarily by incorrect
  record keeping in the tax assessorâ€™s office.Â  We have found no reported case,
  and Buyer has cited none, which holds that a mistake may rise to the level of
  an affirmative, aggressive, and positive act sufficient to constitute inverse
  condemnation. Â Accordingly, the courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to County on
  this cause of action is affirmed.
Â III. Negligence and
  Negligent Misrepresentation
Buyer also contends the circuit court erred in
  granting summary judgment in favor of County on its claims of negligence and
  negligent misrepresentation.Â  We agree. 
The circuit
  court judge, relying on the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, held that Buyerâ€™s
  tort claims against County were barred by sovereign immunity.Â  Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  15-78-40 (2005) states:Â  â€œThe State, an agency, a political subdivision, and a
  governmental entity are liable for their torts in the same manner and to the
  same extent as a private individual under like circumstances, subject to the
  limitations upon liability and damages, and exemptions from liability and
  damages, contained herein.â€Â  Moreover, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-50(b) (2005)
  provides:Â  â€œIn no case is a governmental entity liable for a tort of an
  employee where that employee, if a private person, would not be liable under
  the laws of this State.â€Â  Thus, the circuit court reasoned, County is liable
  for the negligent administration and enforcement of its zoning ordinances only
  if a private person could also be held liable for breach of that same duty
  under South Carolina law.Â  
We recognize
  that there is Federal authority which supports the circuit courtâ€™s resolution
  of this issue.Â  See United States v. Olson, 546 U.S. 43 (2005) (holding
  that under a similar provision of the Federal Tort Claims Act, the United
  States only waives sovereign immunity under circumstances where local law would
  make a private person liable in tort). Â Moreover, the circuit court also relied
  upon a recent decision from this court in granting summary judgment to County
  on these causes of action; however, the case relied upon was recently reversed
  by our supreme court.Â  See Sloan Constr. Co., Inc. v. Southco
    Grassing, Inc., 368 S.C. 523, 629 S.E.2d 372 (Ct. App. 2006), revâ€™d ___ S.C. ___, 659 S.E.2d 158 (2008) (holding that because a private person
  would never be liable for the failure to require bonds mandated under the
  â€œLittle Miller Act,â€ this court found Sloan had no right to sue under the South
  Carolina Tort Claims Actâ€™s limited waiver of sovereign immunity).Â  Thus, no South Carolina precedent exists to support the circuit courtâ€™s determination that it is
  necessary to have a private analogue in order for liability to exist against a
  governmental entity under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  Therefore, at
  this premature stage of the litigation, we decline to hold that Buyer may not
  pursue its claims for negligence and negligent misrepresentation based on these
  provisions of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.
The
  circuit court also based its decision to grant summary judgment on S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 15-78-60(4) (2005), which states a governmental entity is not liable for a
  loss resulting from:Â  â€œadoption, enforcement, or compliance with any law or
  failure to adopt or enforce any law, whether valid or invalid, including, but
  not limited to, any charter, provision, ordinance, resolution, rule,
  regulation, or written policies . . . .â€Â  We view Buyerâ€™s claims for negligence
  and negligent misrepresentation as arising from Countyâ€™s actions in mistakenly
  advising Buyer on the applicable zoning restrictions on the 72.5 acre parcel,
  not as emanating from the adoption or enforcement of Countyâ€™s zoning
  ordinances; therefore, we disagree with the circuit court that this provision
  of the tort claims act bars Buyerâ€™s claims.Â Â  Accordingly, we reverse the
  circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on Buyerâ€™s causes of action for
  negligence and negligent misrepresentation.Â  
IV. Equitable Estoppel
Finally, Buyer
  contends the circuit court
  erred in granting summary judgment to County on its claim for equitable estoppel.Â  Specifically,
  Buyer argues further inquiry is needed to determine whether County should be estopped from enforcing the RS-1
  zoning determination almost two years after County determined the same parcel
  was zoned RU and a year after it approved Buyerâ€™s site plan.Â  We agree.Â  
â€œ[E]stoppel is an equitable doctrine,
  essentially flexible, and therefore to be applied or denied as equities between
  the parties may preponderate.â€ Â Pitts v. N.Y. Life Ins.
    Co., 247 S.C. 545, 552, 148 S.E.2d 369, 372 (1966).Â  To prevail on a
  claim of equitable estoppel, a party must show: â€œ(1) a lack of knowledge[,] and
  the means of knowledge[,] of truth as to facts in question; (2) justifiable
  reliance upon the conduct of the party estopped; and (3) prejudicial change in
  the position of the party claiming estoppel.â€ Â Evins v. Richland County Historic Pres. Commâ€™n, 341 S.C. 15, 20, 532 S.E.2d 876, 878 (2000).[2] Â 
â€œThe acts of a
  government agent that are within the proper scope of his authority may give
  rise to estoppel against a municipality.â€ Â Charleston County v. Natâ€™l Adver. Co., 292 S.C. 416, 418, 357 S.E.2d
  9, 10 (1987); see also Landing Dev. Corp. v. City of Myrtle Beach,
  285 S.C. 216, 221, 329 S.E.2d 423, 426 (1985) (â€œTo allow the city to repudiate
  its former interpretation of permissible rentals and the statements of its
  zoning director, based upon a re-assessment of the meaning of an undefined term
  in the ordinance[,] would be unconscionable.â€).

1.  Lack of
  Knowledge
In granting summary
  judgment to County on Buyerâ€™s claim of equitable estoppel, the circuit court
  found the zoning administratorâ€™s interpretation of the official zoning map was
  conclusive because: â€œRichland County Zoning Ordinances provide that the
  official zoning map of Richland County constitutes the only official description
  of the location of zoning district boundaries, and that the zoning
  administrator is the only representative on behalf of Richland County that can
  interpret the official zoning map.â€Â  However, this finding ignores the clear
  import of the Countyâ€™s website which directs the public to the Development
  Services Counter as â€œthe primary information resource of property owners and
  land use professionals who often need to know â€˜What can and can not be done
  with a piece of property.â€™â€ Moreover, the Frequently Asked Questions portion of
  the website advises the public to check the zoning of a parcel prior to its
  development by consulting with the Department of Development Services, and
  suggests that it is advisable â€œto meet with the Planning Staff to discuss your upcoming
  project.â€Â  Nowhere on the website is it stated that the official zoning map
  must be consulted to determine a propertyâ€™s correct zoning designation.
Accordingly, we
  believe a genuine issue of material fact exists as to whether Buyer possessed
  the knowledge or the means to acquire the knowledge concerning the true zoning
  of this property.Â  See Abbeville Arms v. City of Abbeville, 273
  S.C. 491, 257 S.E.2d 716 (1979); Landing Dev. Corp., 285 S.C. at 220,
  329 S.E.2d at 425.Â  At trial, both parties will have the opportunity to develop
  evidence on the issue of whether or not the official zoning map in Richland County is the exclusive means for acquiring zoning information.
2.  Justifiable
  Reliance
Buyer contends
  there is a question of material fact whether its reliance on the
  representations of County officers and staff, acting within their proper scope
  of authority, was justified.Â  We agree.
At the zoning
  hearing, Price was asked about Staffâ€™s determination that Buyerâ€™s parcel was
  zoned RU, and the Planning Commissionâ€™s subsequent approval of Buyerâ€™s
  subdivision plan for manufactured housing which was predicated upon RU zoning.Â 
  Price admitted: â€œIt was thought to be approvable when we were asked.â€Â  Price
  also conceded subdivision coordinator Gosline told him the parcel was zoned
  RU.Â  Price then reviewed tax cards from the assessorâ€™s office showing the
  parcelâ€™s zoning as RU; however, Price could offer no reason for the
  contradictions of these statements and his later determination the development
  had a classification of RS-1.Â  
Broker
  testified he met with subdivision coordinator Gosline about two months before
  Buyer purchased the parcel.Â  Broker stated it was the common practice for
  brokers to consult Staff to determine a parcelâ€™s zoning classification.Â  He
  also acknowledged that, prior to November 17, 2004, he was unaware County kept
  an official zoning map and had never heard of developers demanding to see it. Additionally,
  Broker testified that Gosline determined the parcel was zoned RU by looking it
  up on his computer.Â  Broker confirmed he later saw a tax bill that showed the
  property was zoned RU.Â  Finally, Broker stated prior to November 17, 2004, all
  County documents referring to the parcel, including Buyerâ€™s recorded
  subdivision plat, showed the parcel was zoned RU.Â  
Based
  on all of these assertions, Buyer purchased the parcel, then surveyed, platted
  and prepared it for development.Â  We hold this evidence created a genuine issue
  of material fact as to whether Buyerâ€™s reliance on the representations of
  County officers and staff was justified.
3.  Prejudicial
  Change in Position
Buyer
  contends there is a question of material fact whether harm was caused by his
  justifiable reliance on the Countyâ€™s representations.Â  Specifically, he argues
  there was evidence that: (1) after Countyâ€™s Planning Staff determined the
  parcel was zoned RU, which permitted a manufactured home subdivision, Buyer
  purchased the parcel and prepared it for development; (2) after the Planning
  Commission unanimously approved the subdivision plan for Brockington Acres,
  Buyer recorded the plat, marketed the property, and sold lots for twelve months
  without objection; and (3) after County granted permits to purchasers for
  installation ofÂ  their manufactured homes, it notified Buyer the parcel was
  zoned RS-1 and development must cease.[3]Â  
Buyer
  contends that, as a result of his detrimental reliance, the value of his
  property was greatly diminished.Â  Broker testified mobile homes predominate in
  the community encompassing Brockington Acres and lots for â€œstick-built homesâ€
  do not sell as quickly as lots for manufactured-homes.Â  After County
  told Buyer he could not install manufactured-homes on his property, he sold six
  lots at a twenty-percent discount to the church members who had earlier opposed
  his development, losing a substantial amount of interest Buyer would have
  received from self-financing those six lots to the original purchasers.Â  We
  believe these facts clearly demonstrate a question of Buyerâ€™s prejudicial
  change in position.Â  Â Â 
Under the
  standard of review for summary judgment, we find questions of material fact exist
  on each of the elements of Buyerâ€™s cause of action for equitable estoppel.Â 
  Accordingly, the courtâ€™s order granting County summary judgment on this cause of
  action is reversed.
CONCLUSION
The circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor
  of County on Buyerâ€™s claims of the existence of a valid zoning ordinance and
  inverse condemnation are affirmed.Â  The grant of summary judgment in favor of
  County on Buyerâ€™s claims of negligence, negligent misrepresentation, and
  equitable estoppel are reversed.
AFFIRMED IN PART,
  REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
CURETON, A.J.,
  concurs.Â  PIEPER, J., dissents in a separate  opinion.
PIEPER, J., dissenting:
While
  I recognize the facts of the case are troubling, I respectfully dissent.
I do not believe
  that the Tort Claims Act provides a remedy for any negligence or mistake of a
  governmental employee not authorized by statute or ordinance to deviate from a
  zoning ordinance duly passed by the county.Â  The negligence or mistake at issue
  did not involve the exercise of a discretionary act by even the duly authorized
  zoning administrator; instead, the negligent act or mistake at issue was the
  misinterpretation of the official zoning classification by an official other
  than the zoning administrator.Â Â  Moreover, there simply is no indication that
  the zoning administrator or anyone else had the authority to deviate from the
  official zoning classification absent a duly authorized variance.
I am
  also concerned that the opinion may be interpreted as modifying the
  long-standing jurisprudence of this state regarding the application of estoppel
  against a governmental entity by recharacterizing a possible estoppel claim, if
  any, into one for negligence or negligent misrepresentation.Â  United States
  Supreme Court Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes once noted that "men must turn
  square corners when they deal with the Government."Â  Rock Island, A.
    & L. R. Co. v. United States, 254 U.S. 141, 143 (1920).Â  This case
  indeed presents such a situation and the majority opinion is very compelling as
  to the estoppel issue and the issue of summary judgment.
However,
  based upon my interpretation of the law on this issue, I would affirm the
  decision of the circuit court.


[1] The Record indicates Price was not the Countyâ€™s
  zoning administrator in 2003 when the Planning Commission approved Buyerâ€™s
  subdivision plan.Â  Â Â 
[2] We note there appears to be a divergence in our
  stateâ€™s case law as to the number of elements required to prove equitable
  estoppel; however, for the purposes of this appeal, we analyze this claim under
  the three element rubric.Â  See e.g. McCrowey v. Zoning Bd. of
    Adjustment of City of Rock Hill, 360 S.C. 301, 305, 599 S.E.2d 617, 619
  (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Oswald v. Aiken County, 281 S.C. 298,
  305, 315 S.E.2d 146, 151 (Ct. App. 1984)).
[3] Purchasers
  who had received permits and had placed mobile homes on their lots were
  required to remove them.Â

title: Houston v. Deloach & Deloach
description: In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the Appellant alleges the circuit court erred: (1) in affirming the Full Commissionâ€™s denial of benefits to the Claimant when the Claimant was injured in a motor vehicle accident while on the route assigned by the Employer and acting in furtherance of his employerâ€™s business at the time of the accident; (2) in finding that the Claimant deviated from his employment by allowing a trainee to drive the dump truck; and (3) in holding the Commissionâ€™s finding that the Appellant allowed an unauthorized driver drive the truck was supported by substantial evidence.
