THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jesse
      Houston, Appellant,
				v.
				Deloach
      & Deloach, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Beaufort County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4408
Heard June 3, 2008 â€“ Filed June 10, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Darrell Thomas Johnson, Jr. and Warren Paul Johnson, both of Hardeeville,
  for Appellant.
				Allison M. Carter, of Mount Pleasant, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.:Â 
  Jesse Houston appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the decision of the
  appellate panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission which
  denied him benefits for injuries suffered in a motor vehicle accident.Â  We
  affirm.
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On Saturday, August 23, 2003, Jesse Houston (Claimant) was injured
  in a motor vehicle accident while riding as a passenger in a commercial dump
  truck owned by his employer, Deloach & Deloach (Employer).Â  Employer denied
  the claim, arguing that Claimant was outside the scope of his employment at the
  time of the accident.
Claimant testified that prior to the injury he had been authorized
  to train a prospective employee named Marlene Gadson (Gadson) to drive a dump
  truck.Â  Claimant averred he had been training Gadson for approximately two
  weeks at the time of the accident.Â  Neither party disputed that Gadson was
  authorized to train with Claimant or that Gadson was training with Claimant on
  the morning of the accident.Â  Gadson professed that on the day of the accident she
  had a disagreement with Claimant and ceased her training at approximately 11:00
  a.m.Â  She vouched that Claimant was drinking beer the morning of the accident.
After Gadson exited the dump truck, Claimant picked up Leslie
  Brown (Brown).Â  Brown had never trained to drive a dump truck prior to the date
  of the accident, but Claimant allowed her to drive the truck while fully loaded
  with asphalt that same day.Â  Although the dump truck had only two seats in its
  cab, Claimant and Brown picked up an unauthorized passenger, Kimberly Blake, at
  some point during the day.Â  Neither Brown nor Blake was employed by Employer.Â  Brown
  subsequently wrecked the truck, injuring Claimant.
The testimony conflicted over whether Claimant had permission to
  allow Brown to drive the truck.Â  Claimant contended he first met Brown on
  Tuesday, August 19, 2003, and on that day Otis Deloach (Deloach), owner of
  Employer and Claimantâ€™s boss, expressly permitted him to train Brown to drive
  the dump truck.Â  He advanced that this permission was given in the company of
  Alfred Ervin and Leroy Stevenson, both employees of Employer.Â  Deloach maintained
  that he did not give Claimant permission to train Brown, and he never met Brown
  prior to the August 23, 2003 accident.Â  Brown stated she had not met Claimant
  prior to the date of the accident.Â  She first heard of Employer the day before
  the accident.Â  
Alfred Ervin (Ervin) declared he had no knowledge of Deloach
  giving Claimant permission to train Brown.Â  Ervin substantiated that before he
  ever drove a loaded dump truck, he trained with an unloaded truck for
  approximately ten days.Â  Leroy Stevenson asseverated he did not observe Deloach
  give the Claimant permission to train Brown.
The commissioner issued an order finding Claimant suffered
  compensable injuries within the course and scope of his employment.Â  An appeal
  was heard by the appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  The
  appellate panel issued a split decision where the majority made the following
  findings of fact:

	1.Â  That the Claimant did not have the authority or permission to
  allow Ms. Brown to drive the Employerâ€™s loaded dump truck at the time of the
  accident.
	2.Â  That skill and training are required to drive a commercial
  dump truck filled with asphalt.
	3.Â  That the Claimant did not have permission to drink alcoholic
  beverages during the time period he was performing job duties.
	4.Â  That the Claimantâ€™s act in allowing an unauthorized person to
  drive his Employerâ€™s truck constituted an impermissible deviation from his
  duties, and therefore, the accident did not arise out of the course and scope
  of his duties.
	5.Â  That the Claimantâ€™s injuries to his left lower extremity,
  right arm, and neck did not occur in the course and scope of employment on
  August 23, 2003, and he is therefore not entitled to benefits under the South
  Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.
	The appellate panel announced its conclusions of law:
	1.Â  Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160, the Claimant did not sustain
  an injury by accident arising out of and in the course of his employment.
	2.Â  That the Claimantâ€™s actions deviated outside the course and
  scope of employment by using a company vehicle in an inappropriate and
  unauthorized manner.Â  Boykin v. Prioleau, 255 S.C. 437, 179 S.E.2d 599
  (1971).

The circuit court issued an order affirming the appellate panelâ€™s
  denial of benefits.Â  The circuit court denied Claimantâ€™s motion to alter or
  amend judgment pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP.
ISSUES
1.Â  Does
  substantial evidence support the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Claimant
  allowed an unauthorized person to drive the Employerâ€™s dump truck which
  resulted in an impermissible deviation from his duties?
2.Â 
  Did the circuit court and appellate panel commit an error of law in determining Claimant did not sustain an
  injury by accident arising out of and in the course of his employment?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative
  Procedures Act governs judicial review of a decision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commission. Â Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306
  (1981); Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 467, 617 S.E.2d 369, 376 (Ct. App.
  2005); Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 288, 599 S.E.2d 604,
  610 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Pursuant to the APA, an appellate courtâ€™s review is
  limited to deciding whether the full commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by
  substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Grant v. Grant
    Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 200, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006).
I.  Substantial
  Evidence Standard
The judicial review of the appellate panelâ€™s factual findings is
  governed by the substantial evidence standard.Â  Gadson v. Mikasa Corp., 368
  S.C. 214, 221, 628 S.E.2d 262, 266 (Ct. App. 2006); Frame v. Resort Servs.,
    Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 527, 593 S.E.2d 491, 494 (Ct. App. 2004); Corbin v.
      Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 94-95 (Ct. App. 2002); Lockridge
        v. Santens of America, Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App.
  2001).Â  The appellate panelâ€™s decision must be affirmed if supported by
  substantial evidence in the record.Â  Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C.
  435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Sharpe v. Case
    Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999)).Â  A reviewing
  court may not substitute its judgment for the judgment of the agency as to the
  weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(d)(e) (Supp. 2006); see also Hall
    v. United Rentals, Inc., 371 S.C. 69, 77, 636 S.E.2d 876, 881 (Ct. App.
  2006).Â  However, a reviewing
  court may reverse or modify a decision of the appellate panel if the findings,
  inferences, conclusions, or decisions of the panel are â€œclearly erroneous in
  view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(e) (Supp.
  2006); Bass v. Kenco Group,
  366 S.C. 450, 457, 622 S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 2005); Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App.
  2004), affâ€™d, 369 S.C. 176, 631 S.E.2d 899 (2006).Â  
It is
  not within the appellate courtâ€™s province to reverse the appellate panelâ€™s
  factual findings if they are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Etheredge
    v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 454, 562 S.E.2d 679, 681 (Ct. App. 2002)
  (citing Hoxit v. Michelin Tire Corp., 304 S.C. 461, 405 S.E.2d 407
  (1991)); Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 282, 519 S.E.2d 583, 591
  (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor
  the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which,
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the
  conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action. Â Pratt
    v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004); Jones
      v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 417, 586 S.E.2d 111, 113 (2003); Brown
        v. Greenwood Mills, Inc., 366 S.C. 379, 392, 622 S.E.2d 546, 554 (Ct. App.
  2005); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 495, 520 S.E.2d
  634, 637 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent
  conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s
  findings from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe, 336 S.C.
  at 160, 519 S.E.2d at 105; Smith v. NCCI Inc., 369 S.C. 236, 247, 631
  S.E.2d 268, 274 (Ct. App. 2006); DuRant v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl.
    Control, 361 S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d 704, 707 (Ct. App. 2004).
The appellate panel is the ultimate fact finder in workersâ€™
  compensation cases and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of
  fact.Â  Isochem, 365 S.C. at 468, 617 S.E.2d at 376; Frame, 357
  S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495; Muir, 336 S.C. at 281, 519 S.E.2d at
  591.Â  The final determination of witness credibility and the weight assigned to
  the evidence is reserved to the appellate panel.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); Frame, 357 S.C. at
  528, 593 S.E.2d at 495.Â  Where there are conflicts in the evidence over a factual
  issue, the findings of the appellate panel are conclusive.Â  Brown, 366
  S.C. at 393, 622 S.E.2d at 554; Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 455, 562 S.E.2d
  at 681; see also Mullinax v. Winn Dixie Stores, Inc., 318 S.C.
  431, 435, 458 S.E.2d 76, 78 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œWhere the medical evidence
  conflicts, the findings of fact of the [appellate panel] are conclusive.â€).
The
  findings of the appellate panel are presumed correct and will be set aside only
  if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Kenco Group, 366 S.C. at 458,
  622 S.E.2d at 581; Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495; Broughton,
  336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 637.Â  The appellate court is prohibited from
  overturning findings of fact of the appellate panel unless there is no
  reasonable probability the facts could be as related by the witness upon whose
  testimony the finding was based.Â  Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C.
    Second Injury Fund, 611 S.E.2d 297, 301, 363 S.C. 612, 621 (Ct. App. 2005); Hargrove, 360 S.C. at 290, 599 S.E.2d at 611; Etheredge, 349 S.C.
  at 455-56, 562 S.E.2d at 681.Â  The appellate panelâ€™s factual findings will
  normally be upheld; however, such a finding may not be based upon surmise,
  conjecture, or speculation, but must be founded on evidence of sufficient
  substance to afford a reasonable basis for it.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care
    Ctr. of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 339, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999); Muir,
  336 S.C. at 282, 519 S.E.2d at 591; Sharpe v. Case Produce Co., 329 S.C.
  534, 543, 495 S.E.2d 790, 794 (Ct. App. 1997), revâ€™d on other grounds,
  336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 102 (1999). 
II.  Errors
  of Law
An appellate court may reverse or modify
  the decision of the appellate panel if substantial rights of the appellant have
  been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions,
  or decisions are affected by other error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(A)(5)(d) (Supp. 2006); Porter v. Labor Depot, Â 372 S.C. 560,
  567, 643 S.E.2d 96, 100 (Ct. App. 2007), cert. denied, Dec. 5, 2007; Bass
    v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 467, 617 S.E.2d 369, 376 (Ct. App. 2005); Pratt
      v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 353 S.C. 339, 344, 577 S.E.2d 475, 477 (Ct. App.
  2003), affâ€™d as modified, 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 272 (2004).
Section
  14-3-330 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) vests the South Carolina
  Supreme Court with â€œappellate jurisdiction for correction of errors of law in
  law cases . . . .â€Â  Citing both section 14-3-330 and South Carolina Constitution,
  article V, section 5, the supreme court has held an appellate court may decide
  novel questions of law with â€œno particular deference to the lower court.â€Â  Madison ex rel. Bryant v. Babcock Ctr., Inc., 371 S.C. 123, 134, 638 S.E.2d
  650, 656 (2006); Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 378, 529 S.E.2d
  528, 533 (2000).Â  Section 14-8-200(a) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides
  the Court of Appeals â€œshall apply the same scope of review that the Supreme
  Court would apply in a similar case.â€ 
An
  appellate courtâ€™s review of factual findings in a workersâ€™ compensation case is
  governed and controlled by the substantial evidence rule.Â  However, an
  appellate court freely and absolutely reviews a trial courtâ€™s decision
  concerning an issue of law. See Lizee v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Health,
  367 S.C. 122, 126, 623 S.E.2d 860, 863 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œ[W]here the
  Commissionâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of law, this courtâ€™s review is
  plenary.â€). Â No passivity or complaisance is owed or given to the ruling of the
  appellate panel or circuit judge in this context.Â  The highly deferential
  standards statutorily and universally applied in reviewing issues of fact, such
  as the â€œclearly erroneousâ€ and the â€œmanifest errorâ€ standards, have no efficacy
  in regard to an issue of law.Â  â€œThe South Carolina Court of Appeals exercises
  freedom and independence in deciding an issue of law in a workersâ€™ compensation
  case.â€Â  Thompson ex rel. Harvey v. Cisson Const. Co., 659 S.E.2d 171
  (Ct. App. 2008).
LAW / ANALYSIS
â€œThe
  South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act requires that, to be compensable, an
  injury by accident must be one â€˜arising out of and in the course of
  employment.â€™â€Â  Osteen v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., 333 S.C. 43, 49,
  508 S.E.2d 21, 24 (1998).Â  See also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2007); Grant v. Grant Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 201, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007); Hall
    v. Desert Aire, Inc., 376 S.C. 338, 348, 656 S.E.2d 753, 758 (Ct. App.
  2007).Â  â€œAlthough the requirements are somewhat overlapping, they are not
  sysonymous and both must exist simultaneously to allow the claimant to recover
  workersâ€™ compensation benefits.â€Â  Hall, 376 S.C. at 349, 656 S.E.2d at
  758. 
The
  question of whether an injury arises out of and is in the course and scope of
  employment is largely a question of fact for the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commissionâ€™s appellate panel.Â  Broughton v. South of the Border, 336
  S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 638 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The claimant has the
  burden of proving facts that will bring the injury within the workersâ€™
  compensation law.Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510,
  518, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000); accord Clade v. Champion
    Laboratories, 330 S.C. 8, 11, 496 S.E.2d 856, 857 (1998); Sola v. Sunny
      Slope Farms, 244 S.C. 6, 10, 135 S.E.2d 321, 324 (1964).
I.  â€œArising Out Ofâ€
The
  phrase â€œarising out ofâ€ in the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act refers to the injury's
  origin and cause.Â  Osteen, 333 S.C. at 50, 508 S.E.2d at 24; Baggott
    v. Southern Music, Inc., 330 S.C. 1, 5, 496 S.E.2d 852, 854 (1998). Â For an
  injury to â€œarise out ofâ€ employment, the injury must be proximately caused by
  the employment.Â  Osteen, 333 S.C. at 50, 508 S.E.2d at 24. See also Fowler v. Abbott Motor Co., 236 S.C. 226, 230, 113 S.E.2d 737, 739
  (1960) (accident â€œarises out ofâ€ employment when it arises because of it, as
  when the employment is a contributing proximate cause).Â  â€œIt must be apparent
  to the rational mind, considering all the circumstances, that a causal
  relationship exists between the conditions under which the work is performed
  and the resulting injury.â€Â  Hall, 376 S.C. at 350, 656 S.E.2d at 759
  (citing Smith v. NCCI, Inc., 369 S.C. 236, 253, 631 S.E.2d 268, 277
  (Ct.App.2006); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 497, 520
  S.E.2d 634, 638 (Ct.App.1999)).Â  In Douglas v. Spartan Mills, Startex
    Div., 245 S.C. 265, 140 S.E.2d 173 (1965), our supreme court discussed the
  â€œarising out ofâ€ requirement:

	It (the
  injury) arises â€œout ofâ€ the employment, when there is apparent to the rational
  mind upon consideration of all the circumstances, a causal connection between
  the conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the
  resulting injury.Â  Under this test, if the injury can be seen to have followed
  as a natural incident of the work and to have been contemplated by a reasonable
  person familiar with the whole situation as a result of the exposure occasioned
  by the nature of the employment, then it arises â€œout ofâ€ the employment.Â  But
  it excludes an injury which cannot fairly be traced to the employment as a
  contributing proximate cause and which comes from a hazard to which the workmen
  would have been equally exposed apart from the employment.Â  The causative danger
  must be peculiar to the work and not common to the neighborhood.Â  It must be
  incidental to the character of the business and not independent of the relation
  of master and servant.Â  It need not have been foreseen or expected, but after
  the event it must appear to have had its origin in a risk connected with the
  employment, and to have flowed from that source as a rational consequence.

Id., 245 S.C. at 269, 140 S.E.2d at 175 (quoting Eargle
  v. S.C. Elec. & Gas Co., 205 S.C. 423, 429-30, 32 S.E.2d 240, 242-43
  (1944); In re Employersâ€™ Liability Assur. Corp., 102 N.E. 697, 697 (Mass. 1913)).
II.  â€œIn the Course of
  the Employmentâ€
The
  phrase â€œin the course of the employmentâ€ refers to the time, place, and
  circumstances under which the accident occurred.Â  Owings v. Anderson County
    Sheriffâ€™s Depâ€™t, 315 S.C. 297, 433 S.E.2d 869 (1993); Loges v. Mack
      Trucks, Inc., 308 S.C. 134, 417 S.E.2d 538 (1992); Hall, 376 S.C. at
  349, 656 S.E.2d at 758; Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 187, 528
  S.E.2d 435, 443 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  An injury occurs â€œin the course ofâ€
  employment within the meaning of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act when it occurs
  within the period of employment at a place where the employee reasonably may be
  in the performance of his duties and while fulfilling those duties or engaged
  in something incidental thereto.Â  Baggott, 330 S.C. 1, 496 S.E.2d 852; Fowler,
  236 S.C. 226, 113 S.E.2d 737; Broughton, 336 S.C. at 498, 520 S.E.2d at
  639.
III.  Impermissible
  Deviation
In Boykin
  v. Prioleau, 255 S.C. 437, 179 S.E.2d 599 (1971), an employee was assigned
  to take several co-workers home after work.Â  â€œInstead of doing so, he took them
  on an extensive joy ride. During the course of this jaunt some intoxicants were
  consumed while stops were made at two houses, two night clubs and, finally, at
  a restaurant several miles out Farrow Road at about 5:45 A.M.â€Â  Id. at 440, 179 S.E.2d at 600.Â  While the employee was driving back to Columbia to take the co-workers home, the vehicle was involved in a fatal accident.Â  Id.

	The supreme
  court articulated:
	
		The
  only reasonable inference from the facts which have been stated is that almost
  immediately upon driving away from his employerâ€™s place of business, Dickerson
  forsook the task assigned to him and embarked upon the pursuit of his own ends.
  It is abundantly clear that while thus engaged he was not conducting his
  employerâ€™s business within the meaning of the [workersâ€™ compensation] statute.
	

Id. at 441, 179 S.E.2d at 600.
The appellate panel
  correctly applied Boykin to the facts of this case when concluding
  â€œClaimantâ€™s actions deviated outside the course and scope of employment by
  using a company vehicle in an inappropriate and unauthorized manner.â€
In Brownlee
  v. Wetterau Food Services, 288 S.C. 82, 339 S.E.2d 694 (Ct. App. 1986),
  this Court held that an employee who died in an automobile accident while out
  of town on business was not acting within the scope of and in the course of his
  employment at the time of death.Â  Brownlee, who worked out of the employerâ€™s North Charleston office, was sent to St. Louis, Missouri to attend a training seminar.Â  Id. at 84, 339 S.E.2d at 695.Â  The seminar began each day around 7:00 a.m. and ended
  at 10:00 p.m.Â  Id.Â  Everyone attending the seminar from out of town
  roomed at the motel where all of the seminar activities took place.Â  Id.
The
  accident occurred at 1:55 a.m., apparently when the employee and several other
  seminar attendees were returning from watching a movie.Â  Id.Â  The movie
  was an outing planned by Brownlee and other attendees after the end of the
  seminarâ€™s daily events.Â  Id.Â  Because the accident occurred some
  distance from the motel and several hours after the last scheduled seminar
  event had ended, we held: â€œthere is substantial evidence Brownlee died while
  engaged in an outing that occurred after work, away from the premises of his
  employer, and at a time when his employer exercised no control over his
  activities.â€Â  Id. at 85, 339 S.E.2d at 695.
The
  present case can be distinguished from Hall v. Desert Aire, Inc., 376
  S.C. 338, 656 S.E.2d 753 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  In Hall, the employee and
  another individual went for a jeep ride after a dinner party where alcohol was
  consumed.Â  Id. at 345, 656 S.E.2d at 756-57.Â  The employer regularly
  paid for entertainment, including alcohol, which was common practice for the
  industry.Â  Id.Â  The evidence indicated that the discussions at the
  dinner party were strictly related to the employerâ€™s business, and the two
  intended on continuing their business discussions in the jeep.Â  Id.Â  The jeep overturned approximately 300 yards from where the ride started,
  wounding Hall and killing the driver.Â  Id.

	This
  Court determined:
	
		Pellucidly,
  the evidentiary record exuberates that Hall was engaged in ongoing discussions
  regarding planning for sales activities on behalf of Desert Aire at the time of
  the accident.Â  The accident occurred within the period of employment, at a
  place where Hall was reasonably in the performance of his duties and was
  fulfilling those duties or engaged in activities incidental to that employment.Â 
  Like the claimants in Beam, Hall was not exercising a personal privilege
  wholly apart from Desert Aireâ€™s interests.Â  Rather, Hallâ€™s ongoing business
  discussion with Brunner was an act, incidental to and recognized as beneficial
  by Desert Aire in connection with Hallâ€™s duties as national sales manager. . .
  .
		We hold
  substantial evidence supports the factual finding that Hallâ€™s injury arose out
  of and in the course of employment with Desert Aire, illatively satisfying the
  legal standard for compensability under section 42-1-160 of the South Carolina
  Code of Laws.
	

Id. at 360-61, 656 S.E.2d at 764-65 (citing Beam v.
  State Workmenâ€™s Compensation Fund, 261 S.C. 327, 200 S.E.2d 83, (1973)).
The
  case sub judice differs from Hall, where Hall was advancing his
  employerâ€™s interests by discussing business on the jeep ride.Â  Although the
  parties in the present case dispute whether Claimant was authorized to train
  Brown and allow her to drive the truck, there is substantial evidence to
  support the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Brown was not authorized to drive
  the truck.Â  By allowing Brown to drive, Claimant deviated from the task he was
  assigned to do: haul asphalt from a plant to a road construction site.Â  The
  deviation resulted in an accident that injured him, and thus, Claimantâ€™s
  injuries did not arise out of and in the course of his employment with Deloach
  & Deloach.
CONCLUSION
The
  factual findings of the appellate panel are presumed correct and will only be
  set aside if unsupported by substantial evidence. Rodney v. Michelin Tire
    Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 519, 466 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1996). We rule there is
  substantial evidence to support the factual finding that allowing Brown to
  drive the dump truck was an impermissible deviation from Claimantâ€™s duties.Â  We
  hold Claimantâ€™s injuries did not arise out of and in the course of his
  employment.Â  We place our imprimatur upon the rulings of law by the appellate
  panel and the circuit court.
Accordingly,
  the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

title: Sweat v. State
description: In this criminal prosecution, the State appeals contending the circuit court erred: (1) in interpreting Section 56-5-4140(2)(a) to not limit the maximum gross vehicle weight of the enumerated vehicles of that subsection beyond the allowable cumulative axle weights not withstanding the plain language of the limiting phrase for maximum gross vehicle weight; and (2) in interpreting the words â€œthis sectionâ€ in the phrase â€œand the gross weight may not exceed the maximum weight allowed by this sectionâ€ to refer to and confine itself to subsection 56-5-4140(2)(a) to the exclusion of 56-5-4140(1)(a) which sets forth maximum weights of commercial vehicles thus ignoring the legislative intent to restrict gross vehicle weight on South Carolina highways.

FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
On
  February 14, 2006, Reginald Craig Sweat, a sanitation truck driver for the City
  of Aiken, was stopped and cited by a State Transport Police (hereafter STP)
  officer for exceeding the allowable gross vehicle weight for the 2005 Sterling
  Model LT9500, three-axle sanitation truck he was driving.Â  The citation alleges
  the vehicle weighed 57,100 pounds.Â  The officer claimed the allowable weight
  was 50,600 pounds, calculated as 46,000 pounds plus a ten percent scale
  tolerance of 4,600 pounds.
On
  April 10, 2006, a different STP officer cited Arthur Bryant, III, another
  driver for the City of Aiken, for driving the same sanitation truck in excess
  of the allowable gross vehicle weight.Â  On this occasion, the truck weighed
  56,900 pounds.Â  The officer noted the allowable weight as 50,600 pounds.
A
  trial was held before an Aiken County Magistrate.Â  The State and Respondents
  stipulated to the facts of the case.Â  The drivers made a motion to dismiss both
  tickets alleging South Carolina Code Section 56-5-4140 permits them to operate
  the cityâ€™s sanitation truck at a maximum gross vehicle weight of 66,000 pounds,
  i.e., a higher gross vehicle weight than the actual vehicle weight shown on the
  two citations.Â  The magistrate issued two separate orders finding each driver
  guilty of violating the gross vehicle weight statute.Â  The orders do not
  contain findings of fact or conclusions of law.
The
  drivers appealed their convictions to the Court of Common Pleas.Â  The circuit
  court reversed the magistrateâ€™s orders and remanded the cases for entry of a
  not guilty verdict.Â  The courtâ€™s order articulates:

	S.C. Code Section 56-5-4140 contains several sections
  which set forth the weight limits of trucks driving on South Carolina roads
  that are not in the interstate highway system.
	Under Section 56-5-4140(1)(a)(2), the general weight
  limit provision, the gross weight for vehicles equipped with three axles is
  46,000 pounds.
	Several exceptions to this general rule for gross
  vehicle weights exist under this statute, however.
	Under Section 56-5-4140(1)(b) trucks with three axles
  spaced 32 feet in any consecutive group allow the gross vehicle weight to top
  out at 60,000 pounds.
	Another excepted group of trucks appears in Section
  56-5-4140(2)(a).Â  Under this provision, trucks designated and constructed for
  special type workâ€”and the state [sic] has stipulated the City of
    Aiken garbage truck is such a truckâ€”are exempted from any axle spacing
  requirements, are limited to a maximum gross weight of 20,000 pounds per axle 
	plus
    scale tolerances.
	Under S.C. Code Section 56-5-4160, scale tolerances
  are set at ten percent.
	Photos introduced to Magistrate Neal and this Court
  show the garbage truck to have three axles.Â  A review of the tickets issued to
  Appellants show that the vehicle weights for Sweatâ€™s driving to have been
  15,500 pounds for axle 1 and 41,600 pounds for axle 2 and 3 in total.Â  When
  Bryant drove the truck, it weight [sic] in at 15,300 for axle 1; 21,200 for
  axle 2; and 20,400 for axle 3.
	All of these weights were well within the
  statutorily-set maximum weight per axle of 22,000 pounds.Â  
	The Stateâ€™s position that only the general provision
  under Section 56-5-4140(1)(a)(2) apply to this truck is misplaced.
	To adopt the Stateâ€™s reading of this statute would
  contravene state law of statutory interpretation.Â  When reviewing a statute,
  this Court must follow specific provisions over general language in the
  statute.
	In these present cases, applying the specific
  statutory provisions allow for a garbage truck, as a vehicle constructed for a
  special type of work, means it can weigh in at up to 22,000 pounds per axle.Â 
  Both Appellants were well within these limits as appears from the uncontraverted
  [sic] evidence in this record.

In
  the order denying the Stateâ€™s motion to alter or amend judgment pursuant to
  Rule 59(e), SCRCP, the circuit court reiterated and further explained the
  reasoning of its prior order:

	Respondent has stipulated that the City of Aiken garbage truck driven by these two Appellants is a truck â€œ. . . designed and
  constructed for special type work . . .â€ under the provisions of Section
  56-5-4140(2)(a), S.C. Code Ann. (2005).
	Trucks subject to this exception to the state gross

  weight of 20,000 pounds per axle, plus a 10% scale tolerance, not to exceed the

	In one instance, this truck driven by Sweat, with a
  single axle under the cab, and a tandem axle under its payload, weighed a total
  of 57,100 pounds [15,500 for the cab axle plus 41,600 lbs for payload axles].Â 
  When driven by Arthur Bryant, III, this truck weighed a total of 56,900 pounds
  [15,300 cab axle plus 41,600 for payload axles].Â  In both instances, the truck
  was well below the statutory maximum gross vehicle weight for a three-axle,
  specially built truck under 56-5-4140(2)(a):

	Section 56-5-4140(2)(a) is the applicable specific
  statutory exception to the general gross weight limits contained in

  Except on the interstate highway system:
	(a) Dump
  trucks, dump trailers, trucks carrying agricultural products, concrete mixing
  trucks, fuel oil trucks, line trucks, and trucks designated and constructed for
  special type work or use are not required to conform to the axle spacing
  requirements of this section. However, the vehicle is limited to a weight of
  twenty thousand pounds for each axle plus scale tolerances and the maximum
  gross weight of these vehicles may not exceed the maximum weight allowed by
  this section for the appropriate number of axles, irrespective of the distance
  between axles, plus allowable scale tolerances.
	(b)
  Concrete mixing trucks which operate within a fifteen-mile radius of their home
  base are not required to conform to the requirements of this section. However,
  these vehicles are limited to a maximum load of the rated capacity of the
  concrete mixer, the true gross load not to exceed sixty-six thousand pounds.
  All of these vehicles shall have at least three axles each with brake-equipped
  wheels.
	(c)
  Well-drilling, boring rigs, and tender trucks are not required to conform to
  the axle spacing requirements of this section. However, the vehicle is limited
  to seventy thousand pounds gross vehicle weight and twenty-five thousand pounds
  for each axle plus scale tolerances.

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-4140 (2006).
Section 56-5-4160(A) states, in part: â€œIn determining
  whether the limits established by Section 56-5-4130 or 56-5-4140 have been
  exceeded, the scaled weights of the gross weight of vehicles and combinations
  of vehicles are considered to be not closer than ten percent to the true gross
  weight, except as otherwise provided in Section 56-5-4140.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  56-5-4160(A) (Supp. 2007).
The
  State has conceded that the drivers were operating â€œtrucks designated and
  constructed for special type workâ€ as defined in subsection (2)(a) of section
  56-5-4140.Â  The only remaining question is how to interpret the language of
  this subsection.Â  It permits special use trucks to weigh 20,000 pounds per axle
  plus the ten percent scale tolerance.Â  This totals 22,000 pounds per axle or
  66,000 total pounds for three-axle vehicles such as the sanitation truck at
  issue here.Â  This is the only reasonable way to interpret this language.
The
  State focuses on the second part of subsection (2)(a) and argues it
  incorporates the general standard of subsection (1)(a).Â  The Stateâ€™s position
  is incorrect because it would render subsection (2)(a) meaningless.Â  If we
  accepted the Stateâ€™s interpretation, the maximum allowable weight for a
  three-axle vehicle would be 46,000 pounds plus scale tolerances totaling 50,600
  pounds, regardless of the special use exception found in subsection (2)(a).Â  The
  Stateâ€™s interpretation strips the special use vehicle exception of any real
  force or meaning.Â  Under the Stateâ€™s theory, the general rule in (1)(a) would
  always apply and the exception in (2)(a) would be pointless.Â  The General
  Assembly obviously intended the exception to have some efficacy, or the
  legislature would not have enacted it into law.
The
  circuit courtâ€™s interpretation properly honors and harmonizes both
  subsections.Â  Subsection (1)(a) sets the general per-axle standard for vehicles
  in South Carolina.Â  Subsection (2)(a) provides a different standard for
  specific types of vehicles when they are not operated on the interstate highway
  system.Â  Subsection (2)(a) does precisely what an exception is intended to do:
  it identifies a category to which the general rule does not apply.Â  The courtâ€™s
  interpretation recognizes the common interplay between general rules and their
  statutorily created exceptions.Â  
The
  State overlooks the fact that subsection (2)(a) carves out an exception that
  applies only to certain specified types of vehicles, but an understanding of
  this point is vital to aÂ  proper reading of the statute.Â  The Stateâ€™s
  interpretation raises the question: why have subsection (2)(a) at all if
  subsection (1)(a) always controls?Â  The answer is that subsection (2)(a) exists
  to create a different weight allowance for â€œtrucks designated and constructed
  for special type work.â€Â  Neither subsection â€œcontrolsâ€ the other.Â  They work
  together to set forth the different standards for regular and special use
  vehicles.Â  This is the only way to harmonize the two subsections and give
  effect to both.Â  Under the rules of statutory interpretation, it was proper and
  indeed necessary for the circuit court to do so.Â  
The
  State focuses on a perceived inconsistency in the use of the words â€œthis
  sectionâ€ in subsection (2)(a).Â  According to the State, the phrase â€œmaximum
  weight allowed by this sectionâ€ can only be a reference back to the general
  standard of subsection (1)(a).Â  We rule that the phrase â€œthis sectionâ€ refers
  to section 56-5-4140 as a whole.Â  This includes subsection (1)(b), which
  presents a formula for increased weight allowances based on the number of axles
  and the distances between them.Â  The maximum allowable weight for a three-axle
  vehicle under subsection (1)(b) is 80,000 total pounds.Â  This is the largest
  allowable weight found anywhere in section 56-5-4140.
When
  one reads the phrase â€œthis sectionâ€ in the clause â€œ. . . and the maximum gross
  weight of these vehicles may not exceed the maximum weight allowed by this
  section for the appropriate number of axles, irrespective of the distance
  between axles, plus allowable scale tolerancesâ€ in subsection (2)(a) to refer
  to the entire section of the Code, a clear and consistent meaning emerges.Â 
  Special use vehicles can exceed the general rule requirements of subsection
  (1)(a), but the exception in no event allows those vehicles to surpass the
  maximum figures found in subsection (1)(b).Â  The legislature used the
  additional clause in subsection (2)(a) simply to clarify this point.Â  
The
  Stateâ€™s interpretation honors only subsection (1)(a), leaving subsection (2)(a)
  without any force.Â  In affirming the circuit courtâ€™s order, we find all three
  subsections coexist, each serving specific, complementary functions.Â  
Had
  the legislature intended subsection (2)(a) to be an exception only as to tandem
  axle vehicles, as the State advances, the General Assembly could have easily
  included language expressly limiting the nature of the exception contained in
  subsection (2)(a).Â  The statute is lacking any such verbiage.Â  
It
  is true that agencies charged with enforcing statutes usually receive deference
  from the courts as to their interpretation of those laws.Â  Brown v. Bi-Lo,
    Inc., 354 S.C. 436, 440, 581 S.E.2d 836, 838 (2003).Â  Yet where â€œthe plain
  language of the statute is contrary to the agencyâ€™s interpretation, the Court
  will reject the agencyâ€™s interpretation.â€Â  Id. (citing Brown v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 560 S.E.2d 410 (2002); Richland
      Co. Sch. Dist. Two v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Educ., 335 S.C. 491, 517 S.E.2d 444 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  In this case, the State is not entitled to any deference in its
  interpretation because the plain language of section 56-5-4140(2)(a) refutes
  the Stateâ€™s position.Â  The circuit court was not bound to accept the Stateâ€™s
  interpretation of the statute.Â  This Court is free to read the statute based on
  its plain language without deference to the Stateâ€™s position.
The
  circuit court properly interpreted section 56-5-4140 based on the clear wording
  of the statute.Â  By its express terms, subsection (2)(a) allows special use
  vehicles like the one involved in these cases to weigh up to 22,000 pounds per
  axle.Â  This is an intentional exception to the general rule of subsection
  (1)(a).Â  Subsection (1)(b), and not the general rule, provides the overall
  maximum weight limitations for special use vehicles.Â  This interpretation
  honors the plain meaning of the statute, and it gives force and effect to all
  the subsections.Â  The Stateâ€™s proposed interpretation, which elevates
  subsection (1)(a) over all others and effectively renders subsection (2)(a)
  meaningless, flies in the face of the plain language of the statute.
III.Â  Public Policy
The
  Stateâ€™s claim that the circuit courtâ€™s interpretation of the statute would
  allow for grossly overweight vehicles is without merit.Â  According to the
  State, reading subsection (2)(a) as allowing up to 22,000 pounds per axle would
  lead to vehicles in excess of 100,000 pounds on South Carolinaâ€™s roads.Â  The
  State has not demonstrated that affirming the circuit court will adversely
  affect the stateâ€™s roads or public safety.Â  The Stateâ€™s argument overlooks
  subsection (1)(b).Â  This subsection establishes a maximum total weight for all
  vehicles, including special use vehicles like the one involved in this case.Â 
  The special use exception in subsection (2)(a) references and incorporates the
  statuteâ€™s overall weight limitations.Â  The maximum total weight in subsection
  (1)(b) is 80,000 pounds.Â  With the ten percent scale tolerance, the maximum
  weight of a vehicle on South Carolinaâ€™s roads is 88,000 pounds.Â  This puts to
  rest the Stateâ€™s fears of trucks weighing more than 100,000 pounds on South Carolinaâ€™s roads.Â  The State is able to cite drivers of vehicles over 88,000 pounds
  under the circuit courtâ€™s interpretation of the statute.
To
  the extent any policy considerations are implicated, they support the circuit
  courtâ€™s ruling.Â  The legislature obviously determined there was a legitimate
  reason to create separate, higher weight allowances for special use vehicles.Â 
  One purpose for this special category is to permit larger loads in order to
  limit the trips these vehicles are required to make.Â  The Stateâ€™s
  interpretation would prevent sanitation trucks from hauling full loads and
  require them to make more trips to and from the landfill.Â  This would result in
  increased fuel costs passed on to the taxpayers.Â  The legislature recognized
  that sanitation trucks and other special use vehicles are designed and built to
  handle heavier loads safely to reduce the number of trips per truck.
There
  is nothing in the statute to indicate the legislature intended to place the
  standard limitations on sanitation trucks and other special use vehicles.Â  The
  existence of the special use exception suggests the legislature wanted to
  achieve the opposite result.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s decision honors that goal.
CONCLUSION
The
  position articulated by the State in regard to the body of the statute and the
  exception is quintessential academic statutory colliquefaction.Â  The conflation
  of the base of the statute and the exception emasculates the separate efficacy
  intended by the General Assembly in adding the exception.Â  
Accordingly,
  the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.Â  
HUFF
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â

Carr (Estate) appeals the trial courtâ€™s order granting the motion for directed verdict by Circle S Enterprises, Inc. d/b/a Newberry Auto Mart, (the Dealership).  The Estate argues the trial court erred in granting a directed verdict in favor of the Dealership on the following grounds: (1) the motion for a directed verdict was improperly postured; (2) the Estate suffered damages as a result of the Dealership's conduct; and (3) there was sufficient evidence for submission of the various causes of action to the jury. THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Estate of
      Beatrice K. Carr by and through Beatrice Sue Bolton, Personal Representative, Appellant,
				v.
				Circle S
      Enterprises, Inc. d/b/a Newberry Auto Mart, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Newberry County
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  4410
Heard May 7, 2008 â€“ Filed June 10, 2008
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Paul A. James, of
  N. Charleston and Paula Howker Amick, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Karl S. Brehmer
  and L. Darby Plexico, III, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PIEPER, J.: Â The Estate of Beatrice K. Carr
  (Estate) appeals the trial courtâ€™s order granting the motion for directed
  verdict by Circle S Enterprises, Inc. d/b/a Newberry Auto Mart, (the Dealership).
  Â The Estate argues the trial court erred in granting a directed verdict in
  favor of the Dealership on the following grounds: (1) the motion for a directed
  verdict was improperly postured; (2) the Estate suffered damages as a result of
  the Dealershipʼs conduct; and (3) there was sufficient
  evidence for submission of the various causes of action to the jury.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In late
  September 2000, Linda Carr (Linda) was in the market to buy an automobile.Â 
  Linda, her mother Beatrice Carr (Beatrice), and the rest of her family went to the
  Dealership to purchase a vehicle for Linda.Â  While negotiating for the purchase
  of a 1999 Chrysler Sebring convertible with the Dealershipâ€™s salesman, it was
  brought to Linda and Beatriceâ€™s attention that they would receive a more
  favorable interest rate on their loan if the vehicle was purchased in
  Beatriceâ€™s name as opposed to Lindaâ€™s name. Â Accordingly, Beatrice
  agreed to allow the vehicle to be purchased under her name and signed a retail
  installment contract and security agreement with the financing company, Firstar
  Financial Services (Firstar), for the financing of the vehicle.[1]Â  The amount financed was $15,751.49
  and monthly payments on the loan came to $334.09.Â  Each of the first 41 monthly
  payments included $29.00 to pay for credit life and disability insurance, which
  Linda testified the Dealership required in order for the sale to be completed
  in Beatriceâ€™s name.Â  The total cost of the proposed insurance coverage came to
  $1,543.49. 
On June
  1, 2003, Beatrice, at age eighty-one, passed away.Â  After her motherâ€™s death,
  Linda stopped making the payments on the note under the assumption that the
  credit life insurance would apply and pay off the note.Â  Upon discovering that
  the note had not been paid, Linda contacted the Dealership which, after
  numerous attempts to justify the misapplication of the premiums, eventually informed
  her that Beatrice had been too old to qualify for the insurance; the Dealership
  proceeded as if the coverage had never been purchased. Â The Dealership
  thereafter refunded the insurance premiums plus 6% interest from the date of
  the sale to the Estate.Â  However, at this point, the note was past due and the
  vehicle had been repossessed. 
The
  only beneficiaries under Beatriceâ€™s last will and testament were Lindaâ€™s
  daughter, Deborah S. Carr, and Lindaâ€™s sister, Beatrice Sue Bolton (Mrs.
  Bolton).Â  Mrs. Bolton was the personal representative for the Estate.Â  She
  filed the original inventory and appraisement on February 3, 2005, without
  mention of the 1999 Sebring as an asset of the Estate, the potential civil
  claim against the Dealership, or the debt owed to Firstar/US Bank.Â  Mrs. Bolton
  reopened the Estate in August of 2006, after this claim was filed, to account for
  the action against the Dealership.Â  
The Estate
  filed a Summons and Complaint on January 18, 2005, alleging breach of contract,
  conversion, negligence, violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices
  Act (hereinafter SCUTPA), and violations of the Regulation of Manufacturers,
  Distributors, and Dealers Act (hereinafter Dealers Act).Â  Ultimately, the case
  was called for trial before a jury on February 5, 2007, in the Newberry County
  Court of Common Pleas.Â  At the close of all evidence, the trial court granted the
  Dealershipâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  The trial judge stated â€œthereâ€™s no
  evidence that the Estate has suffered any loss or has been damaged in any way
  on the specific causes. . . . I also find thereâ€™s insufficient evidence to show
  a violation of the Dealers Act . . . and the same thing with unfair trade practice.â€Â 
  This ruling on the record was solemnized by a written form order stating â€œCourt
  Directed Verdict Against Plaintiff.â€Â  The Estate thereafter filed and served
  this notice of appeal on February 26, 2007.
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
In
  ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the trial court is required to view
  the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the
  light most favorable to the party opposing the motion and to deny the motion
  when either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in
  doubt.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642,
  648 (2006); Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231,
  236 (2002).Â  However, this rule does not authorize submission of speculative,
  theoretical, or hypothetical views to the jury.Â  Proctor v. Depâ€™t of Health
    & Envtl. Control, 368 S.C. 279, 292-93, 628 S.E.2d 496, 503 (Ct. App.
  2006).Â  In essence, the court must determine whether a verdict for the opposing
  party would be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in
  his or her favor.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 309, 566
  S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002); Proctor at 293, 628 S.E.2d at 503.Â  
The
  appellate court will reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling on a directed verdict
  motion only when there is no evidence to support the ruling or when the ruling
  is controlled by an error of law.Â  Law at 434-35, 629 S.E.2d at 648.Â  When
  considering directed verdict motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate
  court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the
  testimony or evidence.Â  Erickson v. Jones St. Publishers, L.L.C., 368
  S.C. 444, 463, 629 S.E.2d 653, 663 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
First,
  the Estate argues that the trial court erred in directing a verdict since a
  motion for a directed verdict was not made by the Dealership at the close of
  the plaintiffâ€™s case.Â  We disagree.
The Estate
  claims that because the Dealership only made a motion to dismiss at the close
  of the plaintiffâ€™s case, it could not subsequently make a motion for a directed
  verdict at the close of all the evidence. Â The Estate is mischaracterizing the
  motions made by the Dealership.Â  At the close of the plaintiffâ€™s case, the
  Dealership did make a motion to dismiss challenging the Estateâ€™s existence at
  the time the suit was filed.Â  However, immediately thereafter, the Dealership
  asserted its directed verdict motion as to each of the causes of action.Â  The trial
  court entertained the request as a directed verdict motion, despite not
  initially being mentioned by name, and denied the request at that point in the
  trial.Â  At the close of all evidence, the directed verdict motion was
  revisited.Â  The Dealership appropriately referred to the motion by claiming
  entitlement to a directed verdict and the trial judge treated the motion as
  such in his order by directing a verdict against the Estate.Â  Regardless of the
  form in which the request for relief was framed, the substance of the relief
  sought is controlling.Â  Standard Federal Sav. and Loan Assâ€™n v. Mungo,
  306 S.C. 22, 26, 410 S.E.2d 18, 20 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  The record is clear that
  throughout the arguments both counsel and the trial judge understood the motion
  being entertained was a motion for a directed verdict.Â  Counsel for the
  Dealership at the close of his final argument stated: â€œwe think that weâ€™re
  entitled to a directed verdict on all causes of action for all the reasons
  stated.â€ Accordingly, the motion was properly before the court and the judge
  appropriately treated the motion as a directed verdict motion. 
In
  addition, the Estate failed to contemporaneously object to the trial court treating
  the motion as one for a directed verdict.Â  Therefore, the matter is not
  preserved for our review.Â  See In re Michael H., 360 S.C.
  540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal. Â In order to preserve
  an issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€); Lucas v. Rawl Family
    Ltd. Pâ€™ship., 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (â€œIt
  is well settled that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an
  appellate court cannot address an issue unless it was raised
  to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).
As to the
  remainder of the Estateâ€™s allegations, we must consider whether or not the Estate
  suffered any damage.Â  The trial judge based his ruling primarily on the
  conclusion that the Estate suffered no damage.Â  We respectfully find the court
  erred.Â  
We first note that it was error for the trial court to conclude
  that the Estate suffered no damage at the directed verdict stage of the trial.Â 
  â€œThe failure to list an item in the inventory of an estate is not determinative
  of the title.â€ Gibson v. Belcher, 287 S.C. 315, 318, 338 S.E.2d 330, 332
  (1985) (citing Griffith Admâ€™x. v. Miller, 285 Ky. 675, 149 S.W.2d
  11 (1941)).Â  Furthermore, the president of the Dealership admitted the
  existence of a contract between Beatrice and the Dealership.Â  Beatrice bought
  the vehicle from the Dealership by arranging for financing through Firstar.Â 
  Beatrice was therefore the legal owner of the vehicle, although Linda made
  payments on the vehicle.Â  Therefore, under these circumstances, legal title
  would remain in Beatrice but we recognize Linda may arguably have a legal or
  equitable claim because of any payments made.Â  
Since
  Beatrice was the legal owner of the vehicle, her interest passes to her estate
  upon her demise.Â  â€œIt has long been the law in South Carolina that upon the
  testatorâ€™s death, title to the personal property vests in the executor.â€ Belcher,
  287 S.C. at 318, 338 S.E.2d at 332 (citing Lenoir v. Sylvester, 1 Bail.
  632, 17 S.C.L. 632 (1830)).[2]Â 
  Therefore, we find the Estate would have benefitted had the insurance been
  obtained and the policy paid, thereby preventing the repossession of the
  vehicle.Â  The loan in Beatriceâ€™s name would have been paid off by those
  proceeds as an obvious benefit to the Estate in its entirety. Â The Estateâ€™s
  legal title would only be subject to Lindaâ€™s equitable or legal interest at
  that point as opposed to also being subject to Firstar/U.S. Bankâ€™s security
  interest.Â Â Â  
Moreover,
  we find that whether the Dealership is liable for any alleged insurance
  coverage is a question for the jury.Â  If the jury were to find such liability,
  that coverage would be an asset of the Estate.Â  See Moultis v. Degen,
  279 S.C. 1, 7, 301 S.E.2d 554, 558 (1983) (citing In re Miles Estate,
  262 N.C. 647, 138 S.E.2d 487 (1964) (holding that an undistributed insurance
  policy is an asset of the estate)).Â  There is sufficient evidence in the record
  to support the claim that the Dealership was obtaining insurance for Beatrice.Â 
  Generally, one who pays insurance premiums is justified in assuming that
  payment will bring immediate protection.Â  Crossley v. State Farm Mut. Auto.
    Ins. Co., 307 S.C. 354, 357, 415 S.E.2d 393, 395 (1992).Â  In the case at
  hand, the insurance premium was paid up front through its inclusion in the
  financing arrangement thereby evidencing an insurance agreement between the
  parties; however, we also recognize the existence of contrary contractual
  language yet cannot resolve these conflicts at the directed verdict stage. The
  terms of the contract included the offer to secure credit life and disability
  coverage in exchange for the payment of the premium.Â  The premiums were
  admittedly received and misapplied. Â While the Dealership argues that it is not
  an insurance provider and that it was only offering to obtain quotes for Beatrice,
  it nonetheless accepted and retained payments for insurance coverage it never
  obtained for an extensive period of time.Â  The acceptance of these payments at
  a minimum presents a question as to the existence of a contract as well as a
  question as to the Dealershipâ€™s liability for said coverage.Â  
Having
  established that the Estate suffered damage, we now turn to the remainder of
  the Estateâ€™s allegations.Â  First, as to the breach of contract claim, there is
  sufficient evidence as to the existence of a contract and its breach by the
  Dealership.Â  Further, sufficient evidence exists in the record for a jury to
  conclude that the Estate, as legal owner of the automobile, was damaged by the
  breach of that contract.Â  Second, the Dealership admitted to accepting and
  retaining the insurance premiums for its own benefit, thereby creating at least
  an inference that the funds were improperly converted, although eventually
  returned.Â  Third, as to the negligence cause of action, due to the nature of the
  relationship between the Dealership and Beatrice, the Dealership had a duty to
  properly utilize the insurance premiums paid to obtain the proper insurance
  coverage; otherwise, at a minimum, the Dealership should have indicated that
  coverage was not obtained.Â  Sufficient evidence exists in the record that such
  duty was breached and that the breach proximately injured the Estate, thereby warranting
  the submission of the claim to the jury.Â  The mere fact the Dealership
  subsequently realized its error and refunded the alleged premiums is not dispositive
  as to whether the Estateâ€™s claims may proceed.
Accordingly, we respectfully find the court erred in directing a
  verdict as to the causes of action for breach of contract, conversion, and
  negligence.
The Estate next asserts that the court erred in directing a
  verdict on its cause of action for a violation of the Dealers Act.Â  The Dealers
  Act declares certain unfair methods of competition and unfair or deceptive acts
  or practices to be unlawful. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-15-30(a) (2006). Â It is a
  violation of the Dealers Act for any manufacturer or motor vehicle dealer â€œto
  engage in any action which is arbitrary, in bad faith, or unconscionable and
  which causes damage to any of the parties or to the public.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  56-15-40(1) (2006).
Our supreme court has defined the term â€œarbitraryâ€ for purposes of
  the Dealers Act to include â€œacts which are unreasonable, capricious or
  nonrational; not done according to reason or judgment; depending on will
  alone.â€ Taylor v. Nix, 307 S.C. 551, 555, 416 S.E.2d 619,
  621 (1992). Furthermore, our supreme court has defined bad faith as:

	The opposite of good faith, generally
  implying or involving actual or constructive fraud, or a design to deceive or
  mislead another, or a neglect or refusal to [fulfill] some duty or some
  contractual obligation, not prompted by an honest mistake as to oneâ€™s rights or
  duties, but by some interested or sinister motive.

State v.
  Griffin, 100 S.C. 331, 333, 84 S.E. 876, 877
  (1915) (quoting Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary).
â€œThe Dealers Act defines â€˜fraudâ€™ to include its â€˜normal legal
  connotationâ€™ as well as â€˜misrepresentation in any manner, whether
  intentionally false or due to gross negligence, of a material fact; a promise
  or representation not made honestly and in good faith; and an intentional
  failure to disclose a material fact.â€™â€ deBondt v. Carlton Motorcars, Inc.,
  342 S.C. 254, 263-64, 536 S.E.2d 399, 404 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 56-15-10(m) (1991)).
To be liable under the Dealers Act, the
  dealer must participate in the wrongful conduct. Â Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 302, 486 S.E.2d 750, 756 (1997). â€œAn agent for an entity who
  makes misrepresentations while attempting to sell a motor vehicle qualifies as
  a dealer who may be held liable under this act.â€ Id. at 302, 486 S.E.2d
  at 756.Â  The record contains evidence of misrepresentations by the Dealership.Â 
  Whether intentional or not, the president of the Dealership admitted to
  unintentionally offering numerous misleading explanations regarding the
  ultimate disposition of the insurance premiums.Â  These misrepresentations constitute
  a sufficient basis to submit the violation of the Dealers Act cause of action to
  the jury.Â  Accordingly, the trial court erred in granting a directed verdict on
  this cause of action.
Finally, the Estate claims the trial court
  erred in directing a verdict on its SCUTPA cause of action.Â  To recover in an
  action under the SCUTPA, the plaintiff must show: (1) the defendant engaged in
  an unfair or deceptive act in the conduct of trade or commerce; (2) the unfair
  or deceptive act affected the public interest; and (3) the plaintiff suffered
  monetary or property loss as a result of the defendantâ€™s unfair or deceptive
  act(s). Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-10-560 (Supp. 2007).Â  The second element may be
  satisfied by proof of â€œfacts demonstrating
  the potential for repetition of the defendantâ€™s actions.â€ Daisy Outdoor
    Adver. Co., Inc. v. Abbott, 322 S.C. 489, 493, 473 S.E.2d 47, 49
  (1996). Â â€œPlaintiffs . . . generally have shown potential for repetition in two
  ways: (1) by showing the same kind of actions occurred in the past, thus making
  it likely they will continue to occur absent deterrence . . . or (2) by showing
  the companyâ€™s procedures create a potential for repetition of the unfair and
  deceptive acts.â€ Id. at 496, 473 S.E.2d at 51 (citations omitted).Â  
Sufficient evidence exists in the record for submission of this
  cause of action to the jury.Â  The first and third elements of the cause of
  action are sufficiently supported by the evidence for submission to the jury
  for reasons similar to those as necessary for submission of the Dealers Act
  claim.Â  The public interest element necessitates additional scrutiny. Â The Estate,
  while questioning the president of the Dealership, specifically inquired about
  the existence of safeguards to ensure that unapplied premiums would be
  refunded.Â  While the response to the question was unclear, an inference could
  be made that the Dealership lacked internal protections to prevent the
  reoccurrence of this conduct in the future.Â  The conduct complained of herein
  continued for approximately three years without action.[3]Â  Therefore, there is some evidence
  relating to the potential for public harm which justifies the submission of the
  SCUTPA claim to the jury.Â  Accordingly, the trial court erred by directing a
  verdict against the Estate as to the SCUTPA cause of action.
CONCLUSION
For the aforementioned reasons, the order
  of the trial court directing a verdict against the Estate is hereby
REVERSED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and CURETON, A.J. concur.


[1] Firstar subsequently sold the note to U.S. Bank.
[2] This concept is currently codified in section
  62-3-101 which states that a decedentâ€™s personal property â€œdevolves, first, to
  his personal representative.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-101 (Supp. 2007). 
[3] As to SCUTPA, counsel specifically asked whether
  other customers could have been similarly overcharged.Â  The question was never
  answered even after an objection to the question was successfully overruled.Â
