title: Tobias v. Rice
description: Ruby Rice (Rice) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order denying her motion to alter, amend, or vacate the judgment against her.  Rice also appeals the entry of judgment in favor of William and Elena Tobias (William and Elena).  We affirm.
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				William and
      Elena Tobias, Respondents,
				v.
				Ruby Rice, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4411 
Heard March 6, 2008 â€“ Filed June 10, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Michael F. Talley, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				AdamÂ  Fisher, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondent(s).
			
		
	

PIEPER, J.: Â Ruby Rice (Rice) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order denying her
  motion to alter, amend, or vacate the judgment against her.Â  Rice also appeals
  the entry of judgment in favor of William and Elena Tobias (William and Elena).Â 
  We affirm.
FACTS
William and Elena filed the underlying complaint in
  this case on May 7, 2004.Â  In their complaint, they allege the following four
  causes of action: (1) breach of contract; (2) conversion; (3) unjust
  enrichment; and (4) specific performance.Â  The allegations arose from two lease
  agreements and an alleged oral purchase contract between William and Elena and Rice
  for a number of residential apartments in two separate apartment buildings in Greenville,   S.C., one on Haughty Court and one on Summit Place.Â  The lease agreements
  were structured such that William and Elena would be responsible for
  maintaining the apartments, collecting rent, finding tenants, and generally
  managing the properties in return for below market value rental payments for
  those properties.Â  These lease agreements allowed William and Elena to sublet
  the apartments for a greater amount of rent than they were obligated to pay Rice,
  thereby creating a profit margin.Â  In addition, William and Elena allege that
  they had an oral option to purchase the above-referenced properties from Rice
  for a purchase price of $144,000.00 for the Haughty Court property and
  $288,000.00 for the Summit Place property.Â  
William and Elena further
  assert that Rice violated her duties under the contracts by unilaterally
  cancelling the lease agreements and excluding William and Elena from these
  rental properties once they had successfully subleased each of the individual
  units to tenants.Â  They claim that in reliance on their option to purchase the
  buildings, they expended some $68,000.00 in improving the properties.Â  In order
  to be compensated, William and Elena also seek specific performance on the oral
  option contract. 
In her answer, Rice
  admits the existence of one of the lease agreements, but specifically denies
  the existence of any lease agreement on the Summit place property or the
  existence of any option or purchase agreement on either property.Â  Furthermore,
  Rice alleges that William and Elena defaulted under the lease provisions and
  were excluded properly from the properties pursuant to magistrate court
  procedures. 
The procedural history of this case is important since
  it is the foundation of the motion to vacate and/or set aside the judgment.Â 
  Following the May 7, 2004, filing of the complaint, Rice hired attorney Rodman
  Tullis to represent her.Â  Communication problems existed from the outset of
  their attorney-client relationship and as a result, both Rice and her counsel
  filed a separate answer and counterclaim on Riceâ€™s behalf on August 3, 2004.Â 
  However, throughout these proceedings, Mr. Tullis was listed as Riceâ€™s attorney
  of record with the clerk of court.
William and Elena's
  trial counsel, Randall Hiller, Esquire, indicated to the court that in order to
  obtain discovery, multiple unsuccessful attempts were made to contact attorney Tullis.Â  As a result, he filed a motion to compel which was granted by the
  Honorable D. Garrison Hill by order dated April 26, 2005.Â  Judge Hillâ€™s order
  indicates that neither Rice nor her counsel appeared at the motion hearing.Â 
  Judge Hill further found the record reflected that interrogatories were served
  and had gone unanswered.Â  He then ordered Rice to respond to discovery requests
  within thirty (30) days from the date of service of that order, and in the
  event of noncompliance, Riceâ€™s answer and counterclaim would be dismissed with
  prejudice.Â  Judge Hill, aware of potential communication problems between Rice
  and her attorney, directed attorney Hiller to serve a copy of his order on both
  attorney Tullis and Rice individually. 
Rice was served
  with that order in June 2005; since she was unable to get in touch with Mr. Tullis, Rice contacted attorney J. Patricia Anderson, Esquire, who called
  attorney Hillerâ€™s office requesting a thirty day extension to answer the
  complaint.Â  Attorney Hiller ultimately denied the request pursuant to a
  facsimile letter advising Anderson that the relevant deadline pertained to
  discovery responses and that he was unwilling to grant an extension to that
  deadline.Â  Due to the denial of the extension, Anderson did not become Riceâ€™s
  counsel of record.Â  There was no further communication from Anderson to
  attorney Hiller, nor from any other attorney representing Rice.
The case then
  appeared on the Greenville County non-jury docket for the week of November 7,
  2005, with a mandatory roster meeting scheduled that same day before the Honorable
  John C. Few.Â  Attorney Hiller appeared on behalf of William and Elena but no
  one was present for Rice.Â  The matter was set to be tried the following day.
The trial took
  place on November 8, 2005, at which time Judge Few was made aware of the
  inattentive manner in which attorney Tullis had represented his client in these
  proceedings.Â  However, the trial commenced in Riceâ€™s absence.Â  Judgment was
  entered by order dated November 24, 2005, wherein William and Elena were
  granted judgment in the amount of $211,700.00 with interest thereon at 8.75%
  from April, 2004, to the date of the order and at the judgment rate
  thereafter.Â  Judge Few further ordered Rice to attend a closing for the sale of
  the two above-referenced properties to William and Elena for a total sales price
  of $432,000.00, from which William and Elena would be entitled to offset
  against the purchase price the amount of the judgment obtained. 
Rice was served
  with Judge Fewâ€™s order on December 1, 2005, and filed a motion to reconsider
  claiming that her attorney was disbarred and failed to inform her of the
  commencement of the trial proceedings.Â  She hired Michael Talley to represent
  her.Â  Attorney Talley filed a motion to vacate and/or set aside the judgment on
  January 20, 2006.Â  Judge Few entertained Mr. Talleyâ€™s motion (not the pro se
  motion) to vacate at a hearing on January 3, 2007, and denied that motion by
  form order the same day.Â  Rice now appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of the
  motion to vacate and/or set aside the judgment against her.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Whether to grant or
  deny a motion under Rule 60(b) lies within the sound discretion of the judge.Â  Raby
    Constr., L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 17-18, 594 S.E.2d 478, 482 (2004).Â  An
  appellate courtâ€™s standard of review, therefore, is limited to determining
  whether there was an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  Relief under Rule
  60(b)(1), SCRCP, lies within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will
  not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Paul Davis Sys.,
    Inc. v. Deepwater of Hilton Head, LLC, 362 S.C. 220, 225, 607 S.E.2d 358,
  360 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An abuse of discretion arises where the order was
  controlled by an error of law or where the order is based on factual
  conclusions that are without evidentiary support. Tri-County Ice & Fuel
    Co. v. Palmetto Ice Co., 303 S.C. 237, 242, 399 S.E.2d 779, 782
  (1990).
ANALYSIS
Riceâ€™s first three issues on appeal pertain to issues
  of notice and depend on whether there was a default judgment damages hearing or
  a trial.Â  Each of Riceâ€™s first three grounds for appeal attempt to place some
  affirmative duty on William and Elena to give Rice notice of the trial.Â 
  Pursuant to Rule 55(b), SCRCP, a party seeking a default judgment not involving
  liquidated damages must provide three days notice to the opposing side;
  however, this requirement would only be applicable in the case at hand if William
  and Elena actually sought a default judgment.Â  
A
  similar situation was dealt with by this court in Goodson v. Am. Bankers
    Ins. Co. of Fla., 295 S.C. 400, 368 S.E.2d 687 (1988).Â  In the concurrence
  portion of Judge Curetonâ€™s opinion in Goodson, he articulately points
  out that the defendant was not in default for failing to appear at trial when
  it had filed an answer, where there had been no application for default, and
  where default had not been entered by the clerk. Â Id. at 403, 368 S.E.2d at 690.Â  Recently, this court again relying on
  similar logic reached the same conclusion.Â  In RRR, Inc. v. Toggas, Op.
  No. 4375 (S.C. Ct. App. filed April 23, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 16 at 97), this court held that where the
  plaintiff did not seek or file for a default judgment but instead proceeded to
  a judgment on the merits, the notice prescribed in Rule 55(b)(2) is
  inapplicable.Â  
In the case herein, Rice had answered and filed a counterclaim; no
  application for default was ever made, and no default was ever entered by the
  clerk.Â  While Rice argues that Judge Hillâ€™s order states that the failure to
  answer interrogatories will result in her answer and counterclaim being
  dismissed with prejudice, that order was not automatically effective and there
  was never a motion made to enforce that order.Â  We cannot assume an order of
  the type at issue would be automatically effective when the court would only be
  aware of the failure to comply with the order pursuant to some application by
  the movant to enforce that order.Â  Absent any such motion to enforce the
  courtâ€™s order, compliance is presumed under these circumstances.Â  Accordingly,
  not only was Riceâ€™s answer and counterclaim not dismissed, it was referred to
  and considered by the judge at trial.Â  Therefore, this court will not
  treat the trial as a default judgment hearing; as a result, the notice
  provision in Rule 55(b)(2) is inapplicable.
Despite the fact that Riceâ€™s primary argument on appeal is that William
  and Elena should have provided her notice, we do find the overall situation
  troubling, especially as it pertains to the adequacy of trial notice given to Rice.Â 
  As evidenced by the record, Riceâ€™s counsel of record, Mr. Tullis, was mailed
  and faxed notice of the mandatory roster meeting, thereby providing adequate
  notice of trial.Â  On the other hand, it is undisputed that Mr. Tullis was
  providing inadequate representation to Rice throughout the circuit court
  proceedings.Â  Mr. Tullis had some disciplinary history which ultimately
  culminated in his disbarment in 2007 and included a suspension in 2005 for
  failure to comply with CLE requirements and failure to pay bar dues.[1]Â  
The general rule is that the neglect of an attorney will be
  imputed to the client preventing the client from using the attorneyâ€™s neglect
  as a ground for relief in a later motion to vacate.Â  Mitchell Supply Co. v.
    Gaffney, 297 S.C. 160, 163-64, 375 S.E.2d 321, 323 (Ct. App. 1988).Â 
  However, â€œthis is not a hard and fast rule.Â  Rather, it
  is one that is â€˜to be applied rationally, with a fair recognition that justice
  to the litigants is always the polestar.â€â€™ Brown v. Butler, 347 S.C.
  259, 554 S.E.2d 431 (App. Ct. 2001) (quoting 7A C.J.S. Attorney & Client Â§ 181, at 284 (1980)).Â  Furthermore, this general rule is not always applicable
  when the attorneyâ€™s neglect rises to the level of willful abandonment.Â  Graham
    v. Town of Loris, 272 S.C. 442, 452, 248 S.E.2d 594, 599 (1978); see also 7A C.J.S. Attorney & Client Â§ 181, at 285 (1980) (where
  the conduct of counsel is outrageously in violation of his implicit duty to
  devote reasonable efforts in representing his client, his acts will not always
  be imputed to his client).
Notwithstanding, Rice did not move to vacate the judgment based on
  excusable neglect by arguing that the negligence of her counsel should not be
  imputed to her due to his willful abandonment of her case, nor does she attempt
  to raise this ground on appeal.Â  While arguably one could assert that this
  ground was raised in Riceâ€™s pro se motion to reconsider, that motion was never
  ruled on by the trial court and the issue was never raised on appeal.Â  In order
  for an issue to be properly presented for appeal, Rice's brief must set forth
  the issue in the statement of issues on appeal. See Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR; Silvester v. Spring Valley Country Club, 344 S.C. 280, 285, 543 S.E.2d 563, 566 (Ct. App. 2001). Â Further, it is error
  for the appellate court to consider issues not properly raised
  to it. Â First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d
  513, 514 (1994) (stating appellant must provide authority and supporting
  arguments for his issue to be considered raised on appeal).Â  Accordingly, we may not consider this issue. 
As to the excusable neglect of Rice, the decision of the trial
  court is supported by the fact that Rice was on notice of the problems she was
  facing with her counsel of record in June 2005 at the latest, when she was
  served with Judge Hillâ€™s order.Â  While she attempted to obtain new counsel at
  one point, she was unsuccessful and made no further attempts despite knowing
  that the failure to answer the interrogatories would result in the dismissal of
  her answer and counterclaim with prejudice.Â  For almost six months she never contacted
  the clerk to ensure that she was served with all relevant notices, never
  obtained new counsel, nor moved to relieve counsel.Â  We do not find an abuse of
  the trial judgeâ€™s discretion in his apparent reliance on the proposition that
  â€œa party has a duty to monitor the progress of his case.â€Â  Hill v. Dotts,
  345 S.C. 304, 310, 547 S.E.2d 894, 897 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Goodson v.
    Am. Bankers Ins. Co., 295 S.C. 400, 403, 368 S.E.2d 687, 689 (Ct. App.
  1988).Â  Rice was aware of her dire legal situation for at least six months, and
  we find no abuse of discretion in refusing to grant her relief based on her own
  negligence as opposed to excusable neglect for her attorneyâ€™s negligence, which
  has not been raised on appeal.
Rice also asserts the trial court should have set aside its
  judgment because the grant of specific performance absent a written contract
  violates the statute of frauds.Â  This issue was not raised at trial and was
  only raised to the trial judge in the context of a meritorious defense, one of
  the factors considered by the trial court when ruling on a Rule 60, SCRCP
  motion.Â  See Hill, 345 S.C. at 309, 547 S.E.2d at 897.Â 
  Therefore, it is only proper for this court to consider this issue in that
  context. Â 
A court may relieve a party from a final judgment for mistake,
  inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect. Â Rule 60(b)(1),
  SCRCP. In determining whether a default judgment should be set aside under Rule 60(b)(1), â€œ[t]he promptness with which relief is
  sought, the reasons for the failure to act promptly, the existence of [a] meritorious defense, and the prejudice
  to the other parties are relevant.â€ N.H. Ins. Co. v. Bey Corp., 312 S.C. 47, 50, 435 S.E.2d 377, 379 (Ct. App. 1993) (quoting Harry M. Lightsey
  & James F. Flanagan, South
    Carolina Civil Procedure 82 (1985)).Â  The alleged violation of the statute
  of frauds, if true, would amount to a mistake of law, not a mistake of fact.Â 
  Accordingly, the issue is not persuasive since a party may not generally use
  Rule 60(b)(1) as a vehicle for relief from a mistake of law.Â  Hillman v.
    Pinion, 347 S.C. 253, 256, 554 S.E.2d 427, 429 (Ct. App. 2001); see also Binkley v. Rabon Creek Watershed Conserv., 348 S.C. 58, 76 n.37 , 558
  S.E.2d 902, 911 n.37 (Ct. App. 2001) (Relief from a judgment under Rule 60 is
  not a substitute for appeal).Â  While we may not agree with the trial judge's
  rulings on the application of the law at trial, because we find no abuse of
  discretion by the trial court as to excusable neglect, the mere allegation that
  the trial judge made a mistake of law on the merits is not properly presented
  for the first time in a Rule 60 motion and is insufficient by itself as
  presented to warrant reversal.Â  Since this appeal is postured on grounds solely
  related to the denial of the Rule 60 motion, as opposed to a direct appeal of
  the rulings outside of the Rule 60 context, we find no reversible error.[2]Â  
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] See In the Matter of Rodman C. Tullis,
  Op. No. 26383 (S.C. Sup. Ct. Oct. 8, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 36 at 15).
[2] This case has a somewhat strained procedural
  history.Â  Rice actually filed a pro se notice of appeal in 2005 with the court
  of common pleas.Â  However, that notice was not filed with the court of appeals.
  Therefore, a direct review on the merits of the trial has not been preserved.Â 
  After Judge Few denied the Rule 60 motion, Riceâ€™s counsel filed a timely notice
  of appeal in January 2007 relating solely to the Rule 60 denial.Â  Accordingly,
  our review is limited solely to the Rule 60 proceeding.

title: State v. Williams
description: Christopher Williams appeals his convictions, arguing the trial court committed reversible error in sustaining the State's Batson motion and thereafter allowing a challenged juror to sit on the new jury.
text:
<!--

font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Christopher
          Williams, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
  Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 4412
Heard May 7, 2008 â€“ Filed June 12, 2008Â Â Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for
          Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
          and Assistant Attorney General Julie M. Thames, all of Columbia; and Solicitor
          David Michael Pascoe, Jr., of Orangeburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Christopher Williams was convicted of two
  counts of assault of a high and aggravated nature (AHAN), one count of
  attempted escape, and two counts of kidnapping.Â  He was sentenced to two
  concurrent terms of ten years in prison for AHAN, a consecutive term of fifteen
  years in prison for attempted escape, and two concurrent terms of life in
  prison without parole for the kidnappings.Â  Williams appeals, contending the
  trial court committed reversible error by sustaining the Stateâ€™s Batson[1] motion and thereafter mandating that a challenged juror be seated on the new
  jury.Â  We reverse and remand.
I.
The
  Stateâ€™s Batson motion began with a challenge to all of Williamsâ€™ peremptory
  challenges.Â  Rather than requiring the State to be more specific, the court
  required Williams to account for all strikes.Â  Williams did so, and the inquiry
  narrowed to three potential jurors.Â  The court granted the Stateâ€™s Batson motion regarding the three jurors.Â  The court precluded Williams from striking
  any of the three jurors (Jurors 78, 72 and 116) when the jury was redrawn.Â 
  Because only Juror 78 was called and served on the jury that convicted Williams,
  the appeal is limited to Juror 78.
Williamsâ€™
  counsel said he struck Juror 78, a white male, â€œbecause his wife is unemployedâ€
  and he â€œusually like[d] to have jurors that consider their spouse somewhat
  equal and they both work.â€Â  The State contended the reason was pretextual
  because Williamsâ€™ counsel sat Juror 81, also a white male, who is unemployed.Â  Williamsâ€™
  counsel maintained that there is a fundamental difference between a juror who
  is unemployed and a juror whose spouse is unemployed.Â  Williamsâ€™ counsel
  stated:

  
    And
      as far as I struck [Juror 78] because his wife was unemployed, and he said I
      sat somebody who was unemployed.Â  Thereâ€™s a difference between a juror being
      unemployed and a jurorâ€™s wife being unemployed, and thatâ€™s where I make my
      difference, Your Honor.Â  
  

The
  State then turned its argument to, â€œHow is that any different from every juror
  thatâ€™s a single juror then?â€Â  Williamsâ€™ counsel reiterated his distinction
  between jurors who are unemployed and spouses of jurors who are unemployed.Â 
  Concerning unmarried jurors, defense counsel asserted that â€œevery juror thatâ€™s
  single wouldnâ€™t be sitting here thinking how much money is my unemployed wife
  at home spending . . . .Â  Thereâ€™s a big difference between a single juror and a
  married juror.â€Â  
Without
  further discussion, the trial court granted the Stateâ€™s Batson motion,
  observing that, in connection with Juror 78, â€œsomeone similarly situated was
  seated of a different race.â€ Â Williams claims the trial court erred in both of
  its stated reasons.Â  First, according to Williams, the other juror (Juror 81)
  may not properly be considered â€œsimilarly situated,â€ as Williams repeatedly
  emphasized to the trial court his distinction between an unemployed juror and
  an employed juror whose spouse is unemployed.Â  Second, the other juror, Juror
  81, is white (as is Juror 78) and therefore not of a â€œdifferent raceâ€ from
  Juror 78.Â  We agree with Williams on both counts, and as a result, we reverse
  and remand for a new trial.
II.
If a
  trial court improperly grants the Stateâ€™s Batson motion, but none of the
  disputed jurors thereafter serve on the jury, any error in improperly quashing
  the jury is harmless because a defendant is not entitled to a particular jury.Â  State v. Rayfield, 369 S.C. 106, 631 S.E.2d 244 (2006).Â  Conversely, if
  one of the jurors is thereafter seated on the jury, then the erroneous Batson ruling has tainted the jury and prejudice is presumed in such cases â€œbecause
  there is no way to determine with any degree of certainty whether a defendantâ€™s
  right to a fair trial by an impartial jury was abridged.â€Â  Id. at 114,
  631 S.E.2d at 248; see also State v. Short, 327 S.C. 329, 489
  S.E.2d 209 (Ct. App. 1997) (finding the remedy for the improper granting of a Batson motion where a disputed juror is seated on the new jury is a new trial).
Even in light of the deference given trial judges in Batson motions, we are persuaded that error has been established in this case.Â  The
  State, in its brief, acknowledges that Williams â€œoffered race-neutral reasons
  for his strikes.â€Â  We agree that Williams offered a race-neutral reason for
  striking Juror 78.Â  The State has no good answer for the trial courtâ€™s clearly
  erroneous statement that â€œsomeone similarly situated [Juror 81] was seated of a
  different race.â€Â  The State suggests the trial court really meant to say that
  the strike â€œwas so fundamentally implausible [as] to not require disparate
  treatment.â€Â  Â Â 
We
  reject the Stateâ€™s efforts to rescue the trial courtâ€™s erroneous Batson ruling,
  and we decline the invitation to recast the trial courtâ€™s ruling to something
  it was not.Â  In any event, we do not view as â€œfundamentally implausibleâ€ the
  idea that counsel may draw a distinction between the employment status of a
  prospective juror and the employment status of the spouse of a prospective
  juror.[2]Â 
  More to the point, employment, or lack of it, is a well-understood and
  recognized consideration in the exercise of peremptory challenges.Â  State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 632, 515 S.E.2d 88, 92 (1999) (stating unemployment is
  a race-neutral reason for a strike); State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 59, 65, 512
  S.E.2d 500, 504 (1999) (holding place of employment is a race-neutral reason
  for a strike); see State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 125, 470 S.E.2d
  366, 372 (1996) (finding type of employment is a race-neutral reason for a
  strike).Â  And finally, there is no evidence that someone similarly situated to
  Juror 78 was seated, i.e., no other juror was seated whose spouse was
  unemployed.
III.
In
  sum, Williams articulated a race-neutral reason for striking Juror 78, and the
  State failed to establish that a similarly situated juror was seated.Â  The
  proper remedy is a new trial.
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED.
ANDERSON AND
  HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).
[2]Â  See State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 629, 515
  S.E.2d 88, 91 (1999) (â€œPretext generally will be established by showing
  that similarly situated members of another race were seated on the jury.Â 
  Under some circumstances, the race-neutral explanation given by the proponent
  may be so fundamentally implausible that the judge may determine, at the third
  step of the analysis, that the explanation was mere pretext even without a
  showing of disparate treatment.â€) (emphasis added).Â  As noted, Jurors 78 and 81
  are both white and they are not â€œsimilarly situated,â€ as Juror 81 is unemployed
and the spouse of Juror 78 is unemployed.Â Â Â

title: Snavely v. AMISUB of South Carolina, Inc.
description: In this action for breach of patient-physician confidentiality, Lisa Snavely appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of Piedmont Medical Centerâ€™s motion for summary judgment and Dr. Zellnerâ€™s motion to dismiss.  We affirm.
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Lisa Snavely, Appellant,
        v.
        AMISUB of South
          Carolina, Inc., d/b/a Piedmont Medical Center, Tenet Healthcare Corporation,
          Tenet South Carolina, Inc., and Eric Eugene Zellner, M.D., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge
  Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Special Circuit
Court Judge

Opinion No. 4413
  Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 12,
2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Nekki Shutt and Mary Dameron Milliken, both of Columbia, for
          Appellant.
        William B. Darwin, of Spartanburg, H. Spencer King and Jason M.
          Imhoff, of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
      
    
  

THOMAS, J.:Â  In
  this action for breach of patient-physician confidentiality, Lisa Snavely
  appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of Piedmont Medical Centerâ€™s (Piedmont) motion
  for summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
On
  January 20, 2003, Carol Brooks, Snavelyâ€™s sister-in-law, drove Snavely to the
  emergency room of Piedmont because Snavely was complaining of weakness,
  jaundice, and abdominal pain.[2]Â 
  Per Snavelyâ€™s request, Mrs. Brooks accompanied her to a private examination
  room.Â  Dr. Zellner, an emergency room physician working at Piedmont, examined
  Snavely in Mrs. Brooksâ€™ presence and questioned Snavely regarding her
  symptoms.Â  After completing the examination and reviewing Snavelyâ€™s medical
  history, Dr. Zellner informed Snavely â€œshe had likely contracted some form of
  hepatitis.â€Â  To confirm his diagnosis, Dr. Zellner ordered Snavely undergo
  â€œblood work and an ultrasound.â€Â  Shortly thereafter, Snavelyâ€™s brother, James
  Brooks, arrived at Piedmont and joined Snavely in the examination room[3] where Mrs. Brooks informed him of Dr. Zellnerâ€™s preliminary diagnosis. 
After
  obtaining the results of Snavelyâ€™s blood tests, Dr. Zellner returned to the
  examination room and confirmed to Mr. and Mrs. Brooks the diagnosis of
  hepatitis.Â  Dr. Zellner also indicated he would refer Snavely to a specialist
  to determine the type of hepatitis she had contracted.Â  The next day, the Brookses
  accompanied Snavely to the office of Dr. Debra Gazzuolo.Â  After completing a
  physical examination and reviewing Snavelyâ€™s test results, Dr. Gazzuolo
  informed Snavely she contracted Hepatitis B.Â  Dr. Gazzuolo provided Snavely
  information about Hepatitis B, including a pamphlet explaining the nature of
  the disease and methods to avoid transmitting it to others.Â  Snavely then
  shared this diagnosis with the Brookses, and allowed them to review the
  information Dr. Gazzuolo provided.Â  Subsequently, either Mr. or Mrs. Brooks
  disclosed Snavelyâ€™s condition to her employer, a local restaurant, and she was
  fired.[4]Â  
Following
  her termination, Snavely filed an action against Piedmont and Dr. Zellner for
  breach of patient-physician confidentiality.Â  Specifically, Snavely alleged Dr.
  Zellner unlawfully disclosed her medical condition to the Brookses, and Piedmont was responsible for any unlawful act of Dr. Zellner.Â  In response, Piedmont filed a motion for summary judgment asserting Snavely consented to the disclosure
  of her condition by allowing the Brookses to remain in the examination room at
  the time Dr. Zellner delivered his diagnosis.Â  At the motion for summary
  judgment hearing, the trial court ruled in favor of Piedmont finding:

  
    [Snavely]
        permitted Mrs. Brooks to remain in the examination room while Dr. Zellner
        performed his examination, and when he advised [Snavely] of his diagnosis.Â  By
        allowing her sister-in-law to remain in the room throughout Dr. Zellnerâ€™s
        examination, [Snavely] at least tacitly consented to disclosure of her medical
        conditions to her sister-in-law.Â  
    [Snavely]
        then allowed her brother and sister-in-law to accompany her to Dr. Gazzuoloâ€™s
        office the following day and after seeing the doctor, confirmed to the Brooks
        her specific diagnosis of Hepatitis B.Â  [Snavely] also shared a pamphlet with
        her brother and sister-in-law that discussed the disease and ways to prevent
        spreading it.Â  [Snavely] made no attempt to conceal her medical condition;
        rather, she involved her brother and sister-in-law at each stage.Â  Thus, she
        cannot complain that any negligence, assuming there was any, of Dr. Zellner
        caused her injury. 
  

Snavelyâ€™s
  Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration was denied.Â  Shortly thereafter,
  Dr. Zellner filed a motion to dismiss based upon the trial courtâ€™s grant of
  summary judgment in favor of Piedmont.Â  The trial court granted Dr. Zellnerâ€™s
  motion, concluding â€œthe issue of negligence was held to be solely that of
  [Snavely] and no one else.Â  Moreover, medical confidences were waived by
  consenting to the inclusion of family members in medical examination,
  diagnosis, and treatment.â€Â  The trial court further found the collateral
  estoppel doctrine barred Snavely from litigating her claims against Dr. Zellner.Â 
  In response to the trial courtâ€™s order of dismissal, Snavely filed another Rule
  59(e) motion, which was denied.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is
  proper where no genuine issue exists as to any material fact and the moving
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Hurst v. East Coast Hockey League, Inc., 371 S.C. 33, 36, 637 S.E.2d 560, 561
  (2006).Â  On appeal from a grant of summary judgment, the appellate court
  applies the same standard governing the trial court.Â  Id. The trial court should grant summary judgment â€œif the
  pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file,
  together with the affidavits, if any, show there is no genuine issue as to any
  material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Russell v. Wachovia Bank, N.A., 353 S.C. 208, 217, 578 S.E.2d 329,
  334 (2003) (quoting Rule 56(c), SCRCP).Â  In determining whether any
  triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law
    v. S.C. Department of Corrections, 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642,
  648 (2006). Â â€œA court considering summary judgment neither makes factual
  determinations nor considers the merits of competing testimony; however,
  summary judgment is completely appropriate when a properly supported motion
  sets forth facts that remain undisputed or are contested in a deficient manner.â€Â  David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 250, 626 S.E.2d 1,
  5 (2006). 
LAW/ANALYSIS

I. Summary Judgment
Snavely
  contends the trial court erred in granting Piedmontâ€™s motion for summary
  judgment based upon: (1) Snavelyâ€™s lack of consent to the disclosure of her
  medical condition; (2) Piedmontâ€™s contributory negligence; (3) the contradicted
  findings of fact relied upon by the trial court; (4) invasion of privacy; and
  (5) the doctrine of ostensible agency.Â  We disagree.
A.   Snavelyâ€™s Consent to
  Disclosure
Snavely
  contends the trial court erred in granting Piedmontâ€™s motion for summary
  judgment because she did not consent to the disclosure of her medical
  condition.Â  We disagree.Â  
While
  South Carolina does not recognize physician-patient testimonial privilege,[5] the law does recognize an action against a physician for the disclosure of
  confidential information, unless the disclosure is compelled by law or
  consented to by the patient.Â  McCormick v. England, 328 S.C. 627,
  635-40, 494 S.E.2d 431, 435-37 (Ct. App. 1997); see also Aakjer
    v. Spagnoli, 291 S.C. 165, 173, 352 S.E.2d 503, 508 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œThere
  is no physician-patient privilege in South Carolina.â€).Â  
In
  the present case, Snavely implicitly consented to the disclosure of her medical
  condition by involving the Brookses at every stage of her medical treatment.Â  By
  her own admission, Snavely â€œchose to take [Mrs. Brooks] backâ€ to the
  examination room and did not ask her to leave during Dr. Zellnerâ€™s examination.Â  Specifically, Snavely testified as follows:

  
    Q:
    Okay.  And you chose to take [Mrs. Brooks] back with you?
  
  
    A:
    Yes.
  
  
    Q:
    Okay.  That was your decision?
  
  
    A:
    Yes.
  
  
    Q: 
    Okay.  And you met Dr. Zellner in an examining room?
  
  
    A:
    Yes.
  
  
    Q:
    Okay.  And what occurred in the examining room?
  
  
    A: 
    [Dr. Zellner] asked me what my symptoms were.  I
  told him.  He told me that he was guessing right now with hepatitis, but not
  sure which one and that he would send me for blood work and an ultrasound. 
  

Subsequently,
  Snavely permitted the Brookses to accompany her to Dr. Gazzuoloâ€™s office where
  her diagnosis of Hepatitis B was confirmed.Â  Additionally, Snavely shared a
  pamphlet with the Brookses discussing the disease and preventive treatments.Â 
  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in granting summary based upon the finding Snavely â€œat least tacitly consentedâ€ to
  the disclosure of her medical condition.Â  
B. Contributory Negligence
Snavely
  contends the trial court erred in granting Piedmontâ€™s motion for summary
  judgment by failing to find Piedmont contributorily negligent.Â  We disagree. 
In order to establish a cause of action in negligence, a plaintiff
  must prove the following three elements: (1) a duty of care owed by defendant
  to plaintiff; (2) breach of that duty by a negligent act or omission; and (3)
  damage proximately resulting from the breach of duty.Â  Bloom v. Ravoira,
  339 S.C. 417, 422, 529 S.E.2d 710, 712 (2000).Â  â€œHowever, under South Carolinaâ€™s comparative negligence doctrine, a plaintiff may only recover damages if his own
  negligence is not greater than that of the defendant.â€Â  Id. at 422, 529
  S.E.2d 712-13.Â  Generally, a â€œcomparison of the plaintiffâ€™s negligence
  with that of the defendant is a question
  of fact for the jury to decide.â€Â  Id. at 422, 529 S.E.2d 713. Â In a
  comparative negligence case, the trial court should only determine judgment as
  a matter of law if the sole reasonable inference which may be drawn from the
  evidence is the plaintiffâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.Â  See Hopson
    v. Clary, 321 S.C. 312, 314, 468 S.E.2d 305, 307 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œIf the evidence as a whole is susceptible to only one
  reasonable inference, no jury issue is created.â€).Â  
Here,
  Snavely fails to prove any negligent act attributable to Dr. Zellner was the
  proximate cause of the disclosure of her medical condition.Â  Indeed, the record contains no evidence suggesting Dr.
  Zellner, or anyone else connected with Piedmont, disclosed her condition
  outside the examination room.Â  Furthermore, Snavely consented to the disclosure
  of her medical condition by (1) allowing the Brookses to remain in the
  examination room; (2) involving the Brookses at every stage of her medical
  treatment; (3) sharing information explaining the disease with the Brookses;
  and (4) making no attempt to conceal her condition.Â  Consequently, Snavelyâ€™s
  negligence in consenting to the disclosure of her medical condition exceeded
  any negligent act of Dr. Zellner.Â  Thus, the trial court did not err in
  granting Piedmont summary judgment based upon the doctrine of comparative
  negligence. 
C. Uncontradicted v.
  Contradicted Findings of Fact
Snavely
  alleges the trial court erroneously relied upon contradicted facts in granting Piedmontâ€™s motion for summary judgment because the record contains factual discrepancies
  regarding the disclosure of her medical condition.Â  We disagree. 
Mindful
  of the summary judgment standard of review, we note the record contains many
  facts which, even when viewed in the light most favorable to Snavely, clearly
  show Snavely at least tacitly consented to the disclosure of her medical
  condition.Â  Snavely involved the Brookses at every stage of her medical
  treatment and made no attempt to conceal her condition.Â  Consequently, any factual discrepancies
  which might exist as to Piedmontâ€™s contributory negligence cannot alter the
  inescapable conclusion Snavelyâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.Â  Under South Carolina jurisprudence, where evidence of the plaintiffâ€™s greater negligence is
  overwhelming, evidence of slight negligence on the part of the defendant is
  simply not enough for a case to go to the jury.Â  See Hopson, 321 S.C. at 314, 468 S.E.2d at 307.Â  Therefore, we find the trial court did not err in granting
  summary judgment. 
D. Publication
Lastly,
  Snavely argues the trial court erred in granting Piedmont summary judgment
  because the publication of her medical condition to the Brookses amounts to an
  invasion of privacy.Â  We disagree. 

  Invasion of privacy consists of the public disclosure of private
    facts about the plaintiff, and the gravamen of the tort is publicity as opposed to mere publication.Â  The defendant must intentionally reveal facts
    which are of no legitimate public interest, as there is no right of privacy in
    public matters.Â  In addition, the disclosure must be such as would be highly
    offensive and likely to cause serious mental injury to a person of ordinary
    sensibilities. 

McCormick, 328 S.C. at 640, 494 S.E.2d at 437-38 (emphasis
  added).
â€œPublicity involves disclosure to the public, not just an
  individual or a small group.â€Â  Id. at 641, 494 S.E.2d at 438; see also Swinton
    Creek Nursery v. Edisto Farm Credit, 334
  S.C. 469, 478-80, 514 S.E.2d 126, 131 (1999) (noting
  the difference between publicity and publication â€œis one of a communication
  that reaches, or is sure to reach, the publicâ€).Â  Thus, while a confidential
  relationship is breached if unauthorized disclosure is made to an individual not
  a party to the confidence, the right of privacy[6] is not implicated. McCormick, 328 S.C. at 641, 494 S.E.2d at 438.
Based
  upon the foregoing, we find Snavely cannot sustain her claim against Piedmont for invasion of privacy.Â  Here, the record contains no evidence suggesting Dr.
  Zellner or anyone else connected with Piedmont disclosed Snavelyâ€™s condition
  outside the examination room.Â  Consequently, Snavely cannot satisfy the
  publicity requirement of her invasion of privacy claim because Snavely cannot
  prove Piedmont publicized her medical condition to the public at large.Â  Thus,
  the trial court properly granted Piedmont summary judgment on this ground. 
Because we find Dr. Zellner breached no duty, we
  decline to address Snavelyâ€™s remaining argument regarding the ostensible agency
  doctrine established in Simmons v. Tuomey Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 341 S.C. 32,
  533 S.E.2d 312 (2000). See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown,
    Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (appellate court need
  not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive).Â Â  
II. Motion to Dismiss
Snavely
  argues the trial court erred in granting Dr. Zellnerâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  Specifically,
  Snavely argues the trial court erred in finding the collateral estoppel doctrine barred the litigation of her claims
  against Dr. Zellner.Â  We disagree. 
Initially,
  we note this issue is not properly before us because Snavely failed to serve her
  motion to alter or amend judgment pursuant to Rules
  5(a) and 59(e), SCRCP.Â  According to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, â€œa motion to alter or
  amend judgment shall be served no later than 10 days after receipt of written
  notice of the entry of the order.â€Â  Rule 5(a), SCRCP, further provides
  all â€œwritten motions . . . shall be served upon each of the parties of record.â€Â  In the present case, Dr. Zellner was never served with
  Snavelyâ€™s motion to alter or amend judgment.[7]Â 
  Thus, we decline to rule on this issue. 
Adverting
  to the merits, this court set forth the modern
  rule regarding the application of collateral estoppel in Beall v. Doe, 281 S.C. 363, 370-71, 315 S.E.2d
  186, 190-91 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In addressing the application of collateral
  estoppel, the Beall court held a party precluded from relitigating an
  issue with an opposing party is also precluded from relitigating the same issue
  with a different party unless the precluded party lacked full and fair
  opportunity to litigate the issue in the first action.Â  Id.Â  While
  the traditional use of collateral estoppel required mutuality of parties to bar
  relitigation, modern courts recognize the mutuality requirement is not
  necessary for the application of collateral estoppel where the party against
  whom estoppel is asserted had a full and fair opportunity to previously
  litigate the issues.Â  Id.Â  As noted by this court: 

  In the abstract, there is no legitimate reason to permit a defendant
    who has already thoroughly and vigorously litigated an issue and lost the
    opportunity to relitigate the identical question, already once decided, simply
    because he now faces a different plaintiff who for due process reasons could
    not be adversely bound by the prior judgment. The public interest demands an
    end to the litigation of the same issue.Â  Principles of finality, certainty,
    and the proper administration of justice suggest that a decision once rendered
    should stand unless some compelling countervailing consideration necessitates
    relitigation. 

Id. at 370, 315 S.E.2d at 190.Â  Thus, the
  primary concern of our courts in applying collateral estoppel is not whether
  the parties satisfy the mutuality requirement, but whether a potentially
  precluded party had a full and fair opportunity to litigate the issues in a
  prior action.Â  Id.Â  
In the present case, the record clearly indicates Snavely had a
  full and fair opportunity to litigate the issues of consent, waiver, and
  comparative negligence in her claim against Piedmont.Â  Therefore, non-mutual
  collateral estoppel was correctly applied, and Snavely was properly barred from
  relitigating these same issues against Dr. Zellner.Â  Accordingly, the trial
  court did not err in granting Dr. Zellnerâ€™s motion to dismiss. 
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we find the trial court did not err in granting both Piedmontâ€™s motion for
  summary judgment and Dr. Zellnerâ€™s motion for dismissal. Â Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED. 
WILLIAMS
and PIEPER, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] At the time of the incident, Snavely resided with her
brother, James Brooks (Mr. Brooks), and his wife, Carol Brooks (Mrs. Brooks).Â  
[3] The record contains no evidence suggesting Dr.
  Zellner, or anyone else connected with Snavely, disclosed her condition outside
the examination room.Â  
[4] It appears there was a falling out between Snavely
  and the Brookses after which Mrs. Brooks allegedly called Snavelyâ€™s employer
and disclosed Snavelyâ€™s condition. 
[5] At common law, neither the
  patient nor the physician has the privilege to refuse to disclose in court a
  communication of one to the other, nor does either have a privilege that the
  communication not be disclosed to a third person. 61 Am.Jur.2d Physicians,
    Surgeons, and Other Healers Â§Â§ 148, 169 (1981).Â  Although several states
  have statutorily created a â€œphysician-patient testimonial privilege,â€ South Carolina has not enacted a similar statute and does not recognize the
  physician-patient privilege.Â  See Peagler v. Atlantic Coast Line R.R.
    Co., 232 S.C. 274, 282-83, 101 S.E.2d 821, 825 (1958) (noting statutes have
  been enacted in most states making communications between a physician and
  patient privileged from compulsory disclosure, but there is no such statute in
  South Carolina).Â  However, the absence of a testimonial privilege barring certain
  in-court disclosures is not determinative of our issue because this evidentiary
  privilege is discernible from a duty of confidentiality.Â  As noted by our
  Supreme Court in S.C. State Board of Medical Examiners v. Hedgepath, 325
  S.C. 166, 169, 480 S.E.2d 724, 726 (1997): â€œThe terms â€˜privilegeâ€™ and
  â€˜confidencesâ€™ are not synonymous, and a professionalâ€™s duty to maintain his
  clientâ€™s confidences is independent of the issue whether he can be legally
  compelled to reveal some or all of those confidences, that is, whether those
communications are privileged.â€ 
[6] As noted by our Supreme
  Court in McCormick:

  Privacy is a right against the public at large. Its doctrinal
    limits narrowly circumscribe the zone of proscribed conduct in order to prevent
    hindrance of public expression. In contrast, a right to confidentiality exists
    against a specific person, who, by virtue of his relationship to the confider,
    has notice of the duty to preserve the secrecy of clearly identifiable
    information.

328 S.C. at 641, 494 S.E.2d at 438 (citation omitted). 
[7] In her attorney affidavit, Snavelyâ€™s counsel
  explained the motion to alter and amend judgment was not properly served on Dr.
Zellner due to â€œinadvertence and excusable mistake.â€Â

title: Johnson v. Beauty Unlimited Landscape Co.
description: In this action seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits for a work-related eye injury, Macksey Johnson appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming an award of benefits for an 8.5% loss of vision.  We affirm.
text:
<!--

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Macksey
      Johnson, Employee, Appellant,
				v.
				Beauty
      Unlimited Landscape Co., Employer, and Selective Way Insurance Co., Carrier, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Special Circuit
  Court Judge
Opinion No. 4414
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“Filed June 17,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Steven Eric Goldberg, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Benjamin M. Renfrow, of Greenville, for Respondents.
			
		
	

CURETON, A. J.:Â  In this action seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits for a
  work-related eye injury, Macksey Johnson appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order
  affirming an award of benefits for an 8.5% loss of vision.Â  We affirm.[1] Â Â 
FACTS
On May 31, 2001, a tree limb struck Macksey Johnsonâ€™s right eye
  while he was working for Beauty Unlimited Landscaping (Beauty Unlimited).Â  As a
  result of that injury, Johnson developed a traumatic cataract in that eye.Â  Dr.
  Karen Ullian, a general ophthalmologist, surgically removed the cataract and
  implanted an artificial lens.Â  Johnson returned to work in September of 2001.Â 
  One month later, Dr. Ullian recorded that the intraocular implant had restored Johnsonâ€™s
  vision in his right eye to 20/20.Â Â Â  
Dr. Ullian testified in March of 2005 Johnson had 20/30 vision in
  his right eye, but glasses corrected this vision to 20/20.Â  When Johnson
  complained of seeing â€œfloatersâ€ in February of 2005, Dr. Ullian examined him.Â 
  She determined the floating visual disruptions were benign and would eventually
  go away.Â  Dr. Ullian considered the intraocular implant to be a corrective
  measure comparable to glasses or contact lenses.Â  However, according to Dr.
  Ullian, the implant is a permanent solution to Johnsonâ€™s injury.Â  She testified
  the only maintenance the implant would ever require was an annual eye exam.Â 
  Dr. Ullian confidently stated, â€œHe will never need an implant replacement[;]
  that implant is perfect.â€Â  Moreover, as a result of the implant, Dr. Ullian
  testified Johnson â€œha[d] no disability.â€Â Â Â  
Johnson filed a Form 50 with the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Commission)
  seeking compensation for 100% loss of use of his right eye.[2]Â  The single commissioner found
  Johnsonâ€™s eye injury was compensable and ordered Beauty Unlimited to pay all
  approved medical bills related to treatment for this injury through February
  16, 2005, the date Johnson reached maximum medical improvement.Â  However, the single
  commissioner declined to characterize the intraocular implant as a â€œcorrective
  lensâ€ and awarded Johnson only an 18.5% permanent partial disability for the loss
  of vision in his right eye.Â  Both parties appealed.Â Â Â  
The appellate panel affirmed the single commissioner with some
  modifications.Â  The appellate panel reduced the 18.5% loss of vision to 8.5% based
  upon correction of Johnsonâ€™s 20/30 vision to 20/20.[3]Â  Furthermore, the appellate panel
  held the word â€œuseâ€ in the applicable regulation must necessarily indicate a
  removable corrective appliance like glasses or contact lenses.Â  The circuit
  court affirmed the appellate panel.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  reviewing workersâ€™ compensation decisions, the appellate court ascertains â€œwhether
  the circuit court properly determined whether the appellate panelâ€™s findings of
  fact are supported by substantial evidence in the record and whether the
  panelâ€™s decision is affected by an error of law.â€ Â Baxter v. Martin Bros.,
    Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42, 43 (2006) (citations omitted); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2007).Â  Generally, â€œâ€˜[c]ourts
  defer to the relevant administrative agencyâ€™s decisions with respect to its own
  regulations unless there is a compelling reason to differ.â€™â€Â  Neal v. Brown,
  374 S.C. 641, 649, 649 S.E.2d 164, 168 (Ct. App. 2007), cert. granted May 30, 2008 (quoting S.C. Coastal Conservation League v. S.C. Depâ€™t of
    Health & Envtl. Control, 363 S.C. 67, 75, 610 S.E.2d 482, 486 (2005)).Â  

	If a
  statuteâ€™s terms are clear, the court must apply the terms according to their
  literal meaning. Â â€œAn appellate court cannot construe a statute without regard
  to its plain meaning and may not resort to a forced interpretation in an
  attempt to expand or limit the scope of a statute.â€ Â While the appellate court
  usually defers to the [a]ppellate [p]anelâ€™s construction of its own regulation,
  where the [a]ppellate [p]anelâ€™s interpretation is contrary to the plain
  language of the regulation, the court will reject its interpretation. 

Id. at 650, 649 S.E.2d at 168 (citing Brown v. S.C.
  Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414
  (2002)) (internal citations omitted).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.  Regulation 67-1105
Johnson
  first argues the circuit court erred in interpreting regulation 67-1105[4] to exclude compensation for the 100% loss of vision in his eye.Â  We disagree.Â  
A
  disability is an â€œincapacity because of injury to earn the wages which the
  employee was receiving at the time of injury in the same or any other
  employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-120 (1985).Â  An employer must pay an injured
  employee compensation for partial disability.Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-20 to -30
  (1985 & Supp. 2007).Â  The loss of an eye results in a compensable partial
  disability.Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-30(18) (Supp. 2007).Â  â€œLoss of vision is
  based on reading without the use of corrective lenses.â€Â  S.C. Code Regs. Â§ 67-1105
  (1989).Â Â Â  
The
  circuit court properly determined the appellate panel committed no error of
  law.Â  Under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act (Act), a work-related injury is
  compensable above and beyond the cost of treatment to the extent it renders the
  employee disabled.Â  See Â§Â§ 42-9-20 to -30.Â  From this premise it follows
  that when treatment restores the employee to his pre-injury condition so he no
  longer requires assistive devices to compensate for his loss, the employee is
  no longer disabled.Â  Only a disabled employee is eligible for additional workersâ€™
  compensation benefits.Â  In Dr. Ullianâ€™s opinion, Johnson was no longer disabled
  after the implant surgery.Â  However, he did wear glasses to correct the 20/30
  vision in his right eye.Â  No other medical testimony was offered.Â  In light of
  these facts, the appellate panel affirmed an award of disability benefits
  appropriate to Johnsonâ€™s 20/30 vision.Â  Consequently, we find the circuit court
  did not err in affirming the appellate panelâ€™s award.Â  
We
  see no compelling reason to depart from the appellate panelâ€™s ruling that the
  term â€œcorrective lensesâ€ does not include implanted lenses.[5] Â While we agree with Dr. Ullian that an intraocular implant is corrective in
  nature, we find it is not a â€œcorrective lensâ€ as contemplated by regulation
  67-1105.Â  In affirming the appellate panel, the circuit court reasoned:

	Clearly,
  there is a distinct difference between a removable glass or plastic lens, which
  must be replaced or removed periodically, and a complex invasive surgery that
  permanently restructures and repairs oneâ€™s vision.Â  An intra-ocular lens
  implant . . . is an intricate surgery that rebuilds the inner-workings of the
  eye, whereby the patient is able to permanently recover his or her vision to a
  degree often greater than that prior to injury.Â  

We find an intraocular
  implant differs significantly from both glasses and contact lenses in terms of
  the permanence of the solution and the requirement of future maintenance.Â  With
  regard to permanence, a person may wear or remove glasses or contact lenses at
  will.Â  However, an intraocular implant resides wholly within the patientâ€™s eye
  and is inaccessible without surgery.Â  Furthermore, according to Dr. Ullian, the intraocular
  implant will last the rest of Johnsonâ€™s life.Â  In light of these facts, we do not believe Johnsonâ€™s current â€œloss of
  visionâ€ without the use of his implanted lens could be determined without
  surgically removing his implant.Â  See S.C. Code Regs. Â§ 67-1105
  (1989).Â  With regard to future maintenance, common knowledge dictates that both
  glasses and contact lenses frequently require replacement because they become
  lost, break, or, more commonly in the case of contact lenses, wear out.Â  Periodic
  vision examinations and new prescriptions render old glasses and contact lenses
  obsolete.Â  In addition, as Dr. Ullian observed, contact lenses expose the
  wearer to the risk of eye infections.Â  Â Â 
By contrast, Johnsonâ€™s implant will never need replacement and
  does not regularly expose his eye to infections.Â  His vision without the use of
  contact lenses or eyeglasses has been measured at 20/30.Â  He need only wear
  glasses to perfect his vision, which is already quite good.Â  However, Johnson
  received an award of workersâ€™ compensation benefits for the percentage of his
  vision the glasses restore.Â  Because we concur with the appellate panelâ€™s
  reasoning in distinguishing an intraocular implant from the â€œcorrective lensesâ€
  contemplated in the regulation, we defer to the agencyâ€™s expertise and ruling
  in this matter.Â  
II.  Interpretation of
  Regulation
Johnson
  next argues the circuit court erred in failing to interpret the regulation in
  the light most favorable to the claimant.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œWorkersâ€™
  compensation laws were intended by the Legislature to relieve workers of the
  uncertainties of a trial for damages by providing sure, swift recovery for
  workplace injuries regardless of fault.â€ Â Peay v. U.S. Silica Co., 313
  S.C. 91, 94, 437 S.E.2d 64, 65 (1993).Â  On appeal from a decision of the appellate
  panel, a court must â€œreview the evidence, and state the facts and the
  reasonable inferences therefrom, in the light most favorable to claimant.â€ Â Ford
    v. Allied Chem. Corp., 252 S.C. 561, 564, 167 S.E.2d 564, 565 (1969).Â  â€œAny
  reasonable doubts as to construction of the Act should be resolved in favor of
  coverage.â€Â  Mauldin v. Dyna-Color/Jack Rabbit, 308 S.C. 18, 22, 416
  S.E.2d 639, 641 (1992).Â  
The
  circuit court did not err in affirming the appellate panel.Â  The role of the
  courts is to evaluate the evidence â€œin the light most favorable to claimantâ€ to
  ensure injured employees do not bear the cost of disabilities resulting from
  work-related hazards. Â This role does not empower the courts to employ
  semantics to stretch the Act or its attendant regulations and extend benefits
  to persons who no longer suffer a disability.Â  See Santee Cooper
    Resort, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 298 S.C. 179, 184, 379 S.E.2d 119,
  122 (1989).Â  The Commission found Johnson suffered a work-related disability
  and ordered his employer to fund his medical treatment.Â  No evidence suggests
  his employer failed to pay for his treatment.Â  But for a small diminution in
  vision, the medical treatment he received eliminated the disability.Â  Therefore,
  we find Johnson has recuperated without bearing the cost of his recovery.Â  Permitting
  him to recover simultaneously for wholly successful medical treatment and for a
  100% disability that no longer exists would create an unreasonable windfall for
  Johnson.Â  The Act has served its purpose by ensuring coverage for Johnsonâ€™s
  â€œsure, swift recoveryâ€ from injury and by providing for his future vision-care
  needs in accordance with the actual diminution in vision he has experienced.Â  Peay,
  313 S.C. at 95, 437 S.E.2d at 65.Â  Accordingly, we see no error.
CONCLUSION
We
  find no error of law in the appellate panelâ€™s decision to exclude an
  intraocular implant from the term â€œcorrective lensesâ€ in regulation 67-1105.Â  For
  this reason, the circuit court did not err in affirming the appellate panelâ€™s
  decision.Â  Furthermore, we find the appellate panel committed no error in
  evaluating the evidence or interpreting the law in this matter, and thus, its
  decision is supported by substantial evidence.Â  Consequently, the circuit court
  did not err in affirming the appellate panelâ€™s decision.Â  Accordingly, the
  order of the circuit court in this matter is
AFFIRMED.
SHORT
  and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Johnson subsequently developed a cataract in his left
  eye, but Dr. Ullian believed it was unrelated to the right-eye injury.Â  Johnson
  made no claim for his left eye.Â  
[3] According to the Snellen Notation table, 20/30 vision
  corresponds with an 8.5% loss of vision.Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-1105
  (1990).Â  
[4] 25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-1105 (1990).Â  
[5] Both parties to this appeal have surveyed the rather
  even split on this issue in decisions from other jurisdictions.Â  However, we
  are not compelled to weigh the decisions of other jurisdictions when we agree
  with the well-reasoned ruling of the Commission.Â  See Neal v. Brown,
  374 S.C. 641, 649, 649 S.E.2d 164, 168 (Ct. App. 2007), cert. granted May 30, 2008.Â

description: This is a cross appeal arising from an order apportioning interpleaded funds in an equitable action.
