THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Cody Steven
          Powell, by and through his Conservator, Kelly H. Kelley, and his natural and
          legal guardian, Elizabeth Powell, Respondent,
        v.
        Bank of America, Karen P. Unrue, and Travis Powell, Defendants,
        and Elizabeth
          Powell,  Defendant/Intervenor,
        of whom Bank of
          America is the Appellant/Respondent,
        and Elizabeth
          Powell is the Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge
  Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 4415
Heard May 6, 2008 â€“ Filed June 20, 2008Â Â  

APPEAL DISMISSED 


  
    
      
        Clarence Davis and T. William McGee, III, both of Columbia, for Appellant-Respondent.Â  
        Jennifer R. Kellahan, W.E. Jenkinson, III, and Ronnie Alan Sabb,
          all of Kingstree, for Respondent.Â  
        Helen Tyler McFadden, of Kingstree, for Respondent-Appellant.
        Harry C. Wilson, Jr., of Sumter, for Defendant Travis Powell.Â  
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â 
  We are presented with cross-appeals arising from an order apportioning
  interpleaded funds in a severed equitable action.Â  The appeal of the Bank of
  America (the Bank) is dismissed because it has no legal interest in the
  interpleaded funds and is not an aggrieved party in the severed equitable
  action.Â  Because the Bankâ€™s appeal is dismissed, we decline to address the
  remaining issues.Â  
I.
On
  November 19, 2000, Steven Powell died in a work-related accident, leaving
  behind his wife, Elizabeth, and a minor son, Cody.Â  Elizabeth received life
  insurance proceeds for herself and Cody from three separate policies.Â  
In February 2001,
  Stevenâ€™s sister, Karen Powell (now Karen P. Unrue), approached Elizabeth about managing these funds.Â  At the time, Karen was the owner of an accounting
  business, Carolina Bookkeeping, and held herself out as knowledgeable regarding
  investments.Â  Karen told Elizabeth that the investment firm of Charles Schwab,
  where Elizabeth had already invested a portion of the funds, would cheat her
  out of her money.Â  Ultimately, Elizabeth began to rely on Karen for investment
  advice, and between February 21 and May 1 of 2001, Elizabeth transferred
  $274,191 to Karen for investment.Â  
In a
  March 29, 2001 order of the probate court of Williamsburg County, Karen and her
  brother, Travis Powell, were appointed co-conservators for the estate of Cody.Â 
  Under the probate court order, the funds were to be deposited in a restricted
  account, and no funds were to be withdrawn or transferred without written order
  of the probate court.Â  The probate court also prohibited Karen and Travis from
  compensating themselves out of Codyâ€™s funds.Â  
Codyâ€™s funds were
  never placed in a restricted account.Â  Karen deposited Codyâ€™s funds into her
  checking account at the Bank, and subsequently placed them into certificates of
  deposit (CDs) with the Bank in her name.Â  As each CD matured, the money was
  re-deposited into Karenâ€™s personal checking account, and by September 2001, all
  of the funds had been withdrawn from the CDs and placed into Karenâ€™s personal
  account.Â  
Karen
  and her husband moved to Colorado in 2001.Â  By the end of November 2001, Karen
  had removed $355,000 from her checking account at the Bank and deposited the
  funds in an account with Vectra Bank in Colorado in the names of Karen, Travis,
  and Elizabeth.Â  Elizabeth was unaware of this account.Â  While in Colorado, Karen withdrew the funds for her own personal use.Â  On several occasions, Elizabeth contacted Karen through a phone booth in Colorado requesting an accounting of
  the funds.Â  While Karen did make several small payments at the request of Elizabeth, Karen failed to provide an accounting of the funds or to return the funds to
  Cody and Elizabeth.Â Â Â  
On
  May 30, 2002, Elizabeth filed a complaint against Karen for conversion of the
  funds. Â The same day, Karen forwarded a check in the amount of $194,637.97
  drawn from the account at Vectra Bank to a South Carolina attorney, who placed
  the funds in escrow.Â  In June 2004, Elizabeth secured a judgment in her action
  against Karen in the amount of $249,733.39 actual damages and $750,000 punitive
  damages.Â Â Â  
On
  May 2, 2003, Cody, through his conservator, Kelly H. Kelley, and his mother,
  Elizabeth, filed suit against the Bank, Travis, and Karen to recover his
  funds.Â  The Bank and Travis appeared and filed answers denying liability.Â 
  Karen, however, did not respond and was held in default.Â Â Â  
By
  consent order filed November 21, 2003, the parties in Codyâ€™s action agreed for
  all funds in the escrow account to be deposited in an interest-bearing account
  with the clerk of court for Williamsburg County.Â  Subsequently, on June 16,
  2004, Elizabeth joined the case as a defendant-intervenor pursuant to Rule
  24(a)(2), SCRCP.Â  
Judge
  Howard P. King issued a scheduling order in Codyâ€™s case on December 30, 2004,
  which set March 1, 2005, as the deadline for completion of discovery.Â 
  Subsequent to the discovery deadline, the Bank filed a motion to sever Elizabethâ€™s equitable action pursuant to Rule 42, SCRCP.Â  The Bankâ€™s motion, dated May 12,
  2005, asserted five grounds to justify its request for severance:Â  

  (1) Codyâ€™s claims against the Bank are â€œentirely
    separate and have no relation to the issue . . . [of] what portion of
    the escrowed funds belongs to [Cody] and what portion belongs to [Elizabeth].â€Â  
  (2) â€œ[D]eciding the ownership of such funds furthers
    the important interests of judicial economy for all parties, counsel and the
    Courtâ€ because Elizabeth â€œwill not have to actively participate in the trial of
    the primary claims[.]â€Â  
  (3) â€œ[S]evering this issue from the first-party action
    also serves the best interest of [Cody]. . . .Â  If the Court agrees with [the
    Bankâ€™s expert], [Cody] will receive over $150,000 in cash before trial . . .
    which is patently to his benefit.â€Â  
  (4) â€œ[S]everance of this claim will benefit all parties to this action.Â  [Elizabeth] will receive her interest of the escrowed
    funds and will not have to incur additional attorneysâ€™ fees, costs and
    inconvenience associated with the trial of this case.â€Â  
  (5) The Bank â€œwill know [its] liability before
    trial.â€Â  (Emphasis in original.)Â Â Â  

The
  Bankâ€™s motion to sever was heard by Judge Thomas W. Cooper, Jr.Â Â  Judge Cooper
  granted the severance motion by order dated July 25, 2005.Â  Judge Cooperâ€™s
  reasoning tracked the grounds asserted in the Bankâ€™s May 12 motion, as the
  order emphasized factors such as convenience of parties, convenience of
  witnesses, judicial economy, and the â€œseparateâ€ and â€œindependentâ€ nature of
  Codyâ€™s legal claims and Elizabethâ€™s â€œequitable claim as to a portion of the
  escrowed funds.â€Â  At the hearing before Judge Cooper, the Bank acknowledged
  that neither the Bank â€œnor any of the
  co-conservators or anyone else is claiming any ownership of those funds. 
  Itâ€™s only how much belongs to [Cody and] how much belongs to [Elizabeth]. 
  Thatâ€™s it.â€   
The
  hearing to apportion the escrowed funds was scheduled to begin December 20,
  2005 before Judge King.Â  According to the record, Cody and Elizabeth reached an
  agreement on the eve of the hearing concerning the apportionment of the
  escrowed funds.Â  Subject to court review and approval, Cody and Elizabeth
  agreed to apportion the funds 56% to 44%, respectively.Â  The Bank objected to
  the settlement as it, in hopes of minimizing Codyâ€™s ultimate damage claim,
  advocated for Cody receiving a greater share of the funds. Elizabeth contended
  that the Bank did not have an interest in the funds, noting that she and Cody
  â€œhave an absolute unfettered right to settle.â€ 
The
  issue of apportionment of the funds proceeded to a contested hearing, with the
  Bank taking a prominent role ostensibly on Codyâ€™s behalf.Â  Judge King
  apportioned the funds, which then totaled $197,596.44, giving 56% to Cody ($110,654)
  and 44% to Elizabeth ($86,942.44), the same as the settlement agreement.Â  The
  cross-appeals followed.Â 
II.
APPEAL OF ELIZABETH POWELL 
Elizabeth argues the Bank has no interest in the subject matter
  of the apportionment of the escrowed funds.Â  We agree and dismiss the Bankâ€™s
  appeal.
We conclude the Bank has no interest in the subject matter of the apportionment of the escrowed
  funds and therefore lacks standing.Â  As a consequence of its lack of interest
  in the escrowed funds, the Bank is not an aggrieved party under Rule 201 of the
  South Carolina Appellate Court Rules.Â  The Bank is a party only to Codyâ€™s
  underlying damage claims.Â  The Bank has never been a party to the severed
  equitable claim of Elizabeth.Â  As Judge Cooper correctly noted in severing the
  legal and equitable claims, â€œ[t]here is no overlapping evidence in these two separate cases brought by separate parties.â€Â  (Second emphasis
  added.)Â  
Standing
  refers to a â€œ[a] partyâ€™s right to make a legal claim or seek judicial
  enforcement of a duty or right.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1413 (7th ed.
  1999).Â  â€œStanding is . . . that concept of justiciability that is concerned
  with whether a particular person may raise legal arguments or claims.â€Â  1A
  C.J.S. Actions Â§ 101 (2005).Â  It concerns an individualâ€™s â€œsufficient
  interest in the outcome of the litigation to warrant consideration of [the personâ€™s]
  position by a court.â€Â  Id.Â  
Standing
  is comprised of three elements:

  First,
    the plaintiff must have suffered an â€œinjury in factâ€â€”an invasion of a legally
    protected interest which is (a) concrete and particularized, and (b) â€œactual or
    imminent, not â€˜conjecturalâ€™ or â€˜hypothetical.â€™ â€Â  Second, there must be a
    causal connection between the injury and the conduct complained ofâ€”the injury has to be
    â€œfairly . . . trace[able] to the challenged action of the defendant, and not .
    . . th[e] result [of] the independent action of some third party not before the
    court.â€Â  Third, it must be â€œlikely,â€ as opposed to merely â€œspeculative,â€ that
    the injury will be â€œredressed by a favorable decision.â€

Smiley v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health
    & Envtâ€™l Control,  374 S.C.
  326, 329, 649 S.E.2d 31, 32-33 (2007) (quoting Lujan v. Defenders
    of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560-61 (1992) (alteration in original)).Â  â€œThe party seeking to establish standing
  carries the burden of demonstrating each of the three elements.â€Â  Sea Pines
    Assâ€™n for the Protection of Wildlife, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural
    Res., 345 S.C. 594, 601, 550 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2001).
â€œAs
  a general rule, to have standing, a litigant must have a personal stake in the
  subject matter of the litigation.â€Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 62,
  624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  â€œOne must be a real party in interest, i.e.,
  a party who has a real, material, or substantial interest in the subject matter
  of the action, as opposed to one who has only a nominal or technical interest
  in the action.â€Â  Id.Â  
The
  Bank admits it has no ownership interest in the interpleaded funds.Â  The Bank
  posits two grounds to support its claim of standing: (1) it is in Codyâ€™s best
  interest to receive all of the interpleaded funds; and (2) by allocating all of
  the interpleaded funds to Cody, the Bank reduces Codyâ€™s damages, thereby
  reducing the Bankâ€™s potential liability.
First,
  we reject as transparently thin the Bankâ€™s argument that it is seeking to
  protect Codyâ€™s best interest.Â  We are unaware of any law (and the Bank has
  cited none) supporting the idea that one party may acquire standing by
  asserting the interest of an adverse party.Â  The familiar principle that courts
  must zealously guard the rights of minors certainly does not give the Bank a pass
  on standing requirements.Â  Second, while we understand the Bankâ€™s desire to
  limit its potential exposure in Codyâ€™s underlying action, this practical
  concern falls far short of the â€œinjury in factâ€ standing requirement.Â  Not
  every practical concern equates to the legal interest required for standing.Â 
  The Bank denies any liability to Cody, and its interest in maximizing Codyâ€™s
  share of the interpleaded funds is therefore speculative and contingent.Â  
We
  find instructive the supreme courtâ€™s recent decision in Ex Parte Government
    Employeeâ€™s Insurance Co., 373 S.C. 132, 644 S.E.2d 699 (2007), in which the
  court addressed the sufficiency of a partyâ€™s potential liability in relation to
  joinder and standing.Â  Ronnie Cooper was injured in a motor vehicle accident.Â  Id. at 134, 644 S.E.2d at 700.Â  Cooper, claiming the status of a Class I insured,
  sought to stack underinsured motorist coverage provided by Government
  Employeeâ€™s Insurance Co. (GEICO) to Yolanda Goethe.Â  Id.Â  According to
  Cooper, he and Goethe had a common law marriage.Â  Id.Â  GEICO denied the
  common law marriage claim and Cooperâ€™s stacking claim.Â  Id.Â  GEICO
  brought a declaratory judgment action against Cooper to determine the partiesâ€™
  rights pursuant to the policy issued to Goethe.Â  Id.Â  Cooper responded
  by filing a family court action seeking an order recognizing the purported
  common law marriage.Â  Id.Â  Because the family courtâ€™s decision on the
  common law marriage issue would impact GEICOâ€™s ability to protect its interest
  in the circuit court declaratory judgment action, GIECO moved to join the
  family court action.Â  Id. at 134-35, 644 S.E.2d at 700.
Finding
  that GEICO was not a necessary party for joinder and did not have standing to
  intervene, the family court denied GEICOâ€™s motion.Â  Id. at 135, 644 S.E.2d
  at 700.Â  The supreme court affirmed, referring to GEICOâ€™s interest in the
  common law marriage determination as â€œinsufficient,â€ â€œmerely tangential,â€ and
  â€œmerely peripheral.â€ Id. at 136-37, 644 S.E.2d at 701-02.Â  The supreme
  court, while well aware that â€œthe existence of a common law marriage may impact
  GEICOâ€™s liability to Cooper,â€ id. at 136, 644 S.E.2d at 701, concluded
  that â€œGEICOâ€™s interest is in the financial implications of the family
  courtâ€™s decision, which is peripheral to the subject matter before the court.â€Â  Id. at 138-39, 644 S.E.2d at 702 (emphasis added).
GEICO
  presented a stronger case for standing than does the Bank.Â  The Bankâ€™s interest
  in the allocation of the interpleaded funds falls far short of conferring
  standing.Â  The Bankâ€™s potential and speculative liability to Cody is tangential
  and peripheral to the precise allocation of the interpleaded funds between Cody
  and Elizabeth.Â  As with GEICO, the Bankâ€™s interest is merely in the â€œfinancial
  implicationsâ€ of the trial courtâ€™s decision allocating the interpleaded funds.
We
  now turn to Elizabethâ€™s specific assignments of error concerning the Bankâ€™s
  lack of standing.Â  Elizabeth first claims the trial court erred in allowing the
  Bank to prevent her and Cody from settling the matter of the allocation of
  escrowed funds.Â  As noted, Elizabeth and Cody reached an agreement concerning
  their respective ownership interest of the funds.Â  When the Bank objected to
  the proposed settlement, Elizabeth challenged the Bankâ€™s standing to do so.Â 
  The trial court erred.Â  Yet the error, by itself, would not warrant reversal,
  for the trial court ultimately apportioned the funds in the same manner as the
  parties had proposed in their settlement.Â  Consequently, Elizabeth was not
  prejudiced by the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  See Brown v. Pearson,
  326 S.C. 409, 417, 483 S.E.2d 477, 481 (Ct. App. 1997) (stating â€œ[a]n error not
  shown to be prejudicial does not constitute grounds for reversalâ€); McCall
    v. Finley, 294 S.C. 1, 4, 362 S.E.2d 26, 28 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œAppellate
  courts recognize . . . an overriding rule of civil procedure which says:Â 
  whatever doesnâ€™t make any difference, doesnâ€™t matter.â€).Â  
Elizabeth finally challenges the Bankâ€™s status as an â€œaggrieved
  partyâ€ for appeal purposes.Â  There is no
  material distinction in general standing principles juxtaposed to the ability
  of an â€œaggrieved partyâ€ to appeal pursuant to Rule 201(b) of the South Carolina
  Appellate Court Rules.Â  See Beaufort Realty Co. v. Beaufort County, 346
  S.C. 298, 301-03, 551 S.E.2d 588-89, 589 (Ct. App. 2001) (conducting an
  analysis under both Rule 201 and general standing principles in addressing
  whether a party had standing to appeal). 
In
  considering the Bankâ€™s ability to appeal from the order apportioning the
  escrowed funds, the Bank is neither a â€œpartyâ€ nor â€œaggrieved.â€Â  As noted
  earlier, the Bank has never been a party to the severed equitable action.Â 
  Judge Cooper specifically stated in his order granting the motion for a
  severance that this matter involves â€œtwo separate cases brought by separate
  parties.â€Â  In addition, Elizabethâ€™s counsel pointed out at a subsequent hearing
  that the Bank was never made a party to the equitable action.Â  
Rule
  201(b) limits the ability to appeal to â€œ[o]nly a party aggrieved by an order,
  judgment . . . or decision . . . .â€Â  Rule 201(b), SCACR.Â  This court has
  previously explained that under Rule 201(b), â€œ[t]he word â€˜aggrievedâ€™ refers to
  a substantial grievance, a denial of some personal or property right, or the
  imposition on a party of a burden or obligation.â€Â  Beaufort Realty Co.,
  346 S.C. at 301, 551 S.E.2d at 589.Â  â€œA party is aggrieved by a judgment or
  decree when it operates on his or her rights of property or bears directly on
  his or her interest.â€Â  Id.Â  In light of Ex Parte Government
    Employeeâ€™s Insurance Co., the Bank may not properly claim that the trial
  courtâ€™s apportionment of the escrowed funds affects its property rights or
  otherwise bears on its interest.
Because
  the Bank has no interest in the escrowed funds, the Bank is not aggrieved by
  the trial courtâ€™s apportionment of the funds between Cody and Elizabeth.Â  We
  dismiss the Bankâ€™s appeal.Â  
Elizabeth conceded at oral argument that the dismissal of the
  Bankâ€™s appeal renders the balance of her appeal moot.Â  We therefore decline to
  address the balance of her appeal.
APPEAL
  DISMISSED.
ANDERSON
  and HUFF, JJ., concur.

title: Olson v. South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control
description: This is an appeal from  an Administrative Law Court (ALC) order.  Bruce and Barbara Olson challenge the ALC's finding that (1) a dock permit issued by the Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management (OCRM) and subsequently transferred to the Olson's adjoining landowner, Jack Sims, was not a joint-use permit for Sims' lot 55 and the Olsons' lot 56 and (2) the denial by OCRM of an independent dock permit to the Olsons was proper. We affirm.

<!--

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Bruce and
          Barbara Olson, Appellants,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Health and Environmental Control, Office of Ocean and Costal
          Resources Management, Jack L. Sims, John McCown and Molly Ball, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
  Â Ray N. Stevens, Administrative Law Court
Judge

Opinion No. 4416
Heard June 3, 2008 â€“ Filed June 20, 2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        C. C.Harness, III, and Melinda Adelle Lucka of Mt. Pleasant; for
          Appellants.
        Carlisle Roberts, Jr., Evander Whitehead, and Leslie S. Riley all of
          Columbia, Elizabeth Dieck and William A. Scott, both of Charleston, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  This is an
  appeal by Bruce and Barbara Olson from an Administrative Law Court (ALC) order
  finding a permit issued by the South Carolina Department of Health and
  Environmental Control, Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management
  (hereinafter OCRM) and subsequently transferred to the Olsonâ€™s adjoining
  landowner, Jack L. Sims, was not a joint-use permit for Simsâ€™ lot 55 and the
  Olsonsâ€™ lot 56.Â  The Olsons also appeal the denial by OCRM of an independent
  permit for a dock from their property to the Intracoastal Waterway.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The
  Olsons own lot 56 in the Romain Retreat subdivision.Â  Sims is the owner of lot
  55, which is adjacent to the Olsonsâ€™ property.Â  John McCown owns lot 54, which
  is adjacent to Simsâ€™ lot 55.Â  Molly Ball is the owner of lot 61, located across
  a drainage ditch easement from the Olsons.Â  The Olsonsâ€™ property is situated
  such that the extension of their property lines result in their lot bordering
  the drainage ditch, across from which is the backyard of the Ball property. [1]Â 
  The Ball property lines extend out over a marsh and toward the Intracoastal Waterway, as do the Sims and McCown properties.[2]Â  
The
  Olsonsâ€™ lot was previously owned by Ann Graves, and the Sims lot was previously
  owned by Annâ€™s son, Stephen Graves.Â  In 1996, William Blume entered into two
  contracts to purchase lot 55 and lot 56 from Stephen Graves and Ann Graves.Â 
  Prior to finalizing the purchase, Blume applied for a permit for a dock located
  on lot 55, noting the property was under contract to purchase.Â  On July 3,
  1997, OCRM issued a permit to Blume, but included with the permit the special
  condition that â€œthis is the only dock permitted for lots 55 & 56.â€Â  Prior
  to issuance of the permit, in April 1997, Blume informed Ann and Stephen Graves
  he was exercising his right to terminate the contract as he was unable to
  obtain a dock permit that was satisfactory to him.[3]Â 
  Shortly thereafter, on July 8, 1997, Stephen Graves applied for a permit to
  construct a private dock from lot 55.Â  On August 25, 1997, OCRM issued the
  permit, which again included the special condition that it was the â€œonly dock
  permitted for lots 55 and 56.â€Â  
In
  1998, Sims purchased lot 55 from Stephen Graves. Â In 2001, the Olsons purchased
  lot 56 from Ann Graves.Â  In August, 2002, Stephen Graves transferred his dock
  permit to Sims.Â  After discovering the Sims property was being surveyed for the
  construction of a dock, the Olson family approached Sims about the possibility
  of a joint-use dock with Sims, which Sims declined.Â  In October 2003, Sims and
  McCown, who held his own permit for a private dock on his lot 54, applied for
  an amended permit allowing the two landowners to build one walkway down their
  property line leading to two pier heads.Â  OCRM approved the amended permit for
  Sims and McCown in February 2004.Â  In March 2004, the Olsons appealed the
  approval of the Sims/McCown amended permit for a joint-use dock and requested a
  contested hearing before the ALC.Â  Thereafter, the Olsons submitted an
  application for their own private dock from lot 56 to the Intracoastal Waterway.Â 
  On September 3, 2004, OCRM denied the Olsonsâ€™ permit application.Â  The Olsons
  challenged this decision by OCRM as well, and the two matters were consolidated
  for consideration by the ALC.
Following
  a hearing on the matter, the ALC judge issued his order concluding the Olsonsâ€™
  permit was properly denied and the Sims/McCown joint-use permit was properly
  issued.Â  Specifically, the judge affirmed the denial of the Olsonsâ€™ permit
  based on (1) the impact the proposed Olson dock would have on the adjacent
  property ownersâ€™ value and enjoyment and (2)Â  â€œthe extent to which long-range,
  cumulative effects of the project may result within the context of other
  possible development and the general character of the area.â€Â  He further
  determined, based on the evidence before him, the permit originally issued to
  Stephen Graves did not create a joint dock permit for lot 55 and lot 56.Â  The
  ALC judge also concluded the Olsonsâ€™ due process rights were not violated, and
  found no deprivation of the Olsonsâ€™ equal protection rights as well.Â  This
  appeal followed. [4] 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  contested permitting cases, the ALC serves as the finder of fact.Â  Neal v.
    Brown, 374 S.C. 641, 648, 649 S.E.2d 164, 167 (Ct. App. 2007); Brown v.
      S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 520, 560 S.E.2d
  410, 417 (2002).Â  Judicial review of the ALC judgeâ€™s order is governed by
  section 1-23-610(C) of the South Carolina Code which provides as follows: 

  The
    review of the administrative law judgeâ€™s order must be confined to the record.Â 
    The reviewing tribunal may affirm the decision or remand the case for further
    proceedings; or it may reverse or modify the decision if the substantive rights
    of the petitioner has (sic) been prejudiced because of (sic) the finding,
    conclusion, or decision is:
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (a)
      in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions;
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (b)
      in excess of the statutory authority of the agency;
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (c)
      made upon unlawful procedure;
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (d)
      affected by other error of law;
  
    (e)
      clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence
      on the whole record;Â  or
    (f)
      arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly
      unwarranted exercise of discretion.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610(C)
  (Supp. 2007).Â  Thus, this court can reverse the ALC if the findings are affected
  by error of law, are not supported by substantial evidence, or are characterized
  by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.Â  The ALCâ€™s
  findings are supported by substantial evidence if, looking at the record as a
  whole, there is evidence from which reasonable minds could reach the same
  conclusion the administrative agency reached.Â  Neal, 374 S.C. at 648,
  649 S.E.2d at 167.Â  The mere
  possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not
  prevent a finding from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  DuRant v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 361 S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d 704,
  707 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Joint Dock Permit
The Olsons first
  argue the ALC erred in finding the permit issued to Graves did not create a
  joint dock permit for lots 55 and 56.Â  In particular, the Olsons point to
  evidence that the dock permit in question contained the provision that it was
  the only permit for lots 55 and 56, and that one of OCRMâ€™s internal documents
  on the application noted the permit type as â€œjoint.â€Â  We find substantial
  evidence in the record supports the ALC decision.
While the
  application by Stephen Graves did result in a notation on the Agencyâ€™s DBASE IV
  information sheet that the â€œPermit Typeâ€ was â€œjoint,â€ Richard Chinnis, director
  of regulatory programs with OCRM, explained this language did not indicate it
  was an application for a joint-use permit, but designated it was a joint
  application with OCRM and the Corps of Engineers.Â  We find absolutely no merit
  to the Olsonsâ€™ assertion that Chinnis did not participate in the Blume or
  Graves permitting process and therefore did not â€œunderstand the dynamics of the
  whole processâ€ sufficient enough to accurately describe the meaning of the
  condition or the notes in the file.Â  The record clearly reflects Chinnis
  participated in the permitting decision for both the Blume and Graves applications.Â  Further, the Olsons called Chinnis as their own witness, and it was
  the Olsons who elicited information on the meaning of the term â€œjointâ€ in the
  internal document from Chinnis.Â  
As
  to the special condition of the permit providing â€œthis is the only dock
  permitted for lots 55 and 56,â€ we find this language insufficient to transform
  the permit into a joint-use permit for lots 55 and 56.Â  Chinnis testified the
  condition was placed on the Blume permit because at the time Blume was in the
  process of acquiring both lots 55 and 56, and this was a notice to him that he
  need not apply for a dock permit for lot 56 as one would not be issued.Â 
  Chinnis further stated he was under the assumption that Stephen Graves owned
  both lots 55 and 56 when he applied for the dock permit, and looking at it as
  they did the Blume application with one owner of both lots, the special
  condition was an advisement to the applicant that lot 56 was not going to
  receive a dock permit.Â  Chinnis indicated there was never any mention nor
  documentation of any agreement between Stephen Graves and Ann Graves for a
  joint-use dock.[5]Â 
  As noted above, we find no merit to the Olsonsâ€™ assertion that Chinnis lacked
  knowledge on the subject.
Further,
  the evidence here clearly shows the dock permit for lot 55 issued to Stephen
  Graves and subsequently transferred to Sims did not include the owner of lot 56
  as an applicant.Â  Rather, the application shows a single-use permit for a
  private dock was sought for lot 55, with no mention of a joint-use dock.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Additionally,
  the property identified on the application corresponded with the property
  description of lot 55 and the application clearly shows the dock was solely
  located within the boundaries of lot 55.Â  The public notice for the Graves
  permit application made no reference to any joint-use dock for lots 55 and 56,
  but indicated only it was for construction of a private dock located at lot
  55.Â  The permit issued to Stephen Graves by OCRM stated the purpose of the
  permit was â€œfor the property ownerâ€™s private recreational use.â€Â  Accordingly,
  substantial evidence exists to support the ALC judgeâ€™s decision that no
  joint-use dock permit existed for lot 55 and 56.
Additionally,
  as noted by the ALC judge, there is no evidence the Olsons have secured any
  easement rights to cross Simsâ€™ property to reach the dock located on lot 55.Â 
  In fact, the Olsons admitted they had no written agreement for a joint-use dock
  with Sims, nor an easement across Simsâ€™ property. Â Issuance of a joint-use
  permit for lots 55 and 56 by OCRM could not convey any right for the owners of
  lot 56 to cross the land of lot 55.Â  See 23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. Â§
  30-4(E) (Supp. 2007) (â€œNo permit shall convey, nor be interpreted to convey, a
  property right in the land or water in which the permitted activity is
  located.â€).Â  Thus, the Olsons would have no access to the dock as originally
  permitted from the Graves application.Â  This lack of access further indicates
  the Graves permit was not a joint-use permit for lots 55 and 56. 
II.Â  Independent Dock
  Permit
The Olsons next
  maintain lot 56 is entitled to its own dock and their application should have
  resulted in the issuance of a permit.Â  We disagree. 
In asserting
  their right to an independent dock permit, the Olsons challenge several of the
  bases cited by OCRM in its letter denying the Olsons permit request.Â  However,
  this court is concerned with whether
  the ALC judgeâ€™s decision was supported by substantial evidence.Â  While the ALC
  judge agreed with the Olsons that several of OCRMâ€™s reasons were insufficient
  as a basis for denial, he concluded that there were two separate bases which
  warranted denial of the permit.Â  We find substantial evidence in the record to
support the ALC judgeâ€™s decision.
In
  determining whether to approve or deny a permit application the Department is
  to base its decision on the individual merits of each application, the policies
  specified in South Carolina Code sections 48-39-20 and 48-39-30, and specified
  statutory general considerations, including â€œ[t]he extent to which the proposed
  use could affect the value and enjoyment of adjacent owners.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  48-39-150(A)(10) (2008).Â  â€œAfter considering the views of interested agencies,
  local governments and persons, and after evaluation of biological and economic
  considerations, if the department finds that the application is not contrary
    to the policies specified in this chapter, it shall issue to the applicant
  a permit.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-39-150(B) (2008) (emphasis added).Â  South
  Carolina Code of Regulations section 30-11(B) includes the same general
  considerations as South Carolina Code Annotated section 48-39-150, with section
  30-11(B)(10) of the Regulations likewise providing the Department must consider
  â€œ[t]he extent to which the proposed use could affect the value and enjoyment of
  adjacent owners.â€ Â 23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. Â§ 30-11(B)(10) (Supp. 2007). Â The Regulations
  further provide that in fulfilling its responsibility under section 48-39-150,
  the Department must also be guided in part by â€œ[t]he extent
  to which long-range, cumulative effects of the project may result within the
  context of other possible development and the general character of the area.â€Â  23A
  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. Â Â§ 30-11(C)(1) (Supp. 2007).Â  The ALC judge determined
  both the impact on adjacent owners and the long-range cumulative effects of the
  project warranted denial of the permit.
In the present
  case, there is evidence that the dock as proposed by the Olsons would have to
  come through some trees and run down the drainage ditch easement border between
  the Olson and Ball property lines, and that there was no cove or other such
  area as depicted in the Olsonsâ€™ permit application.[6]Â 
  The dock would then have to â€œbendâ€ at a right angle to head out toward the
  water.Â  Additionally, the Olsonsâ€™ proposed dock and pier would be in very close
  proximity to existing docks and piers.Â  Specifically, the proposed Olson dock
  would have to run between the Ball dock and Sims/McCown dock and would be as
  close as seven feet from the Ball dock and forty-four feet from the Sims
  floating dock.Â  Further, there is an existing piling[7] that is used for mooring and as an area for swimming between the Ball and Sims
  floating docks, and that piling would have to be removed for construction of
  the dock as proposed by the Olsons.Â  McCown testified to safety issues with
  swimming off the docks that would be created by the proposed new dock.Â  Sims
  also testified to safety concerns with boat navigation if another dock were
  allowed in that area.Â  Sims maintained an attempt to place another dock between
  the two existing docks would also lower his property value because of the close
  proximity.Â  Ball likewise testified to the decreased value of her property from
  the proposed Olson dock, stating it would â€œclog up the whole view,â€ make it
  impossible to navigate, impair their ability to swim, kayak and fish from their
  dock, and impede the ability to tie boats up to the side of her dock.Â 
  Accordingly, there is substantial evidence to support the ALC judgeâ€™s finding
  concerning the effect on the adjacent ownersâ€™ value and enjoyment.Â  
There
  is also evidence of record that the proposed Olson dock would have long-range,
  cumulative effects within the context of other possible development and the
  general character of the area.Â  McCown testified allowing the Olsons to build a
  dock there would open it up to others being able to build a dock down any ditch
  that runs to the Intracoastal Waterway.Â  Sims expressed concern that building a
  dock in that location could block the easement and jeopardize maintenance of
  the ditch.Â  Richard Chinnis testified placement of a dock down the drainage
  easement could inhibit the maintenance of the area.Â  He further stated that a
  permit for the proposed Olson dock would violate the definition of waterfront
  property in the Regulations and, assuming adequate room existed to build the
  dock as proposed, the cumulative impact of permitting docks on non-waterfront
  property would cause material harm to the policies of the Act governing the
  permitting process.Â  Thus, there is substantial evidence.
  III.Â  Due Process
The Olsons next
  assert they were not afforded procedural due process.Â  Specifically, they
  maintain they were entitled to direct notice of the Sims/McCown dock permit
  amendment and were not afforded the same.
 When Sims and
  McCown applied to amend their permits to build a joint-use dock, no direct
  notice was sent to the Olsons as adjoining property owners.Â  However, public
  notice for the request was published in the Post and Courier on January 10,
  2004.Â  The amended permit actually reduced the overall square footage of the
  two pier heads, and changed the number of walkways from two to only one.Â 
  Richard Chinnis testified no public notice was required for an amended permit
  if the size of the project was smaller and there was no change in use.Â 
  However, he later acknowledged, generally speaking, if it involves combining
  two permits, â€œit should go on public notice.â€Â  It was never clarified whether
  the newspaper notice sufficed as â€œpublic notice.â€
Assuming
  arguendo the Olsons were entitled to direct notice of the amended application,
  we find no violation of the Olsonsâ€™ due process rights.Â  â€œProcedural due
  process imposes constraints on governmental decisions which deprive individuals
  of liberty or property interests within the meaning of the Due Process Clause
  of the Fifth or Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.â€Â  Kurschner
    v. City of Camden Planning Commâ€™n, 376 S.C. 165, 171, 656 S.E.2d 346, 350
  (2008). Â â€œDue process requires (1) adequate notice; (2) adequate opportunity
  for a hearing; (3) the right to introduce evidence; and (4) the right to
  confront and cross-examine witnesses.â€Â  Clear Channel Outdoor v. City of Myrtle Beach, 372 S.C. 230, 235, 642 S.E.2d 565, 567 (2007).Â  Procedural due process
  requirements are not technical, and no particular form of procedure is
  necessary.Â  Sloan v. S.C. Bd. Of Physical Therapy Examâ€™rs, 370 S.C. 452,
  485, 636 S.E.2d 598, 615 (2006).Â  Rather, due process is flexible and calls for
  such procedural protections as the particular situation demands.Â  Id. Â The fundamental requirement of due process is the opportunity to be heard at a
  meaningful time and in a meaningful manner.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t. of Soc. Servs. v.
    Beeks, 325 S.C. 243, 246, 481 S.E.2d 703, 705 (1997).Â  To prevail on a
  claim of denial of due process, there must be a showing of substantial
  prejudice.Â  Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C.
  430, 435, 319 S.E.2d 695, 698 (1984).
The
  amended permit for the Sims/McCown joint-use dock was issued in February 2004
  and the Olsonâ€™s appealed the approval of the amendment the following month.Â  A
  full hearing was held on the matter before the ALC, where the Olsons challenged
  the joint-use dock permit approved for Sims and McCown.Â  As noted by the ALC
  judge, the Olsons participated extensively in the hearing by eliciting
  testimony, presenting evidence, and confronting witnesses.Â  Thus, the Olsons
  received an opportunity to be heard at a meaningful time and in a meaningful
  manner.Â  Furthermore, no prejudice resulted because the Olsons received
  sufficient notice of the actions of OCRM such that they were able to obtain a
  hearing before the ALC providing them the opportunities required by due
  process.Â  We also agree with the ALC judge the fact that Sims and McCown
  continued construction of the joint-use dock did not violate the Olsonsâ€™ due
  process rights since, had the Olsons been successful in contesting the matter,
  the ALC could have ordered the removal of the dock.Â  Accordingly, we find no
  denial of the Olsonsâ€™ due process rights.Â  
IV.Â  Equal Protection
Finally, the Olsons maintain they were deprived of their right to
  equal protection because Simsâ€™ lot 55 is â€œidentically situatedâ€ to their lot
  56, and the denial of the right to a dock to them is therefore â€œpatently
  unequal treatment.â€Â  We disagree.
Under
  the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States
  Constitution, â€œa state may not â€˜deny to any person within its jurisdiction the
  equal protection of the laws.â€™â€Â  Town
    of Iva ex rel. Zoning Admâ€™r v. Holley, 374 S.C. 537, 540-41, 649 S.E.2d
  108, 110 (Ct. App. 2007) (citing U.S. Const. amend.Â  XIV, Â§ 1).Â  â€œThe sine qua non of an equal
  protection claim is a showing that similarly situated persons received
  disparate treatment.â€Â  Grant v. S.C. Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 354,
  461 S.E.2d 388, 391 (1995).Â  The Olsons claim similarity between lots 55
  and 56, summarily arguing they â€œhave angled lines in the highwater, both would
  fail to reach water before either extended property line reached other land,
  and both got an interest in the Graves permit.â€Â  The Olsons fail, however, to
  cite any evidence of record that support these assertions.Â  Further, as
  previously determined, the Olsonsâ€™ lot has no interest in the dock permit
  originally issued to Graves and transferred to Sims.Â  
At
  any rate, a review of the record reveals substantial differences in the two
  properties.Â  First, the shape and location of the Olsonsâ€™ lot requires the
  dockâ€™s walkway to be placed along a drainage ditch.Â  The Sims/McCown dock does
  not run along the drainage ditch, but runs down their common property line.Â 
  Additionally, an aerial photograph showing the existing Ball and Sims/McCown
  docks submitted into evidence, and used to demonstrate the position of the
  proposed Olson dock, reflects that the Sims/McCown dock runs straight out over
  the marsh and into the Intracoastal Waterway, while the Olson dock would have
  to make a dogleg bend at a right angle to head out toward the water.Â  Chinnis
  testified that OCRM â€œgenerally [does not] let people build sharply angled like
  that off a non-waterfront property.â€Â  Accordingly, the Olsons failed to meet
  their burden of demonstrating they were treated differently from other similarly
  situated landowners and we find no equal protection violation.Â  
Based
  on the foregoing, the decision of the ALC is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] While the Olsons asserted a portion of their property
  bordered a â€œfinger of water,â€ there is evidence of record the area around there
  is â€œhardly ever wetâ€ and there is no cove area to the property as asserted by
the Olsons.Â  
[2] Sims and Ball also testified to their ownership of
  lots 55A and 61A, respectively, which is marshland between their land lots 55
  and 61 and the Intracoastal Waterway.Â  McCown also testified to his ownership
  of the marsh between his lot 54 and the Waterway.Â  While the Olsons contest the
  validity of their ownership of this marshland, we need not address the matter
as it is unnecessary for our determination.Â  
[3] Stephen Graves testified that there was a dock
  contingency clause in the contract on his lot and Blume used a â€œdocking poleâ€
  to the side of lot 61â€™s dock (the Ball dock) to get out of the contract,
claiming the pole interfered with his proposed dock.Â  
[4] OCRM raises the issue of jurisdiction to this court.Â 
  Because the Olsonsâ€™ appeal was pending before the Appellate Panel, not the ALC
  or the circuit court, on the effective date of Act 387 (codified at Â S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 1-23-610 (Supp. 2007)), we find jurisdiction is proper in this court
  pursuant to our supreme courtâ€™s recent decision in Chem-Nuclear Sys., LLC v.
    S.C. Board of Health & Envtl. Control, 374 S.C. 201, 648 S.E.2d 601
(2007). 
[5] Stephen
  Graves testified he was involved with the sale of lot 56 to the Olsons and that
  he never told the Olsons they had a joint-use dock with Sims.Â  He specifically
  informed the Olsons that lot 56 did not have a dock permit and informed Mr.
  Olson â€œa number of timesâ€ that he did not have a right to a dock for that
property.Â  
[6] Stephen
  Graves testified the Olsonsâ€™ lot â€œdoes touch salt marsh on the cornerâ€ but it
  then â€œbecomes the ditch that runs down the property line and all the way
through the main drainage trunk.â€Â  
[7] This piling appears to be the same â€œdocking poleâ€
  Stephen Graves referred to that Blume used as a reason to get out of his
contract to purchase lot 55. Â

title: Power Products and Services Company, Inc. v. Kozma
description: This case involves the issue of personal jurisdiction.  Appellant, Power Products and Services Co., Inc., filed a complaint against the respondents, four individuals and three entities, asserting six causees of action arising from respondents' alleged misappropriation of trade secrets.  Appellant maintained jurisdiction was appropriate in South Carolina, allegeing the acts of the respondents occurrred within this State and the actions complained of are the result of employment based relationships the individual respondents had while associated with appellant.  The trial court granted the respondents' motion for dismissal for lack of personal jurisdiction.  We affirm the trial court's finding that Power Products failed to meet its burden of proving personal jurisdiction under the strictures of due process.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Power Products
          and Services Company, Inc., Appellant,
        v.
        Robert A.
          Kozma, Longdrive Partners, Ltd., Cheryl C. Ferguson, James V. Hobbs, Lakeland
          Engineering Corporation, Timothy H. Montgomery, individually and d/b/a River
          Technologies, LLC, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
  Â Benjamin H. Culbertson, Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 4417
Heard May 6, 2008 â€“ Filed June 20, 2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Richard C. Detwiler and Ian D. McVey, both of Columbia, for
          Appellant.
        David J. Mills, of Georgetown; and Robert L. Widener, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HUFF,
  J.:Â  Power Products and Services
  Company, Inc., (Power Products) appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of Respondentsâ€™[1] motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Power Products is a
  Virginia corporation, formed in 1983, which moved its principal place of
  business to Georgetown, South Carolina in 1998.Â  Power Products provides
  radiological control and decontamination equipment to the nuclear industry.Â 
  The individual Respondents all had some form of working relationship with Power
  Products as employees and/or independent contractors, and had ceased their
  relationship with Power Products at the time this action was initiated.Â 
  Subsequent to this termination of their working relationships, Kozma, Ferguson, Hobbs, and Montgomery formed an entity to distribute products in the nuclear
  power industry and in May 2004 submitted documents to the Virginia State
  Corporation Commission to form River Technologies, LLC.Â  River Technologies
  resells products produced by a manufacturer named Norclean.Â  These products are
  used for the removal of radiological and environmental waste.Â  Power Products
  contends Kozma and Ferguson misappropriated trade secrets during their working
  relationship with Power Products and conspired with the other individual
  respondents to use the misappropriated trade secrets.Â  
Power Products sued
  Respondents, alleging six causes of action:Â  violation of the South Carolina
  Trade Secrets Act, breach of employeeâ€™s duty of loyalty and fidelity, breach of
  employment agreement, breach of contract (specific to Hobbs), breach of the
  duty of good faith and fair dealing, and civil conspiracy.Â  In its complaint,
  Power Products alleged:Â  (1) Kozma resides in Georgetown County and was
  formerly employed by Power Products; (2) Longdrive exists under South Carolina
  laws, has a principal place of business in South Carolina, and is the alter-ego
  of Kozma; (3) Ferguson is a citizen of Virginia and committed the acts
  complained of while employed by Power Products in South Carolina; (4) Hobbs is
  a citizen of Maryland and was a former associate of Power Products, acting as
  an independent contractor; (5) Lakeland is a Maryland corporation and the
  alter-ego of Hobbs; (6) Montgomery is a Virginia citizen and was formerly
  employed by Power Products; (7) River technologies is a de facto partnership of one or more defendants; and (8) the complained of acts occurred
  in South Carolina. Â In particular, Power Products alleged that Kozma and
  Ferguson were terminated in or around July 2003 and, â€œon information and
  belief had already misappropriated all of the Trade Secrets of Power Products
  with a plan toward opening a competitive business.â€Â  
Respondents moved to dismiss based on a lack of
  personal jurisdiction, asserting each were citizens or corporate citizens of a
  state other than South Carolina and there was an insufficient nexus from their
  actions to support jurisdiction in this state.Â  Respondents submitted
  affidavits in support of their motion to dismiss.Â  Fergusonâ€™s affidavit shows
  she is a citizen and resident of Virginia and was employed with Power Products
  from July 1992 through July 2003.Â  She worked solely in Virginia from 1992
  until 1999, at which time she began to commute to South Carolina to work during
  the week, but maintained her residency in Virginia, continued to perform some
  of her work duties from her home in Virginia, and filed for unemployment in Virginia following her termination from Power Products in July 2003.Â  Kozma filed an
  affidavit averring that he is a citizen and resident of Virginia and has been
  since September 2003.Â  From November 1993 to March 1994 and from November 2001
  to September 2003, Kozma performed services for Power Products in his capacity
  as an employee of Longdrive, a New York corporation that served as a marketing
  and sales consultant for Power Products.Â  Hobbsâ€™ affidavit indicates he is a
  citizen and resident of Maryland and has never been a resident of South Carolina.Â  He was associated with Power Products as an independent contractor through
  Lakeland, a Maryland corporation that performed certain engineering services
  for Power Products.Â  Lakeland last performed services for Power Products in May
  2003.Â  Finally, Montgomeryâ€™s affidavit indicates he is a citizen and resident
  of Virginia, never having resided in South Carolina.Â  He was formerly employed
  by Power Products in a sales capacity from 1986 to 1994, during which time he
  was always based in Virginia.Â  South Carolina was never included in his sales
  territory.Â  Power Products terminated his employment in 1994 after Montgomery suffered a back injury, and he has had no contact with Power Products since
  that time.Â  
Power Products
  maintained jurisdiction was proper in South Carolina because (1) many of
  Respondentsâ€™ tortious actions occurred while Respondents were in South Carolina
  and (2) the respondents have minimum contacts with South Carolina because they
  were current or former residents of this state, they committed numerous torts
  in this state, and they are using the misappropriated trade secrets to sell or
  attempt to sell their products in this state.Â  Power Products submitted the affidavits
  of Al Burns and Jeffrey R. Rogers to support its contention Respondents were
  misappropriating Power Productsâ€™ trade secrets and conducting business in South Carolina.Â  Power Products further included within its filings a printout of River
  Technologiesâ€™ website, to show River Technologies was currently doing business
  or attempting to do business in South Carolina.Â  Lastly, Power Products
  submitted a decree of divorce showing Kozma had lived with his wife in South Carolina until their separation in July 2003.Â  
The trial court
  granted Respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.Â  The
  court found â€œall Defendants are out-of-state residents and have so
  resided at all times pertinent to this litigationâ€ and the â€œentities named as Defendants
  are likewise corporate citizens of other states.â€Â  Further, the court found
  Power Products is a corporation organized and registered in Virginia.Â 
  Additionally, the trial court stated:

  [Power
    Products] argues that if [Respondents] are competing in the nuclear industry,
    they must be doing so using trade secrets taken from [Power Products].Â 
    However, this Court finds such conclusory statements an insufficient basis for
    the assertion of in personam jurisdiction.Â  The record establishes that
    fewer than seventy-two (72) nuclear power facilities exist in the United
    States, and the existence of these facilities (and their purchasing
    departments) are in no way â€œsecretâ€ or â€œconfidential.â€Â  The record further
    reflects that there are presently four or five businesses which compete with
    [Power Products] in the nuclear market.Â  The Court thus rejects [Power
    Productsâ€™] argument that all nuclear industry sites are â€œits customersâ€ and any
    contact with them constitutes evidence that these [Respondents] misappropriated
    trade secrets.Â  Moreover, [Power Products] did not submit any evidence that the
    â€œoff the shelfâ€ products re-sold by the [Respondents] were products developed
    pursuant to anything â€œtakenâ€ from [Power Products].

The trial court held Power
  Productsâ€™ â€œconclusory allegations fail to establish the contacts necessary to
  invoke personal jurisdiction over these [Respondents] either generally or
  specifically.â€Â  After analyzing the matter under South Carolinaâ€™s Long-Arm
  Statute and under due process requirements, the court concluded Power Products
  failed to establish the necessary requisites to confer jurisdiction pursuant to
  both this stateâ€™s Long-Arm Statute and the minimum contacts required to afford
  due process.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Personal
  jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant is a question to be resolved upon the
  facts of each particular case.Â  Cockrell v.
    Hillerich & Bradsby Co., 363 S.C. 485,
  491, 611 S.E.2d 505, 508 (2005).Â  â€œThe decision of the trial court
  should be affirmed unless unsupported by the evidence or influenced by error of
  law.â€Â  Id.Â  The party seeking to invoke personal jurisdiction over a
  non-resident defendant by using South Carolinaâ€™s long-arm statute bears the
  burden of establishing jurisdiction.Â  S. Plastics Co. v. S. Commerce
    Bank, 310 S.C. 256, 259, 423 S.E.2d
    128, 130 (1992).Â â€œAt the pretrial stage, the burden of proving personal
  jurisdiction over a nonresident is met by a prima facie showing of jurisdiction
  either in the complaint or in affidavits.â€Â  Moosally v. W.W. Norton &
    Co., 358 S.C. 320, 328, 594 S.E.2d 878, 882 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  When a
  nonresident defendant attacks the allegations of a complaint based on
  jurisdiction, the court is not confined to the allegations of the complaint but
  may resort to affidavits or other evidence to determine jurisdiction.Â  Coggeshall
    v. Reprod. Endocrine Assocs. of Charlotte, 376 S.C. 12, 16, 655 S.E.2d 476,
  478 (2007).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Power
  Products maintains the trial court erred in finding it lacked personal
  jurisdiction over the Respondents.Â  We disagree.
Traditionally, our courts have employed a two-step
  analysis in determining whether it is proper to exercise personal jurisdiction
  over a nonresident defendant.Â  S. Plastics Co. v. S. Commerce Bank, 310
  S.C. 256, 423 S.E.2d 128 (1992). Â First, the trial
  court must determine that the South Carolina long-arm statute applies.Â  Second,
  the trial court must determine that the nonresidentâ€™s contacts in South Carolina are sufficient to satisfy due process requirements.Â  Id.Â  However,
  both this court and our Supreme Court have noted our long-arm statute, which affords broad
  power to exercise personal jurisdiction over causes of action arising from
  tortious injuries in South Carolina, has been construed to extend to the outer
  limits of the due process clause. Â Cockrell v. Hillerich & Bradsby Co.,
  363 S.C. 485, 491, 611 S.E.2d 505, 508 (2005); Moosally v. W.W. Norton &
    Co., 358 S.C. 320, 329, 594 S.E.2d 878, 883 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Accordingly,
  our courts have held, because we treat our long-arm statute as coextensive with
  the due process clause, the sole question becomes whether the exercise of
  personal jurisdiction in this case would violate the strictures of due process.
  Â Id. Â See alsoÂ  Sonoco Prods. Co. v. Inteplast Corp.,
  867 F.Supp. 352, 354 (D.S.C. 1994) (holding our long-arm statute has been
  interpreted to reach the limits of due process and therefore the determination
  of personal jurisdiction in South Carolina compresses into a due process
  assessment of minimum contacts and fair play).Â  Whether employing the
  traditional two-step analysis, or following the more recent determination that
  the analysis is compressed into a due process assessment alone, it is clear
  that personal jurisdiction over a
  non-resident defendant may be invoked only if the
  nonresidentâ€™s contacts in South Carolina are sufficient to satisfy due process
  requirements.Â  Because we agree with the trial court that Power Products failed
  to meet its burden of proving personal jurisdiction under the strictures of due
  process, we affirm. Â 
Due process requires that there exist minimum contacts between the
  defendant and the forum state such that maintenance of the suit does not offend
  traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.Â  Cockrell, 363
  S.C. at 491, 611 S.E.2d at 508.Â  Further, the due process requirement mandates
  the defendant possess sufficient minimum contacts with the forum state such
  that he could reasonably anticipate being haled into court there.Â  Id. at 491-92, 611 S.E.2d at 508.
In
  determining whether due process minimum contacts exist between the defendant
  and the forum state such that maintenance of the suit does not offend
  traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice, a two pronged
  analysis is applied.Â  S. Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 260, 423 S.E.2d at 131.Â  The court must (1) find
  that the defendant has the requisite minimum contacts with the forum, without which,
  the court does not have the â€œpowerâ€ to adjudicate the action and (2) find the
  exercise of jurisdiction is reasonable or fair.Â  Id.Â  â€œIf either prong fails, the exercise
  of personal jurisdiction over the defendant fails to comport with the
  requirements of due process.â€Â  Id.

  Under the power prong, a minimum contacts analysis requires a
    court to find that the defendant directed its activities to residents of South Carolina and that the cause of action arises out of or relates to those activities.Â  Without
    minimum contacts, the court does not have the â€œpowerâ€ to adjudicate the action.Â 
    It is essential in each case that there be some act by which the defendant
    purposefully avails itself of the privilege of conducting activities within the
    forum state, thus invoking the benefits and protections of its laws.Â  The
    â€œpurposeful availmentâ€ requirement ensures that a defendant will not be haled
    into a jurisdiction solely as a result of random, fortuitous, or attenuated
    contacts.Â  Whether the constitutional requirement of minimum contacts has been
    met depends on the facts of each case.

Moosally, 358 S.C. at 331-332, 594 S.E.2d at 884-885 (internal
  citations omitted).
In order to
  determine whether the exercise of jurisdiction over a foreign defendant meets
  the fairness prong, the court must consider the following:Â  (1) the duration of
  the activity of the nonresident within the state; (2) the character and
  circumstances of the commission of the nonresidentâ€™s acts; (3) the
  inconvenience resulting to the parties by conferring or refusing to confer
  jurisdiction over the nonresident; and (4) the Stateâ€™s interest in exercising
  jurisdiction.Â  Cockrell, 363 S.C. at 492, 611 S.E.2d at 508.Â  A single
  act that causes harm in this State may create sufficient minimum contacts to
  confer jurisdiction where the harm arises out of or relates to that act.Â  S.
    Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 260-61, 423 S.E.2d at 131.Â  However, that single
  act must create a â€œsubstantial connectionâ€ with the forum to give rise to
  jurisdiction.Â  Moosally, 358 S.C. at 331, 594 S.E.2d at 884.Â  
A.Â  Power ProngÂ  
Power
  Products asserts it showed the requisite minimum contacts under the power
  prong. It contends the majority of Respondentsâ€™ tortious acts occurred in South Carolina and the alleged duration and frequency of the acts were sufficient to
  satisfy due process.Â  Power Products further maintains it presented evidence
  Respondents were doing business in South Carolina. Â We disagree.
As
  to the assertion the tortious acts occurred in South Carolina, the trial court
  found Power Products failed to allege specific facts to support its conclusory
  allegation that Respondents took the trade secrets in South Carolina, and
  further found the Respondentsâ€™ affidavits actually support the opposite
  conclusion.Â  In particular, the court noted Fergusonâ€™s affidavit shows she was
  unexpectedly terminated on a Sunday and was not allowed to return to Power
  Productsâ€™ facility.Â  Because she did not anticipate being fired, she had no
  opportunity to take anything from the company.Â  While Power Products contends
  that Kozma and Ferguson had already misappropriated the trade secrets of Power
  Products with a plan toward opening a competitive business prior to their termination,
  we find absolutely no support for this conclusory assertion. Â Further, as did
  the trial court, we find the case of Drayton Enters., L.L.C. v. Dunker,
  142 F.Supp.2d 1177 (D.N.D. 2001) particularly instructive and applicable. 
In Drayton,
  the United States District Court for the District of North Dakota analyzed a
  similar personal jurisdiction issue.Â  There, defendants were Value-Added
  Products (VAP), an Oklahoma cooperative based in Oklahoma, and VAPâ€™s employee,
  Dunker, who was a former employee of Drayton.Â  Id. at 1180.Â  Drayton, a North Dakota based company, initiated litigation alleging Dunker had disclosed trade
  secrets to VAP and VAP had wrongfully obtained the trade secrets.Â  Id.Â  Drayton alleged that Dunker revealed its trade secrets to VAP and VAP hired him
  with the secrets in mind.Â  The court found there seemed to be no argument that
  if Dunker did reveal any secrets to VAP, he did so in Oklahoma after he was
  hired by VAP.Â  Id. Â at 1184.Â  Thus, the only direct connection between
  the litigation and the defendantsâ€™ actions was the injury caused by the alleged
  tort to be felt in North Dakota.Â  Id.Â  The court held the tort was
  allegedly committed in Oklahoma, not North Dakota, because until Dunker
  revealed the information and VAP used it, no tort had been committed.Â  Id.Â  In the case at hand, Respondentsâ€™ affidavits establish that the concept
  to form a business entity to do business in the nuclear field did not occur
  until well after all of the Respondents had severed their working relationships
  with Power Products and the individual defendants all resided in states other
  than South Carolina.Â  While Kozma and/or Ferguson may have received such
  information during their work for Power Products in South Carolina, they could
  only have misappropriated it for use in the new company after their working
  relationships with Power Products were terminated and their connections to South Carolina severed.Â  There is no specific allegation or showing that Ferguson and/or
  Kozma revealed, and River Technologies used, the allegedly misappropriated
  trade secrets prior to their termination of employment with Power Products. 
Power
  Products relies on the printout of River Technologiesâ€™ website, to show River
  Technologies was currently doing business or attempting to do business in South Carolina.Â  In particular, it points to language on the website which states, â€œOur
  relationships extend to every commercial nuclear plant in the United States and Canada, a majority of US Government DOE and DOD sites, and several large industrial
  manufacturers. . . .â€ Â However, as noted by the trial court, Power Products
  failed to make any allegations or produce any evidence a South Carolina
  resident purchased any product from or because of River Technologiesâ€™ website,
  or that the website was particularly directed at South Carolinians.Â  See Brown v. Geha-Werke GmbH, 69 F.Supp.2d 770, 777-78 (D.S.C. 1999)
  (holding the critical inquiry in such a matter is the nature and quality of
  commercial activity conducted by an entity over the Internet in the forum
  state, and where the record failed to reflect any commercial activity over the
  Internet in South Carolina and plaintiff failed to submit evidence any South
  Carolina resident, other than the staff of plaintiffâ€™s attorneyâ€™s law firm,
  visited the entityâ€™s website or purchased any product over or because of the
  website, or that the website was directed at South Carolina any more than any
  other place, the entityâ€™s website did not provide the basis for an assertion of
  personal jurisdiction).Â  
Power
  Products also relies on the affidavit of Al Burns, the former director of the
  Planning Commission for Economic Development in Georgetown County.Â  In his affidavit, Mr. Burns states that Kozma informed him in August 2004 he had
  opened a new company in Virginia that would be in the same business as Power
  Products â€œand that he might be looking at moving the company down to Georgetown.â€ Â (emphasis added).Â  Mr. Burns further stated Kozma informed him he was
  interested in playing in an annual golf tournament â€œas a prospective new
  industrial client representing his new Virginia business.â€Â  At most, this
  affidavit merely suggests Respondents considered doing business in South Carolina, not that they actually did business in South Carolina.Â  Accordingly, Power
  Products failed to meet its burden of establishing Respondents directed activities to residents of South Carolina and that
  the cause of action arises out of or relates to those activities, and therefore
  failed to meet the requirements of the â€œpower prong.â€
B.Â  Fairness
  Prong
Power Products contends the court may properly exercise
  jurisdiction under the fairness prong.Â  It argues it has its principal place of
  business in South Carolina and that much of the evidence and many of the
  witnesses are located in South Carolina.Â  Power Products further maintains
  Respondents are all either former residents of the state or have lived and/or
  worked in this state for extended periods of time.
As noted by the trial court, River Technologiesâ€™ principal place
  of business is in Virginia.Â  It does not have offices or employees in South Carolina, and there is no evidence it has any customers in this state.Â  None of the
  Respondent entities are corporations of this state and none of the individual
  Respondents are residents or citizens of South Carolina.Â  While Ferguson worked for Power Products in South Carolina for approximately four years out of
  her eleven year employment with Power Products, she continued to maintain her
  residency in Virginia the entire time.Â  Both Hobbsâ€™ and Montgomeryâ€™s affidavits
  show they have never been residents of South Carolina.Â  Montgomery lives in Virginia and Hobbs lives in Maryland.Â  Only Kozma resided in South Carolina, and his
  affidavit shows he became a citizen of Virginia in early September 2003.Â  We agree with the trial court that the Respondentsâ€™
  limited working relationship with Power Products is not a sufficient nexus to
  satisfy due process.Â  We also agree with the trial
  court that the mere fact that the alleged injury may be felt in South Carolina is insufficient to support jurisdiction under the facts of this case.Â  As
  noted, the alleged tortious conduct of the Respondents could not
  have occurred until after Ferguson and Kozmaâ€™s relationships were severed with
  Power Products and they revealed, and River Technologies used, the allegedly
  misappropriated trade secrets. Â At this time, their connections to South Carolina had been severed.Â  Further, it is uncontested that
  Power Products, despite the fact that it maintains its principal place of
  business in South Carolina, is still a Virginia corporation, organized and
  existing pursuant to Virginia law.Â  Accordingly, under the facts of this
  case, we do not believe this stateâ€™s exercise of jurisdiction over the
  Respondents would be reasonable or fair.
CONCLUSION
We hold Power Products failed to establish sufficient minimum
  contacts of any of the Respondentsâ€™ to indicate purposeful availment of the
  privilege of conducting activities within this state such that they should be
  haled into court in this state. Nor did Power Products meet its burden of
  showing Respondentsâ€™ had such minimum contacts that exercise of jurisdiction is
  reasonable or fair. Â Consequently, the evidence supports the trial
  courtâ€™s findings that Power Products did not establish facts sufficient to
  confer jurisdiction over Respondents.Â  For the foregoing reasons, we find the
  trial court did not err by dismissing Power Productsâ€™ action for lack of
  personal jurisdiction.Â  Accordingly, the trial court is
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON and
  KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Robert A. Kozma (Kozma), Longdrive Partners, Ltd.
  (Longdrive), Cheryl C. Ferguson (Ferguson), James V. Hobbs (Hobbs), Lakeland
  Engineering Corporation (Lakeland), Timothy H. Montgomery (Montgomery),
individually and d/b/a River Technologies, LLC (River Technologies), hereinafter Respondents, collectively.Â
