THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Yoko Kim
          Melton, Respondent,
        v.
        Chong Olenik
          a/k/a Chong Son Kim, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
  Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 4418
  Heard April 16, 2008 â€“ Filed June 20,
2008Â Â  

REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        David Christopher Shea and Rebecca Guental Fulmer, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Stephen D. Schusterman, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PIEPER, J.: Chong Son Kim (Kim) appeals the circuit
  courtâ€™s order denying her motion to set aside entry of default and denying
  relief from default judgment.Â  We reverse in part and remand for further
  proceedings.Â  Â 
FACTS
Yoko Kim Melton (Melton) and Kim entered
  into an agreement in which Melton would purchase a one-half interest in Kimâ€™s
  massage therapy business, â€œOur Place.â€[1]Â 
  The agreement, signed by both parties on January 9, 2002, indicates a purchase
  price of $30,000, due in full within one year of the date of the agreement.[2]Â  Melton was to work in the business
  and learn the operations for one year at which point Kim would turn over the
  one-half interest to Melton.[3]Â 
  However, at the end of the year, Kim did not turn over the one-half interest to
  Melton.Â  
Melton filed a summons and complaint and
  served Kim on November 30, 2005.Â  Kim failed to answer.[4]Â  On March 1, 2006, Melton filed a
  motion seeking entry of default and a default judgment in the amount of
  $50,000.Â  Default was entered against Kim on June 6, 2006, but the court
  continued the damages hearing, expressing concern that Kim had not been
  properly served with notice of the hearing. Â A damages hearing was scheduled
  for July 19, 2006, and Kim was served notice of the damages hearing.Â  Kim filed
  a motion to set aside default and, with Meltonâ€™s consent, the damages hearing
  was continued.Â  Kim moved to set aside default for good cause, inadvertence,
  and excusable neglect on the grounds that: (a) she had only recently become
  aware of the suit against her and no hearing on damages had been held; (b) she
  had a meritorious defense; and (c) there would be no prejudice to Melton.Â  
A
  hearing on Kimâ€™s motion was held on November 13, 2006.Â  The court denied the
  motion to set aside the entry of default and immediately proceeded to hear
  Meltonâ€™s testimony in support of her motion for default judgment.Â  Melton and
  Kim are Korean and they both have a limited proficiency in the English
  language.Â  As such, Melton requested the use of an interpreter she brought with
  her to the hearing.Â  Kim objected to the use of that particular interpreter and
  requested the use of a joint court interpreter.[5]Â 
  The court performed a voir dire of the interpreter to determine her
  experience.Â  After the voir dire, the court asked if there was any objection.Â 
  Kim objected to the interpreter and requested a South Carolina court certified
  interpreter.Â  The court commenced the hearing without any interpreter.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
On the
  basis of Meltonâ€™s testimony, the court found Melton was entitled to a default
  judgment in the amount of $50,000.Â  Kim filed a Rule 59(e) motion, arguing
  default should be set aside, or in the alternative, the default judgment should
  be vacated and she should be granted a new hearing on damages with a qualified
  interpreter.Â  The court summarily denied the motion.Â  This appeal follows.[6] 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Kim argues the
  circuit court erred in denying relief from the default judgment.Â  We agree.
The power to set
  aside a default judgment is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court
  and will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear showing of an abuse of
  discretion.Â  Mitchell Supply Co., Inc. v. Gaffney, 297 S.C. 160, 162-63,
  375 S.E.2d 321, 322-23 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  An abuse of discretion arises when the
  court issuing the order was controlled by an error of law or when the order,
  based upon factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.Â  Goodson v.
    Am. Bankers Ins. Co. of Fla., 295 S.C. 400, 402, 368 S.E.2d 687, 689 (Ct.
  App. 1988).Â  Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the present
  case, Kim asserts the court erred in denying the motion to set aside the
  default judgment on the grounds that: (1) the evidence presented of Kimâ€™s
  inadvertence and excusable neglect justified relief under Rule 60(b)(1), SCRCP;
  (2) the court relied upon incompetent parol evidence and the court's subsequent
  award of damages is without evidentiary support and was controlled by an error
  of law; and (3) the courtʼs refusal to accommodate her request for a
  qualified court interpreter violated statutory law and deprived her of equal
  access to justice and to the court proceedings.
We first address
  the issue on appeal as to the request for an interpreter.Â  Pursuant to Section
  15-27-155(A) of the South Carolina Code (2005): 

  [W]henever
    a party or witness to a civil legal proceeding does not sufficiently speak the
    English language to testify, the court may appoint a qualified interpreter to
    interpret the proceedings and the testimony of the party or witness.Â  However,
    the court may waive the use of a qualified interpreter if the court finds that
    it is not necessary for the fulfillment of justice.Â  The court must first make a finding on the record that the waiver of a qualified interpreter
    is in the best interest of the party or witness and that this action is in the
    best interest of justice.Â  

(Emphasis added).Â  In this
  case, both parties have limited English proficiency and expressed concern with
  a possible language barrier before the hearing.Â  When Kim objected to the use
  of the interpreter Melton brought to the hearing, Melton agreed to an alternate
  qualified court interpreter.Â  The court performed a voir dire of the
  interpreter to determine her experience and abilities, after which Kim renewed
  the objection to the use of that particular interpreter.Â  Kim requested a South Carolina qualified court interpreter but the court refused that request.Â  Rather than proceeding with the
  interpreter Melton provided, the court held the damages hearing without the use of any interpreter.Â  Before proceeding
  to the hearing, the court failed to make any findings under the statute that
  waiver of the use of a qualified interpreter was in the best interest of the
  party, or witness, or that it was in the best interest of justice.Â  We find the
  courtâ€™s decision to proceed without the use of a qualified interpreter without
  making any findings on the record that it was in the best interest of the
  party, witness, or justice was legal error.Â  
Further,
  we find proceeding without the use of an interpreter prejudiced Kim. Â At the
  hearing, Melton attempted to explain the transaction and exchange of money.Â  However,
  the testimony is confusing and at times incoherent, such that both attorneys
  and the judge often sought further clarification of Meltonâ€™s statements.Â  For
  example: 

  
    Q. 
    (Melton’s Attorney)  You gave her $50,000?
  
  
    A. 
     (Melton):  Yes 
  
  
    Q.
    Okay. And what were you supposed to get for
  that 50,000? What were you getting? 
  
  
    A.
    She go – she go sign the $30,000 contract
  promissory, and she gave me two check, two checks.  One each check is $25, $25
a total of $50,000.  She gave me check.
  
  
    Q.
    Okay. Why did she give you two checks for
  $25,000 if you paid her 50,000? 
  
  
    A.
    Because we help a partner asked – she wanted
  $50,000.  Then I’m thinking $50,000, she going to promise a contract.  But she
  go lawyer office.  She say $30,000. Why?  I ask you, why $30,000? I don’t trust
  her.  That’s why I want your check. Give it to me.  Any time you don’t give me
  help, partner, I want my money back. 
  
  
    Q. 
     Okay. So that was in case you didn’t get your
  half, if she didn’t let you have your half?
  
  
    A. 
    She don’t give it to me. She no money back,
  too. 
  
  
    Q.
    How did you give her the $50,000?
  
  
    A.  
     She – I give her money.  She give me check,
  two checks. Mh-hmm (affirmative) 
  
  
    Q.
     Okay.
  
  
    THE COURT: 
     I don’t think she understood the
  question.
  
  
    Q. 
    Okay.
  
  
    THE COURT:
    Because I have the same question.
  
  
    
    . . . 
    
  
  
    
    Q.  
    
    You paid her $50,000?
  
  
    A. 
    Yes, sir. 
  
  
    Q. 
    How did you give her the money? Was it in
  cash?  Or was it a check? How did you give it to her? 
  
  
    A. 
    Oh.  I got something in the – the bank check
  and cash it, too.  But she want, everything wanted cash.  That’s why I don’t
  trust her, is I go to a lawyer office.  It’s a notarizer and helping making
  sure.  That’s why I want two checks, 25,000, 25,000, two checks.  I needed
  this.  Then she gave it to me.  
  

At
  the close of Meltonâ€™s direct examination her attorney states, â€œ[y]our Honor, I
  donâ€™t â€“ I â€“ it may be that we need to get a translator if â€“ I donâ€™t know if the
  Court is following whatâ€™s going on.Â  I donâ€™t know that I can get any more
detail because of the language barrier.â€ 
The
  following testimony was elicited during cross-examination of Melton:

  
    Q. 
     (Kim’s Attorney)  Yeah.  What proof do you
  have that you gave her $50,000? 
  
  
    A. 
    (Melton)  They have a – it’s a – I have a
  contract  promise to pay her for that. 
  
  
    Q.  
    Where is that? 
  
  
    A.  
    Where is that? Okay. And two checks.  And
  there is – one of them is $30,000.  One year.  It’s a contract promise.  And I
  give her 50,000.  That’s why, you know, she don’t – she give – she – she a
  liar.  So I don’t trust her.  I need the two check, $50,000.  Mm-hmm
  (affirmative).
  
  
    Q.
    You gave her a check for $50,000?
  
  
    A.
     (Shakes head negatively). 
  
  
    Q.
    Did you give her cash? 
  
  
    A. 
    No. She give me two check. Mm-hmm
  (affirmative). 
  

The
following testimony was further elicited:

  
    Q.
     (Kim’s Attorney)  Okay.   Well, ma’am, it goes
  back to my original question of, do you have any proof whatsoever that you
  actually gave her $50,000?
  
  
    A. 
    Because she wanted to have to share $50,000.
  Mm-hmm (affirmative). 
  
  
    THE COURT: 
    Ma’am, let me – did you give her
  $50,000? 
  
  
    A. 
    Yes, sir. 
  
  
    THE COURT: 
    Cash?
  
  
    A. 
    She wanted cash.  But it’s a -- everything had
  to prove money. Mm-hmm (affirmative).
  
  
    THE COURT:
    Did you give her cash? 
  
  
    A. 
    Yes. She wanted cash. 
  
  
    THE COURT:
    You gave her cash? 
  
  
    A. 
    Yes. 
  
  
    Q.
    (Kim’s Attorney)  Ma’am, do you have any sort
  of withdrawal slip from your bank showing that you took out $50,000?
  
  
    A. 
    
    But I don’t give her $50,000.  She don’t sign
  anything.  She don’t give me check. 
  
  
  
    . . . 
     
  
  
    
    Q. 
    
      Do you have any way to prove that you gave her
  $50,000 in cash? 
  
  
    A.
     Yes, sir. 
  
  
    Q.
    What is that proof? 
  
  
    A.
     I have to talk?
  
  
    Q.
     You’re telling us that’s your proof?
  
  
    A.
    Yes.  But I don’t – I don’t have to talk to
  you.  Mm-hmm (affirmative). 
  

Notwithstanding
  the contradictory statements and incoherent testimony of Melton and the lack of
  an interpreter to assist with the language barrier, the court ultimately
  ordered default judgment against Kim for $50,000.Â  We find Meltonâ€™s inability
  to convey the facts of the transaction during the hearing, due to her limited
  English proficiency and the lack of an interpreter, prejudiced Kim and affected
her ability to contest the damages.
Therefore,
  we find the court committed an error of law and thus abused its discretion in regard
  to the interpreter issue.Â  We reverse and remand for a new damages hearing at
  which time the court shall direct that a qualified interpreter must be present
  or alternatively, the court must make the necessary findings of waiver under
  the statute.[7]
Kim also argues the
  circuit court erred in failing to set aside the entry of default as provided
  under Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  Since we have already determined a remand is
  appropriate due to the interpreter issue, we also find a remand as to this
  issue is appropriate.
Under Rule 55(c) of
  the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, a default may be set aside â€œfor
  good cause shown.â€Â  Rule 55(c) should be â€œliberally construed to promote
  justice and dispose of cases on the merits.â€Â  Bage v. Southeastern Roofing
    Co. of Spartanburg, Inc., 373 S.C. 457, 471, 646 S.E.2d 153, 160 (Ct. App. 2007), cert. granted (Mar. 20, 2008). Â The decision whether to grant relief
  from an entry of default is solely within the sound discretion of the trial
  court.Â  Wham v. Shearson Lehman Bros., Inc., 298 S.C. 462, 465, 381
  S.E.2d 499, 501 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  On appeal, this court cannot substitute its
  judgment for that of the trial judge and will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s
  decision absent a clear showing of abuse of discretion.Â  Ricks v. Weinrauch,
  293 S.C. 372, 374, 360 S.E.2d 535, 536 (Ct. App. 1987).Â Â  An abuse of
  discretion arises when the judgeâ€™s decision was controlled by some error of law
  or lacks evidentiary support.Â Â  Boland v. S.C. Public Service Authority,
  281 S.C. 293, 295, 315 S.E.2d 143, 145 (Ct. App. 1984).
In deciding whether
  to set aside an entry of default, the court should consider the following
  factors: (1) the timing of the motion for relief; (2) whether the defendant has
  a meritorious defense; and (3) the degree of prejudice to the plaintiff if
  relief is granted.Â  Wham, 298 S.C. at 465, 381 S.E.2d at 501-02.Â  Kim
  argues the court failed to weigh the Wham factors relevant to her
  motion.Â  Specifically, Kim contends the only factor the court relied upon and
  cited was the timing of the motion for relief.
  â€œ[I]t is not
  necessary for the trial judge to make specific findings in regard to the
  factors enumerated in Wham.Â  This court has held â€˜[t]he trial judge will
  not be reversed for failing to make specific findings of fact on the record for
  each factor if there is sufficient evidentiary support in the record for the
  finding of the lack of good cause.â€™â€ Bage, 373 S.C. at 472, 646 S.E.2d
  at 161 (citing Dixon v. Besco Engineering, 320 S.C. 174, 179, 463 S.E.2d
  636, 639 (Ct. App. 1995)).Â Â  
Arguably, in this
  case, over seven months elapsed between the time Kim was served with the
  summons and complaint and when she moved for relief.Â  As indicated, Kim
  acknowledged the receipt of the envelope in November 2005, but never looked at
  the papers served upon her and claimed the envelope was placed in her purse and
  was subsequently stolen.Â  On the other hand, Kim filed her motion a little over
  one month from being notified of the entry of default.Â  We recognize both of
  these time periods are relevant to the consideration of the motion to set aside
  the entry of default.Â  The trial judge cited in his order that â€œthe defendant
  failed to file a motion for relief from the entry of default until some five
  (5) months after said entry and more than thirty (30) days after she received
  notification for the damages hearing.â€Â  This factual finding is clearly
  erroneous based upon the record.Â  Default was entered on June 6, 2006, and
  mailed to the parties on June 7, 2006.Â  The motion to set aside the entry of
  default was filed on July 17, 2006.Â  We recognize this statement may have been
  a clerical error on the part of the court.
Although we review
  this matter under an abuse of discretion standard, we find a remand is
  appropriate to allow the court an opportunity to clarify or reconsider any
  findings on the motion to set aside the entry of default in light of the
  courtâ€™s erroneous factual finding or clerical error. We simply cannot determine
  whether the trial court, in the exercise of its discretion, relied solely on an
  erroneous factual finding or whether that finding was merely a clerical error
  on the issue of delay and the court relied on the other Wham factors.Â 
  Although we recognize the court is not required to make findings as to each
  factor, we find it problematic to determine here whether the judge properly
  exercised the discretion afforded under the law since the other Wham factors were not discussed. Â Â Since we already have determined a remand is
  appropriate as to the default judgment damages hearing due to the interpreter
  issue, we think fairness suggests that the judge also be afforded an
  opportunity to clarify or revisit this matter on remand since the judge is
  vested with the discretionary review in the first instance.Â  The judge, upon
  making that determination, shall proceed in accordance with that determination
  as well as in accordance with the opinion herein.
Due to our
  disposition of these issues, we need not address the remaining issues on
  appeal.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling
  an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a
  prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
CONCLUSION
We respectfully
  find the courtâ€™s decision to proceed without the use of a qualified interpreter
  without making any findings on the record that it was in the best interest of
  the party, witness, or justice was legal error and we therefore reverse and
  remand as to this issue since we find prejudice to the appellant. Â We also
  remand for further proceedings on the motion to set aside the entry of default
  due to the courtâ€™s reliance on either an erroneous factual finding or a clerical
  error so that the court may be afforded the initial opportunity to exercise its
  discretion without consideration of this erroneous finding or clerical error.Â 
  Once a redetermination of the motion to set aside the entry of default is made,
  the court shall proceed based on that determination and in accordance with our
  opinion.Â  The decision of the circuit court is accordingly
REVERSED
  IN PART AND REMANDED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.


[1] There is some discrepancy as to what business Melton
was purchasing.Â  Melton describes the business as being located in Columbia, South Carolina, whereas Kimâ€™s Answer indicates the business was located in Augusta, Georgia.Â  
[2] Meltonâ€™s complaint and motion for default with
  attached affidavit allege a purchase price of $50,000.Â  Further, at trial
  Melton testified she was owed $50,000, but did not explain the discrepancy
  between the alleged $50,000 purchase price and the $30,000 purchase price
indicated in the agreement.Â  
[3] Again, there is some confusion as to what interest
  Melton agreed to purchase.Â  The agreement indicates Melton was to receive a
  one-half interest in the business, whereas Meltonâ€™s affidavit indicates she was
to receive full ownership of the business. Â 
[4] Kim acknowledged receiving and signing for an
  envelope in November 2005, as she was on her way out of town to visit her
  ailing sister.Â  She recalled placing the envelope in her purse which she
  alleged was subsequently stolen from her sonâ€™s car.Â  She further explained she failed
to look at the contents of the envelope before it was stolen. Â Â 
[5] Melton
agreed to the use of a joint court interpreter.Â Â  
[6] Kim did not actually seek relief under Rule 60,
  SCRCP, to set aside default judgment, as opposed to the entry of default under
  SCRCP 55(c).Â  However, Kim raised the same grounds in a Rule 59 motion as would
  be raised under Rule 60.Â  Notwithstanding, we need not resolve any issue raised
  by this pleading distinction since Kim actually appeared at the damages hearing
  and preserved her grounds for appeal as to the interpreter.Â  Moreover, Kim
  filed an earlier Rule 55(c) motion which was denied by the court.Â  Since the
  Rule 59(e) motion properly requested the court to address its lack of findings
  pursuant to the interpreter statute, it was the proper procedural mechanism to
  use.Â  The remainder of the Rule 59 motion pertaining to the default issue was
  more properly characterized as a Rule 60(b) motion, SCRCP.Â  We are free to
  treat the motion based upon its substance and effect as opposed to how it was
  captioned.Â  See Mickle v. Blackmon, 255 S.C. 136, 140, 177 S.E.2d
  548, 549 (1970).Â  While recharacterization could be problematic as to the
  timeliness of an appeal since Rule 60 does not toll the filing of an appeal, we
  do not see any jurisdictional bar where part of the relief requested is proper
  pursuant to Rule 59.Â  In any event, the appellant asserts she did not receive
  notice of the entry of judgment until January 8, 2007.Â  Since the appeal was
  filed on February 6, 2007, we find the appeal is timely regardless of how the
motion is characterized.
[7]Â  We recognize that counsel in civil cases will often
  arrange for an interpreter to be present.Â  The trial court has the authority to
  direct that a litigant, especially a non-indigent litigant as found herein,
  provide for and compensate an interpreter.Â  Moreover, the court is not limited
  to qualification only of an interpreter of choice by either one of the parties.Â 
  The court may exercise its discretion in the management of a trial or hearing
  in such a manner as to proceed without multiple interpreters if fairness allows
  it to do so and no prejudice will arise.Â  We leave these decisions to the trial
  court.Â  Notwithstanding, absent a determination that an interpreter is not
  necessary, the court must make findings on waiver as required by the statute.Â 
  The record herein indicates that an interpreter was necessary.Â  The court did
  not base its decision on the failure of counsel to arrange for an interpreter
  or upon a finding that an interpreter was not necessary.Â  Accordingly, the
  trial court should have either qualified the interpreter present and proceeded
  with that interpreter if qualified, or continued the proceeding with
  instructions to the parties to make the necessary arrangements; alternatively,
  the court should have made the findings provided by the statute as to waiver if
the court determined the requirements for waiver were met.

title: Sanders v. S.C. Department of Corrections
description: This appeal arises from inmate Cleveland Sandersâ€™s challenge of the manner by which payment of a two hundred and fifty dollar DNA processing fee (â€œfeeâ€), required by statute, was deducted from his E.H. Cooper Trust Fund account (â€œAccountâ€).  We affirm.
text:
<!--

-->




THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Cleveland Sanders, Appellant,
        v.
        S.C. Department
          of Corrections, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4419
  Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 20,
2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Cleveland Sanders, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Andrew F. Lindemann and Christopher M. Coy, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PIEPER, J.: This appeal arises from inmate Cleveland
  Sandersâ€™ challenge of the manner by which payment of a two hundred and fifty
  dollar DNA processing fee (â€œfeeâ€), required by statute, was deducted from his
  E.H. Cooper Trust Fund account (â€œAccountâ€).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 1994, the South Carolina Legislature created the State
  Deoxyribonucleic Acid Identification Record Database Act (â€œDNA Actâ€), Â§23-3-600
  through Â§23-3-700 of the South Carolina Code of Laws, requiring certain inmates
  to provide DNA samples.Â  The DNA Act lists the classes of offenders who are required
  to give a sample and states when the sample is to be taken.Â  In addition, it
  provides all inmates required to submit a sample must pay the fee.Â  This fee is
  mandatory and may not be waived by a court. 
In August 2004, Sanders, an inmate at the Tuberville Correctional
  Institution (â€œTubervilleâ€), signed a â€œDNA Notice & Payment Proceduresâ€ form
  (â€œPayment Formâ€) indicating three options for payment of the fee: Sanders could
  choose to pay the fee from his Account by completing a Form 15-1, â€œCooper Trust
  Fund Withdrawal;â€ he could have a non-incarcerated family member pay the fee by
  money order; or, he could have the money deducted from his inmate wages at a
  rate of 5% when receiving more than $5.00 for the bi-weekly pay period.Â  Sanders
  did not sign the Form 15-1 authorizing a deduction from his Account, but did
  sign the form authorizing a 5% deduction from his wages each pay period.Â  
At some point after Sanders signed the Payment Form, an
  administrative decision was made to change the fee collection procedure in
  order to facilitate the recovery of the fees and to provide a more equitable
  system where wage-earning inmates were not the only inmates required to pay the
  fee.Â Â  Under the new policy, inmates receiving non-wage deposits into their Account
  would automatically have 10% of those deposits retained to pay the fee.Â  On
  August 18, Acting Director of Operations for the South Carolina Department of
  Corrections (â€œthe Departmentâ€), Robert Ward, disseminated a memorandum to all
  wardens regarding the new procedure.Â  The memorandum stated the new procedure
  would begin September 13, 2004, and requested all wardens notify the inmate
  population of the change in policy.Â  
In late 2004, Sanders noticed several deductions listed on his Account
  statement for payment of the fee.[2]Â 
  The deductions were made from monies directly deposited into his Account from
  family members and friends and were in addition to the 5% deductions taken from
  his wages.Â  Sanders filed a Step 1 Inmate Grievance claiming the DNA Act did
  not allow the Department to withdraw non-wage related funds to cover the fee.Â  Â He
  further argued the DNA Act, as applied to him, was an ex post facto violation
  which enhanced his sentence by assessing additional fees after his punishment
  was adjudicated.Â  Sanders requested â€œthe $24.50 (plus another $30 taken from a
  recent $300 deposit) be credited back to my account and future deposits to me
  from outside sources not be tampered with, unless, of course, the law is
  changed to reflect this practice no longer illegal.â€Â  
The request was denied and Sanders filed an appeal to the
  Administrative Law Judge (â€œALJâ€). Â The ALJ found Sanders had a property
  interest in non-wage funds deposited into his Account, but he was provided
  notice of the change in procedure in a manner that satisfied the requirements
  of minimal due process. Â Additionally, the ALJ refused to hear Sandersâ€™ ex post
  facto claim finding that it lacked jurisdiction to hear the matter.Â  Sanders
  appealed the decision to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court found sufficient
  evidence to support the ALJ and affirmed the decision. Â This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
 In an appeal of
  the final decision of an administrative agency, the standard of appellate
  review is whether the ALJâ€™s findings are supported by substantial evidence.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610(C) (Supp. 2007). Â Although this court shall not
  substitute its judgment for that of the ALJ as to findings of fact, we may
  reverse or modify decisions which are controlled by error of law or are clearly
  erroneous in view of the substantial evidence on the record as a whole. Id. Â In determining whether the ALJâ€™s decision was supported by substantial
  evidence, this court need only find, considering the record as a whole, evidence
  from which reasonable minds could reach the same conclusion that the ALJ
  reached.Â  Durant v. S.C. Dept. of Health and Environmental Control, 361
  S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d 704, 706 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The mere possibility of
  drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent a
  finding from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Id. at 420, 604
  S.E.2d at 707.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Initially,
  we note the Department claims the circuit court erred in affirming the ALJâ€™s
  initial finding Sanders had a property interest in his non-wage funds deposited
  in his Account.Â  We do not address this issue because the Department failed to
  cross appeal the ALJâ€™s finding.Â  Commercial Credit Loans, Inc. v. Riddle,
  334 S.C. 176, 187, 512 S.E.2d 123, 129 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding a lower courtâ€™s
  finding was the law of the case because respondent failed to cross appeal the
  issue); Rule 203(c), SCACR (detailing the proper procedure for filing a cross
  appeal).Â  Therefore, the ALJâ€™s finding that Sanders maintained a property
  interest in non-wage funds deposited into his Account is the law of the case
  and we find the circuit court did not err in affirming the ALJ on this issue. Â See Charleston Lumber Co., Inc. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175,
  525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (finding an unappealed ruling, right or wrong, is
  the law of the case).[3]Â  
Accordingly,
  we next determine whether the notice provided Sanders met the minimal
  requirements of due process. Â Sanders alleges the circuit court erred in
  finding the ALJ properly construed the DNA Act so as to allow the Department to
  recover non-wages in payment of the fee.Â  The DNA Act provides: 

  Processing fee; payment by person
    providing sample. 
    (A) A person who is required to provide a sample pursuant to this
    article must pay a two hundred and fifty dollar processing fee which may not be
    waived by the court.Â  If the person is incarcerated, the fee must be paid
    before the person is paroled or released from confinement and may be garnished
    from wages the person earns while incarcerated.Â  If the person is not sentenced
    to a term of confinement, payment of the fee must be a condition of the
    personâ€™s sentence and may be paid in installments if so ordered by the court.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  23-3-670 (Supp. 2007).Â  Sanders claims
  the statute provides the fee may only be paid from wages earned by inmates.Â  While
  the statute provides the fee may be â€œgarnished from wages,â€ we find it does not
  restrict the Department from recovering the fee from non-wages voluntarily deposited in the inmateâ€™s Account subsequent to notice of the deduction
  procedure.
We also find the circuit
  court properly affirmed the ALJâ€™s finding that the notice provided of the
  change in the fee collection procedure met the minimal requirements of due
  process.Â  When the DNA Act was first enacted, the Department adopted a
  procedure whereby all funds in an inmateâ€™s Account in excess of the recognized indigency
  level were automatically deducted until the fee was fully paid.Â  Sprouse v. Sanford, No. 0:04-22477-RBH (D.S.C. Jan. 22, 2008).Â  The Department subsequently
  changed its procedure to automatically deduct the fee from inmate wages only.Â  Id.Â  This meant that any non-wage
  deposits were not subject to an automatic deduction.Â  Id.Â  This procedure was in place at the time Sanders signed
  the Payment Form in August 2004.Â  Under this procedure, inmates who received
  funds from outside sources avoided payment of the fee while inmates participating
  in work programs faced deductions from their accounts for the fee.Â  
Consequently, the
  Department changed its procedure so as to automatically deduct 10% of all
  non-wage deposits into an Account until the fee was paid in full.Â  Id. Â The manner by which deductions were made from inmate wages remained the same.Â  The
  new procedure was outlined in an August memorandum sent to all wardens within
  the state.Â  The memorandum
  also indicated inmates were to be notified of the change in the procedure prior
  to September 13, 2004.Â  Michael Sheedy,
  the warden at Tuberville in August 2004, stated in his affidavit that the memorandum
  was posted in each housing unit on August 19, 2004.Â  Further, Sheedy stated he notified
  the Inmate Relations Council about the information so that it could assist in
  disseminating the memorandum. Â 
The ALJ found
  sufficient factual evidence that the memorandum was sent to Sheedy on August
  18, 2004, and that Sheedy provided notice to all inmates.Â  The ALJ concluded
  that such notice met the demands of minimal due process and therefore any funds
  deducted from the Account which were deposited after notice were properly
  deducted.Â  The circuit court found sufficient evidence to support the ALJâ€™s
  finding. Â The circuit courtâ€™s review of the ALJ order must be confined to the
  record.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610(C) (Supp. 2007).Â  The circuit court may
  reverse or modify the decision based on errors of law, but may only reverse or
  modify an ALJâ€™s findings of fact if they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id.Â  Further, neither the circuit court nor this court may substitute its judgment
  for that of the ALJ on questions of fact when the facts are supported by
  substantial evidence.Â  Id.; see also Al-Shabazz v.
    State, 338 S.C. 354, 380, 527 S.E.2d 742, 756 (2000).
We find Sanders had
  notice. Â Prior to the change in procedure, he knew he was required to submit a
  DNA sample, pay a two hundred and fifty dollar fee, and knew that the fee was automatically
  going to be deducted from his wages as he signed a form notifying him of
  this procedure as to wages.Â  Further, we find substantial evidence in the
  record to support the ALJâ€™s finding that the memorandum was sent to and
  received by Sheedy and that he provided notice to all inmates regarding the
  change in the fee collection procedure as to non-wages.Â  Therefore, we
  find there was sufficient evidence that the posting of the fee collection
  procedure provided notice and did not violate Sandersâ€™ due process rights; accordingly,
  the circuit court did not err in affirming the ALJâ€™s decision.[4]Â 
  Additionally, we note that once Sanders was provided notice of the change in
  procedure, the deposit of any money, beyond wages, into the Account by Sanders
  or his family and friends was completely voluntary.[5] Â Â 
Lastly, Sanders
  argues the circuit court erred in affirming the ALJâ€™s conclusion it lacked
  jurisdiction to hear his ex post facto claim.Â  We agree. 
An ALJ has
  jurisdiction to hear appeals from the final decision of the Department in
  non-collateral or administrative matters.Â  Al-Shabazz, 338 S.C. at 369,
  527 S.E.2d at 750.Â  â€œAn ex post facto violation occurs when a change in the law
  retroactively alters the definition of a crime or increases the punishment for
  a crime.â€Â  Jernigan v. State, 340 S.C. 256, 261, 531 S.E.2d 507, 509
  (2000).Â  Ex post facto violation claims are non-collateral matters.Â  Id. at 260, 531 S.E.2d at 509.Â  Therefore, we find the ALJ did have jurisdiction to
  hear Sandersâ€™ ex post facto claim.Â  However, for purposes of judicial economy,
  we address Sandersâ€™ ex post facto claim. 
A
  law violates the Ex Post Facto Clauses of the United States and South Carolina
  Constitutions if it 1) applies to events that occurred before its enactment,
  and 2) the offender of the law is disadvantaged by the law.Â  State v. Walls,
  348 S.C. 26, 30, 558 S.E.2d 524, 525 (2002); see also Cooper v. S.C.
    Dept. of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Servs., Op. No. 26480 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed May 5, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 17 at 34) (citing State v. Walls for
  the proposition that the above stated elements must be present for a law to
  fall within the prohibition).Â  Further, â€œfor the [E]x [P]ost [F]acto [C]lause
  to be applicable, the statute or the provision in question must be criminal or
  penal in nature.â€Â  Id.Â  
A
  determination of whether a statute is civil or criminal in nature is primarily
  a question of statutory construction, which begins by reference to the actâ€™s
  text and legislative history.Â  In re Matthews, 345 S.C. 638, 648, 550
  S.E.2d 311, 316 (2001).Â  â€œWhere the legislature has manifested its intent that
  the legislation is civil in nature, the party challenging that classification
  must provide â€˜the clearest proof that the statutory scheme is so punitive in
  either purpose or effect as to negate the [legislatureâ€™s] intention.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Seling v. Young, 531 U.S. 250 (2001)).
In Cannon
  v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Prob., Parole and Pardon Servs., 361 S.C. 425, 604 S.E.2d
  709 (Ct. App. 2004), revâ€™d on other grounds, 371 S.C. 581, 641 S.E.2d
  429 (2007), this court found the DNA Act to be civil in nature.Â  â€œBecause the South Carolina legislatureâ€™s intent appears to have been to protect the public, and not to
  punish those individuals who commit or have committed the specified crimes, South Carolinaâ€™s DNA Act is non-punitive and does not constitute a criminal penalty.â€Â  Id. at 433, 604 S.E.2d at 714. Â Further, this court found the plaintiff had failed
  to prove the DNA Act was so punitive in either purpose or effect as to negate
  the legislatureâ€™s intention.Â  Id.Â  
While
  the supreme court has since reversed Cannon, it did so based upon the
  statutory construction regarding the meaning of the word â€œparoledâ€ as it applied
  to Cannon.Â  The court did not address the finding by this court that the DNA Act
  was civil, not penal, or the finding that the Act did not violate the Ex Post
  Facto Clause.Â  While not controlling due to its ultimate disposition on appeal,
  we find the statutory construction of the DNA Act and the reasoning provided by
this court in Cannon nonetheless persuasive[6].Â  
Â We
  simply are not convinced that the DNA Act makes an act which was innocent
  before the law, criminal thereafter and now punishes said act. Â Moreover, the DNA
  Act does not impose a subsequent greater punishment than that which existed at
  the time the act was committed, nor does it make a crime more aggravated than
  it was when committed before the change in law.Â  Finally, the DNA Act does not alter
  in any way the nature of the proof or evidence necessary for a crime at the
  time of the commission of the offense.Â  See Stogner v. California,
  539 U.S. 607 (2003); Weaver v. Graham, 450 U.S. 24 (1981); Calder v.
    Bull, 3 U.S. 386 (1798); see also Jones v. Murray, 962 F.2d 302, 309 (4th Cir. 1992).
Thus,
  we find the Ex Post Facto Clause is not applicable in this case because the DNA
  Act is civil, not criminal or penal, in nature.Â  Further, having found that any
  deposits made into Sandersâ€™ Account after September 13, 2004, were voluntarily made with notice of the fee collection procedure, we can find no way in which
  the DNA Act is so punitive in either purpose or effect as to negate the
  legislatureâ€™s intent.Â  Had Sanders told family members and friends not to
  deposit monies into his Account, he could have avoided any deduction about
  which he had been provided advance notice.Â  Quite simply, we decline to find a
  punitive effect because Sanders had notice of the consequences and the
  contributions were voluntarily made.
CONCLUSION
We
  find the DNA Act does not restrict the Department from recovering the fee from
  non-wages voluntarily deposited into the inmateâ€™s Account. Â Furthermore, we find there was sufficient evidence that the
  posting of the fee collection procedure provided notice and did not violate
  Sandersâ€™ due process rights; therefore, we conclude the circuit court did not
  err in affirming the ALJâ€™s decision.Â  Lastly, we find the ALJ did have
  jurisdiction to hear Sandersâ€™ ex post facto claim; however, we hold the Ex Post
  Facto Clause is not applicable in this case because the DNA Act is civil, not
  criminal or penal, in nature.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court
  is 
AFFIRMED.

HEARN, C.J., and
GOOLSBY, A.J., concur. 


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Sanders
  received monthly statements indicating all Account activity.Â  The statement
  included wages earned working in the prison library, monies directly deposited
  from family members and friends, and monies withdrawn by Sanders for canteen
purchases. 
[3] Our holding the ALJâ€™s unappealed finding that Sanders
  maintained a property interest is the law of the case should in no way be
  interpreted as this courtâ€™s resolution of this issue.Â  We need not do so under
the posture of this case.
[4] On appeal, Sanders also finds error in the ALJâ€™s
  acceptance of two arguments made by the Department.Â  The Department claimed
  Sandersâ€™ non-wage monies were subject to garnishment because 1) he gave consent
  by signing a Form 1815 and 2) wage and non-wage monies were comingled and there
  was no way to differentiate wages from non-wages.Â  Since the ALJ did not rely on
either argument in his order, we find no error. 
[5] Â Likewise, we note that the new procedure for
  deducting the fee was not applied to any funds previously deposited into
  Sandersâ€™ Account.Â  The new procedure was applied only to those monies deposited
into his Account after September 13, 2004. 
[6]Â  In a recent decision upholding the processing fee
  requirement of the DNA Act, the federal district court in South Carolina
  specifically held that the requirement of payment of a processing fee is civil,
  not criminal or penal.Â  In re DNA Ex Post Facto Issues, No.
  2:99-CV-5555-RBH (D.S.C. Oct. 19, 2007).Â  In arriving at its determination, the
  district court relied on the legislative intent of the statute stating â€œit is
  clear that the intent of the state legislature was not to punish inmates by
  imposition of the fee but rather to provide funds for the implementation and
operation of the database.â€Â  Id. at 5.

title: Leon v. State
description: Mauricio Leon filed a post-conviction relief (PCR) application on May 15, 2002, alleging his guilty plea was involuntary, ineffective assistance of counsel, and denial of due process of law.  The PCR judge vacated Leonâ€™s conviction and ordered a new trial.  We reverse.

<!--

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Mauricio Leon, 277794, Respondent,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Appellant.
      
    
  


Certiorari to Spartanburg County
Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4420
  Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 27,
2008Â Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Henry Dargan McMaster, Attorney General, John W. McIntosh, Chief
          Deputy Attorney General, Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Deputy Attorney General,
          and Molly R. Crum, Assistant Attorney General, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Symmes W. Culbertson, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN,
  C.J.: Mauricio Leon filed a post-conviction relief (PCR) application on May 15, 2002, alleging his guilty
  plea was involuntary, ineffective assistance of counsel, and denial of due
  process of law.Â  The PCR judge vacated Leonâ€™s conviction and ordered a new
  trial.Â  We reverse. 
FACTS
Leon pled guilty to following offenses: Â (1) trafficking more than 400 grams of cocaine;
  (2) two counts of trafficking 10 to 28 grams of methamphetamine; and (3)
  trafficking 10 to 28 grams of cocaine.Â  Leon is a native of Mexico and speaks very little English.Â  The interpreter present at the guilty plea hearing, while
  approved by the court, did not appear to be under oath.Â  Leon was sentenced to twenty-five years and a $200,000 fine for trafficking more than 400 grams of cocaine,
  to run concurrent with sentences of ten years and a $25,000 fine for each of
  the remaining three charges.Â  The sum of his sentence was twenty-five years of
  incarceration and fines amounting to $275,000.
Leon filed a PCR application, and a hearing was held.Â  The PCR judge granted Leonâ€™s petition for PCR, finding Leonâ€™s counsel was ineffective for failing to object to the
  interpreter not being sworn at the guilty plea hearing.Â  The PCR judge found
  â€œthe trial counselâ€™s failure to preserve the issue of the omission of the
  interpreterâ€™s oath [constitutes] ineffective assistance of counsel.â€Â  As a result,
  the State petitioned this court for writ of certiorari. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  State contends the PCR judge erred in granting Leonâ€™s PCR application.Â  Specifically
  the State argues Leon failed to meet both prongs of the Strickland test
  for ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  We agree.
In
  order to establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, a PCR
  applicant must prove: (1) counselâ€™s performance was deficient; and (2) the
  deficient performance prejudiced the applicantâ€™s case.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984); Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 117, 386
  S.E.2d 624, 625 (1989).Â  To show counsel was deficient, the applicant must
  establish counsel failed to render reasonably effective assistance under
  prevailing professional norms.Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 687;Â Â  Cherry, 300 S.C. at 117-18, 386 S.E.2d at 625.Â  When a guilty plea has been
  entered, the applicant must prove counselâ€™s representation was below the
  standard of reasonableness and but for counselâ€™s unprofessional errors, there
  is a reasonable probability the applicant would not have pled guilty and would
  have insisted on going to trial.Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 58-59 (1985); Alexander v. State, 303 S.C. 539, 543, 402 S.E.2d 484, 485
  (1991).Â  In determining guilty plea issues, it is proper to consider the guilty
  plea transcript, as well as evidence at the PCR hearing.Â  Harres v. Leeke,
  282 S.C. 131, 133, 318 S.E.2d 360, 361 (1984).Â  
Even
  if we assume counselâ€™s performance was deficient, Leon has the burden to
  establish prejudice under the two-prong Strickland test.Â  â€œ[I]n order to
  satisfy the â€˜prejudiceâ€™ requirement [in the context of a guilty plea], the
  defendant must show that there is a reasonable probability that, but for
  counselâ€™s errors, he would not have pleaded guilty and would have insisted on
  going to trial.â€Â  Alexander, 303 S.C. at 542, 402 S.E.2d at 485.Â  Here, Leon testified he did not understand the interpreter provided by the court because he was
  nervous and the interpreter spoke too fast.Â  However, when asked during
  direct-examination if he would have gone to trial instead of pleading guilty if
  someone would have further explained his rights or possible defenses, Leonâ€™s
  response was, â€œNo.â€Â  Thus, Leon fails to prove the deficient performance by his
  attorney prejudiced his case.Â  Because Leon did not establish prejudice, the
  PCR court erred in granting PCR.Â  Therefore, the order of the PCR court is
REVERSED.[1] 
KITTREDGE, J.,
  and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

title: McLaughlin v. Williams
description: McLaughlin appealed from the circuit court's grant of summary judgment in favor of McLaughlin's realtor, the seller, and the seller's realtor for McLaughlin's claims of fraud and negligent misrepresentation pertaining to the purchase of McLaughlin's home.  On appeal, McLaughlin claimed a genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether he had a right to rely on an incomplete disclosure statement furnished by the seller, which failed to show structural defects due to prior water damage.  The Court of Appeals affirmed the circuit court finding McLaughlin did not have a reasonable right to rely on the disclosure statement as he received a home inspection report and a termite damage report, both indicating moisture damage to the home.

<!--

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Dugan J.
          McLaughlin, Appellant,
        v.
        Sally W.
          Williams, Coldwell Banker Chicora Real Estate, Dunes Realty, Inc., Dan
          Laudone d/b/a U.S. Home Inspections, Inc., and Michael W. Alpaugh d/b/a
          Xtreme Termite & Pest Control, Defendants,
        of whom Sally
          W. Williams, Coldwell Banker Chicora Real Estate, and Dunes Realty, Inc. are Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4421
  Submitted March 1, 2008 â€“ Filed June 30,
2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        N. Ward Lambert, R. Patrick Smith, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Amanda A. Bailey, Mark McAdams, of Myrtle Beach, Kathryn M. Cook,
          of North Myrtle Beach, PhillipÂ  Ferderigos, Charleston, for Respondents.
        Luther O. McCutchen, III, of Myrtle Beach, Nikole Setzler Mergo,
          of Columbia, for Defendants.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Dugan J.
  McLaughlin (McLaughlin) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment
  on his claims for fraud and negligent misrepresentation.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In
  2003, McLaughlin was searching for a house to purchase in Myrtle Beach or Georgetown,   South Carolina.Â  McLaughlin utilized the services of Barbara Kingsmore
  (Kingsmore), a real estate agent with Coldwell Banker Chicora Real Estate
  (Chicora), to locate a suitable house.Â  
Kingsmore
  showed various properties to McLaughlinâ€™s mother-in-law, who believed
  McLaughlin might be interested in the property located at 138 Tarpon Circle in Georgetown (the Subject Property).Â  At the time, the Subject Property was owned by Sally W.
  Williams (Williams), and Dunes Realty, Inc. (Dunes Realty) was Williamsâ€™ listing
  agent.Â  
On
  May 3, 2003, Kingsmore contacted Dunes Realty and requested a Residential
  Property Disclosure Statement (the Disclosure Statement) for the Subject
  Property.Â  On May 5, 2003, Williams and her husband prepared the Disclosure
  Statement, which was subsequently sent to Kingsmore.Â  Upon receipt of the
  Disclosure Statement, Kingsmore noticed several of the items were left blank
  and there were no explanations for certain items, indicating possible problems
  with the Subject Property.Â  Kingsmore requested a more complete disclosure
  statement; however, neither Dunes nor Williams provided one.Â  
On May 14, 2003,
  Kingsmore showed the Subject Property to McLaughlin.Â  Ultimately, McLaughlin
  decided to submit an offer to purchase the Subject Property and executed
  contracts with Chicora to establish the representative relationship between the
  parties.Â  On May 15, 2003, Kingsmore showed the Disclosure Statement to
  McLaughlin and advised him to obtain an inspection to ensure there were no
  major defects with the Subject Property.Â  McLaughlin initialed each page of the
  Disclosure Statement, signifying he had reviewed it.Â  
Following
  negotiations between McLaughlin and Williams, the parties entered into an
  Agreement of Sale and Purchase and scheduled the closing for June 18, 2003.Â 
  Pursuant to the agreement, McLaughlin employed U.S. Home Inspections to perform
  a â€œwhole house inspectionâ€ on the Subject Property.Â  Following the inspection,
  McLaughlin received a written inspection report (the Home Inspection Report)
  indicating moisture damage to the exterior of the Subject Property. 
In addition to the
  Home Inspection Report, a termite and moisture inspection (the CL-100) was
  performed on the Subject Property and included in the closing documents.Â  The
  CL-100 indicated the presence of wood-destroying fungi and a wood moisture
  content of 28% or more below the first main floor.Â  
On
  June 18, 2003, McLaughlin closed and took possession of the Subject Property.Â 
  Approximately six weeks following the closing, McLaughlin learned of defects in
  the structure of the Subject Property due to prior water intrusion.Â  
McLaughlin asserted
  claims for fraud and negligent misrepresentation against Williams, Chicora, and
  Dunes Realty.Â  Separately, each defendant filed a motion for summary judgment.Â 
  In separate orders, the circuit court granted summary judgment for all three
  defendants.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
When
  reviewing the grant of a summary judgment
  motion, this Court applies the same standard of review as the circuit court
  under Rule 56, SCRCP. Â Cowburn v. Leventis, 366 S.C. 20, 30, 619 S.E.2d
  437, 443 (Ct. App. 2005). Â Summary judgment
  is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving
  party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law. Â Id.Â  To determine
  whether any triable issues of fact exist, the reviewing court must consider the
  evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the
  non-moving party. Â Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
McLaughlin
  argues the trial court improperly granted summary judgment in favor of Williams and Chicora because there was a genuine issue of
  material fact as to his ability to rely upon the Disclosure Statement.Â  We
  disagree.
To
  survive a motion for summary judgment, McLaughlin must offer some evidence that
  a genuine issue of material fact existed as to each element of fraud and negligent misrepresentation. SeeÂ  Steele v. Rogers,
  306 S.C. 546, 552, 413 S.E.2d 329, 333 (Ct. App. 1992) (explaining the plaintiff
  has the burden to prove each element of the cause of
  action).Â  To maintain a claim for fraud, a plaintiff must show by clear and convincing
  evidence:

  (1) a
    representation; (2) its falsity; (3) its materiality; (4) knowledge of its
    falsity or a reckless disregard for its truth or falsity; (5) intent that the
    plaintiff act upon the representation; (6) the hearerâ€™s ignorance of its
    falsity; (7) the hearerâ€™s reliance on its truth; (8) the hearerâ€™s right to rely
    thereon; and (9) the hearerâ€™s
    consequent and proximate injury.

Hendricks v. Hicks, 374 S.C. 616, 620, 649 S.E.2d 151,
  152-53 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  To maintain
  a claim for negligent misrepresentation, a plaintiff must show by a
  preponderance of the evidence: 

  (1) the
    defendant made a false representation to the plaintiff; (2) the defendant had a
    pecuniary interest in making the statement; (3) the defendant owed a duty of
    care to see that he communicated truthful information to the plaintiff; (4) the
    defendant breached that duty by failing to exercise due care; (5) the plaintiff
    justifiably relied on the representation; and (6) the plaintiff suffered a
    pecuniary loss as the proximate result of his reliance upon the representation.

Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v.
  Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 473-74, 581
  S.E.2d 496, 504 (Ct. App. 2003).
â€œThe
  key difference between fraud
  and negligent misrepresentation is that fraud requires the conveyance of a
  known falsity, while negligent misrepresentation is predicated upon
  transmission of a negligently made false statement.â€ Armstrong v. Collins,
  366 S.C. 204, 219-20, 621 S.E.2d 368, 375-76 (Ct. App. 2005) (internal
  quotations and citations omitted).Â  While the two causes of action differ, both
  fraud and negligent misrepresentation contain â€œthe necessary element that the
  hearer had the right to rely upon
  the misrepresentation or fraud.â€Â  Id.Â  
Initially,
  we note McLaughlinâ€™s claims against each of the three defendants are based on his
  assertion that the Disclosure Statement completed by Williams was a
  misrepresentation.Â  Specifically, McLaughlinâ€™s complaint asserted: 1) the
  Disclosure Statement was a misrepresentation, upon which he reasonably and
  detrimentally relied; and 2) all three Defendants had a statutory duty to
  ensure that the Disclosure Statement was in compliance with the applicable
  statutory law.Â  Because McLaughlinâ€™s claims focused on the Disclosure Statement
  as a misrepresentation, we must determine whether McLaughlin was entitled to
  rely on the Disclosure Statement itself.Â  
In arguing summary judgment was inappropriate because
  there was an issue of fact as to whether he could rely upon the Disclosure
  Statement, McLaughlin points to the general premise that â€œissues of reliance and its reasonableness going as
  they do to subjective states of mind and applications of objective standards of
  reasonableness, are preeminently factual issues for the trier of facts.â€Â  Unlimited
    Servs., Inc. v. Macklen Enters., Inc., 303 S.C. 384, 387, 401 S.E.2d 153,
  155 (1991) (internal quotations and citations omitted).Â  Additionally,
  McLaughlin notes â€œa buyer has the right
  in South Carolina to rely on a seller of a home to disclose latent defects or
  hidden conditions which are not discoverable on a reasonable examination of the
  property and of which the seller has knowledge.â€Â  May v. Hopkinson, 289
  S.C. 549, 557, 347 S.E.2d 508, 513 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  Â Â 
However,
  while issues of reliance are ordinarily resolved by the finder of fact, â€œthere can be no reasonable reliance on a misstatement if the
  plaintiff knows the truth of the matter.â€Â  Gruber v. Santee Frozen Foods,
    Inc., 309 S.C. 13, 20, 419 S.E.2d 795, 800 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Thus, if
  the undisputed evidence clearly shows the party asserting reliance has
  knowledge of the truth of the matter, there is no genuine issue of material
  fact. 
In
  the instant case, the circuit court determined McLaughlin failed to create an
  issue of fact regarding reliance on the Disclosure Statement in light of the
  information available to him prior to closing.Â  The circuit court pointed to
  the information contained in the Home Inspection Report and the CL-100, which
  showed the existence of water damage to the Subject Property, as well as the
  testimony of McLaughlin and Kingsmore stating such information placed them on
  notice of potential moisture problems.Â  Ultimately, the circuit court
  determined because of this information, no reasonable jury could conclude
  McLaughlin had a right to rely on the Disclosure Statement.Â  
McLaughlin
  argues there is an issue of fact as to what level of knowledge could be gleaned
  from the information contained in the two reports.Â  Specifically, he argues the
  Home Inspection Report does not indicate water damage to locations within the
  interior portion of the house, and therefore, there is an issue of fact as to
  whether or not the Home Inspection Report precluded him from relying upon the
  Disclosure Statement.Â  McLaughlin also argues the CL-100 only indicates the
  presence of active wood destroying fungi, which is not an issue in this case.Â 
  We disagree.
Although
  the Disclosure Statement indicated Williams was not aware of a malfunction or
  defect due to â€œwater seepage, leakage, dampness or standing water or water
  intrusion from any source in any area of the structure,â€ the Home
  Inspection Report clearly informed McLaughlin there was â€œ[s]ome moisture
  damageâ€ in various locations on the exterior of Subject Property.[2] (emphasis added).Â  The CL-100 reported â€œactive wood destroying fungiâ€ and a moisture
  content of at least 28% below the first main floor of the house.Â  Furthermore, the CL-100 explicitly noted â€œfungi damage to woodâ€ is â€œcommonly called
  water damage.â€Â  Both the Home Inspection Report and the CL-100 clearly show McLaughlin
  had information that directly contradicted the Disclosure Statement.Â  
In addition to the
  information contained in the Home Inspection Report and CL-100, McLaughlinâ€™s
  testimony also supports the conclusion that he could not, as a matter of law,
  rely upon the Disclosure Statement.Â  McLaughlin testified the documents reflect
  moisture damage at the home and should have â€œraised red flags.â€Â  
In
  sum, the Home Inspection Report and CL-100 clearly illustrate McLaughlin had
  information indicating there was moisture damage to the Subject Property.Â 
  McLaughlin had knowledge that directly contradicted the representations found
  in the Disclosure Statement, and therefore, as a matter of law, he failed to
  establish the necessary element of reliance for his claims of fraud and negligent
  misrepresentation.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in its grant of
  summary judgment.
We
  affirm the circuit court on the basis that McLaughlin could not rely on the
  Disclosure Statement because the Home Inspection Report and CL-100 gave him knowledge
  contradicting the Disclosure Statement.Â  While this is clearly dispositive of
  McLaughlinâ€™s claims for fraud and negligent misrepresentation, the circuit
  court also noted several other grounds for granting summary judgment, and
  McLaughlin appeals on those grounds as well.Â  For the sake of completeness, we
  address those grounds.Â Â Â  Â Â 
McLaughlin
  argues the circuit court erred in failing to apply the holding of MacFarlane
    v. Manly, 274 S.C. 392, 395, 264 S.E.2d 838, 840 (1980), in which the South
  Carolina Supreme Court held an â€œas isâ€ clause and a â€œright to inspectâ€
  provision contained in a contract for sale do not, as a matter of law, bar an
  action for fraud.Â  It is important to note, however, the circuit court did not
  conclude the â€œas isâ€ clause and the â€œright to inspectâ€ provision contained in
  the sales contract between McLaughlin and Williams barred McLaughlinâ€™s fraud
  claims.Â  
The
  order of the circuit court specifically states the â€œas isâ€ clause and the
  â€œright to inspectâ€ provision did not bar the cause of action for fraud.Â 
  Rather, the circuit court determined the â€œas isâ€ clause and the â€œright to
  inspectâ€ provision barred the claim for negligent misrepresentation as a matter
  of law because he could not justifiably rely on the disclosure statement in
  light of those provisions in the contract.Â  On appeal, McLaughlin challenges
  the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion on the basis that he did in fact inspect the
  property and could rely on the Disclosure Statement in light of such
  inspection.Â  However, having concluded McLaughlin could not rely on the
  Disclosure Statement due to the information contained in the Home Inspection
  Report and the CL-100, we cannot accept this argument.Â Â  
McLaughlin
  also challenges the circuit courtâ€™s determination that Kingsmoreâ€™s knowledge is
  imputed to McLaughlin due to their agency relationship. Â The circuit court did
  not rely upon this determination for its conclusion, however, having already
  found McLaughlin could not rely upon the Disclosure Statement based on the
  information personally available to McLaughlin.Â  
McLaughlin also
  argues he relied on Kingsmoreâ€™s knowledge, pointing to his own testimony that
  she told him there was nothing to worry about after reviewing the Home
  Inspection Report.Â  Kingsmore testified she informed McLaughlin the Home
  Inspection Report showed moisture damage and a potential for structural
  problems, and she advised him to have a contractor or electrician inspect the
  house.Â  While this testimony may raise an issue of fact as to what Kingsmore
  told McLaughlin, it does not raise an issue of fact as to whether McLaughlin
  could rely on the Disclosure Statement.Â  McLaughlinâ€™s complaint alleges he is
  entitled to recover based upon his reliance on the Disclosure Statement, as he
